PETITION.TITLE: Ambassador to Ireland and Holy See
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recall Australia's Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, (Mr Brian Burke) and suspend his appointment while matters of propriety relating to his actions as Premier and subsequently which have been referred to the Minister are investigated, and moreover during the term of the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
And your petitions as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Farm
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That family farming and small business assets are unsuitable for inclusion in the assets test for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm and the assets of other small businesses from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education in ACT
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the Chubb Report on Higher Education for the A.C.T. which proposes that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the Faculties of the Australian National University and the Faculties be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. We believe that the implementation of these proposals would mean the destruction of the Australian National University's national and international high standing and firmly established reputation as a centre of excellence in research and scholarship. The dismemberment of the ANU would severely effect the ability of both the Institute and the Faculties to attract, or even retain, high quality academic staff, funding and support. It would also adversely affect the recruitment of top students. The maintenance of the Australian National University, as it is now constituted,-a national university with an international, national and local role-is of vital importance to the A.C.T. and Australia.
2. We call on the Senate to reject the recommendations of the Chubb report and to support the integrity of the ANU and the existing relationship between the Institute and the Faculties.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
* to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
* the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
* the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
* the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 proposes to amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to enable, among other things, collection of the superannuation supervisory levy which is proposed to be imposed by the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991. It should be read as one with that Bill. It is to come into operation on the day on which it receives Royal Assent.

The Bill also proposes a number of other changes to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Act 1987 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, to which I shall refer later.

Trustees of funds or trusts who lodge an annual return with the Commissioner would be liable to pay the levy when they lodge the return and it would be due and payable at the time of lodgment. It would not be a requirement for the levy, or the full amount of the levy, to be paid at the time of lodgment. However, where some levy remains unpaid, the Commissioner would have the option of either issuing or not issuing a notice concerning the satisfaction of the fund or trust conditions.

The Commissioner proposes to issue guidelines within which he would make decisions to refuse to issue a notice because of an unpaid levy. The Commissioner's decision would be a reviewable decision under the provisions of section 16 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act. This means that the decision could be reconsidered by the Commissioner and if necessary the fund or trust could apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if it were to remain dissatisfied with the outcome of the review.

A late payment penalty may apply if any levy moneys were to remain unpaid after lodgment. This is consistent with provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act, imposing a penalty for the late payment of tax.

The late payment penalty would be calculated on a monthly basis, at a rate of 20 per cent per annum of the levy which remains unpaid at the commencement of the relevant month, subject to a minimum monthly amount.

The late payment penalty would be calculated in the same way as the late lodgment component of the levy under the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill and the use of whole calendar months would provide a smooth cross over from one to the other, where relevant. The provisions would simplify the calculations necessary to determine the total levy to be paid. It is envisaged that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission would produce a simple ready reckoner for this purpose, to which trustees would be able to refer. In addition, the arrangements outlined would facilitate the streamlining of annual return processing in the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
The levy and late payment penalty would be payable to the Commissioner and would be able to be recovered as debts due to the Commonwealth.

The proposed new arrangements outlined above would encourage the timely payment of the correct levy amount. They would also provide flexibility by allowing the Commissioner to process returns and issue a notice of compliance in cases of small underpayments arising from simple and genuine error.

The Commissioner would be able to remit the whole or a part of the late lodgment amount and the whole or a part of a late payment penalty. Guidelines would be issued by the Commissioner which would set out the criteria for the making of such decisions and, as with his decisions to refuse to issue notices of compliance because of unpaid levies, these decisions would be ultimately reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

For flexibility of administration, the Bill provides for the Commissioner to recover amounts of unpaid levy for a previous year from a current year's levy payment. This would enable the Commissioner to refuse to issue a notice of compliance to a fund relating to a current year if there were unpaid amounts arising from previous years and the total payment does not cover all amounts payable.

The Commissioner would be able to make regulations providing for exemptions from the levy, remissions of levy, the manner of payment for the levy and other amounts payable under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act and for the refund, or other application, of overpayments.

For the first few years, until accurate asset profiles of funds and trusts are available, it will be difficult to accurately estimate the revenue which would be generated each year by a prescribed levy which is graduated according to asset size. Also, the precise amount of revenue that would be required to be raised in the first year of the levy, to fully recover relevant costs of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and based on the relevant current functions of the Commission, has yet to be confirmed.
It is estimated, however, that the amount required to be raised by the basic levy in the first year or two would be of the order of $6m to $8m: these amounts are therefore estimated revenue targets.
The revenue estimates do not include any estimate of revenue which might be generated by the late payment penalty.
If the current flat $40 fee were continued, it is estimated that revenue would be of the order of $3.6m.
Apart from the provisions relating to the collection of the superannuation supervisory levy, other provisions of the Bill provide that:

(1) annual returns to the Commissioner by funds and trusts, and notices to the Commissioner required by the reasonable benefit limits provisions of Sections 15F and 15G of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act may, with the Commissioner's approval and within the Commissioner's specifications, be able to be supplied on a data processing device such as a diskette;

(2) a request by a person under section 15Q of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act for a copy of a previous reasonable benefit limit determination must be accompanied by a fee if such a fee is prescribed in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations;

(3) where the Commissioner considers it is reasonable, he may exercise a discretion to accept a part payment of a fee as full payment where that fee relates to a return for a year prior to 1990-91 or to a return for that year which is lodged before the Bill receives Royal Assent. This is to overcome a flaw in the existing legislation which effectively requires the Commissioner to recover all underpayments, no matter how small.

The Bill also proposes amendments to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Act to correct a technical oversight that occurred when the pooled superannuation trust provisions were inserted in 1989, and proposes amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act to make it clear that the late lodgment amount is not deductible from the taxable income of a fund or trust.

All the amendments to be achieved by this Bill would come into effect on the Bill receiving Royal Assent, and, to the extent that they affect returns to be lodged by funds and trusts, would apply to returns lodged after the Bill receives Royal Assent which are for the year of income commencing on 1 July 1990 or a subsequent year of income.
I commend the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill to the Senate, and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may remember that at the adjournment last night I was talking about the then most recent proposal before the public from the Australian Democrats and was noting without surprise that their proposal conveniently divided the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) into constituencies of just such a size that with their normal vote the Australian Democrats might reasonably be able to expect to win a seat in each of those constituencies. That is a surprise to the Senate, I am sure. The Democrats will continue to assume that everybody else makes decisions on self-interest whereas they make their decisions on principle, which always conveniently suits them. But that is not a matter on which I wish to dwell any further. I made that point yesterday, and I enjoyed the chance to make it twice.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the report appearing in this morning's Canberra Times newspaper, the details of which are not yet fully disclosed, but which indicates that the ACT Liberal Party, the Australian Democrats, the Residents Rally and the Proportional Representation Society-a quadrella that nobody would want back-have come to an agreement about what form of Hare-Clark they will support, and the details of that are going to be disclosed later today.

From a partisan Labor Party point of view it is a pity that that agreement has been reached because we would have continued to have a bit of fun until the day they had come to such an agreement. But I think the debate will be enhanced because they have come to such an agreement so early. I look forward to the release of the details, and whether they have Robson rotations, Buchanan versions or other such spectacular innovations will be a matter we will await with interest but not much enthusiasm.

There are some important questions flowing from this agreement which I want to make clear to Senator Reid and Senator Bell before they speak. I have consulted with the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) this morning following that agreement, which of course we expected would come at some time but which has been indicated is going to happen today. I want to make the following three points to Senators Reid and Bell which I think they will welcome.

First, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats in this chamber and in the House of Representatives will be consulted about the wording of the Hare-Clark question on the referendum. Secondly, if there is to be a publicly funded document of the normal yes-no type-and there has not been any decision of whether that should be done-in accordance with normal practice the Liberal Party and the Australian Democrats will be expected, and we will be happy for them, to write the Hare-Clark case. We will, of course, write the House of Representatives case and, in the interests of consistency, which is standard, we will be seeking some sort of common format within which those two will be written. Thirdly, we would wish that common format include a sample of what the ballot-paper would look like under each of the two systems being proposed. Those are proposals which I think would be welcomed by the Liberal Party and Australian Democrats. I have consulted the Minister and he is happy for me to convey that information to the chamber this morning.

Although there is a lot more that can be said and will be said during the course of the important debate about the electoral system in the ACT, I will confine myself to saying that I look forward to both the election in February and the campaign for the referendum. The referendum is a matter in which I expect to be somewhat more involved than the election itself. It is nice to have an election in which one is not a candidate; it is much better for the nerves.

I look forward to the referendum campaign. I will be supporting the introduction into the ACT Legislative Assembly of the system for the House of Representatives, because I think it meets the multiple objectives of electoral systems better than any alternative that has been considered and better than any version of the Hare-Clark which may come forward. Whatever the outcome, the development of an electoral system which is chosen by the people of the ACT, which has their confidence and which has the standard democratic legitimacy that the system around Australia enjoys, is desirable.

Whichever State one goes to in Australia where there is no gerrymander, the electoral system essentially has the support of the people and they accept that the outcome delivered under it are fair. Although they do not always like it if their side does not win, they accept that the system is fair and appropriate. It is desirable that that should be the case in the ACT. The outcome of the processes set in train by this Bill, when it is finally amended, will be a step forward in the development of democracy in the ACT. Therefore, I look forward to the debate around it but I welcome and support the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The central theme of my remarks today concerns the wastefulness of actually conducting this debate at this time. That does not mean that it should not be conducted at all-we have been anxious to see it come on for some months, even years-but there are reasons why it is a waste to have this debate now. Senator McMullan told us yesterday that he favoured single member electorates and in a previous debate on this matter the Government made it quite clear that it also favoured single member electorates. But on the strength of that, what we see in front of us today is the Government introducing a Bill which plainly it does not support, knowing that the Opposition will be presenting substantial amendments to that Bill and knowing that the Australian Democrats do not support the direction of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill is intended to bring about an electoral system which will become redundant as soon as it is used. At the same time, this Bill intends to bring about a referendum which will be conducted concurrently with that soon to be redundant electoral system. The referendum will choose the next electoral system, but after that the responsibility for choosing an electoral system for future elections will be devolved to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) legislature. But in the middle of all this, the Government proposes to hive off this Bill to a committee; so yet another variable and possibility for devising yet another electoral system is introduced to the whole mess to make a greater mess.

Yesterday Senator McMullan rightly described a camel committee procedure. We know what is involved there, but in this case we have a bubbling, broiling mess into which this Government proposes to drop yet another camel. I really cannot understand the purpose of that. The only purpose I can see is to move the responsibility away from the Government to other groups so that the Government can suggest that other groups have had a part in devising the electoral system.

It is apparent to me that this whole mess has been caused by this Government's inability to actually recognise what the ACT needs in terms of an electoral system, what the electorate of the ACT wants, and what the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia is likely to accept. It is the Government's incapacity to deal with this whole system which causes us to be engaged in this waste of time today. We can describe it as a waste of time because all of this could be avoided by conducting a referendum as soon as possible to determine what the electors of the ACT would prefer.

The preference of the ACT electorate could be determined by the referendum. Of course, that preference should involve the opportunity to choose between existing and understood systems. That is essentially what the proposed referendum, to be conducted concurrently with the next ACT election, has identified. The systems have been identified as the best proportional representation system in Australia, the Hare-Clark system, or single member electorates.

In passing, I must comment that other systems were available within Australia that could have been instituted before we had this abomination of the d'Hondt arrangement. The Senate system, which is another system of proportional representation, is a system which is understood by Australians. It is a ready-made system which has been road-tested, if you like, in Australia, as has the Hare-Clark proportional representational system. Again in passing, the problems that have been created here result from the attempts to modify a system which is foreign to Australia.

From what should have been a simple, straightforward matter of whether to allow the ACT to choose its own form of election system this has become an entwined, convoluted conglomeration of grubby party political machinations. These things are unintelligible and even unexplainable to the majority of the ACT citizens, but that majority of ACT citizens is quite clear about one thing-it is quite clear about its abhorrence of d'Hondt. Anything that smells-even a whiff-of d'Hondt has become an anathema to those who vote in the ACT.

This move here today contrives to impose d'Hondt on the ACT for at least this forthcoming election. We can be told that it is modified modified demodified d'Hondt, but it is still d'Hondt and that is what offends the people of the ACT. That is what they fail to understand. After that election it is to become redundant. We were told yesterday by Senator McMullan that it would be a considerable drafting expense-time, effort and energy-to modify d'Hondt to become modified modified demodified d'Hondt, and yet it is to be redundant immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be no less expensive to do it and go to a referendum straight away. You don't understand.

—Senator McMullan does not understand and that is the problem. The need to have this one election under a soon to be redundant system which will never serve us again, which is repulsive to the ACT electorate, is non-existent. It could have been avoided; it could even be avoided now. That is an unnecessary expense.

SPEECH.PARA: The expense of sending it off to a committee to devise this system is considerable on its own. I would hate to attempt to evaluate that expense, but we know that it is considerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to do that if you are going to a referendum straight away. You know that. Why don't you admit it?

—I will not admit that we would have to send the whole business off to a committee. If we had a referendum now to choose between the tried and true Hare-Clark system, and a single member electorate system which the electorate of Australia understands, why would we have to go to a committee to devise modification of that? I would imagine that that process would be considerably cheaper than the convoluted contrivances which we are faced with today. This move contrives to impose d'Hondt on the ACT for at least another election. That is something which I see as being an unjustifiable expense.

SPEECH.PARA: The excuse given by the coalition for not supporting a referendum as soon as possible had to do with the cost of a referendum. There has been no recognition of the extra costs associated with the administration of another clumsy d'Hondt arrangement. The administration itself requires education. That is another point which Senator McMullan included in his justification-that there needs to be time for education and explanation. If we are to explain the modified modified demodified, second time around d'Hondt, it will need more time and greater expense than would be required to explain a system which is already tried and proven in Australia-the system which the electors of the ACT have already had some exposure to with regard to the Senate elections. I presume Senator McMullan realises that he got here as a result of a proportional representation system of election-the Senate election itself. Such a system should not require a great deal of explanation to those electors who elected him.

The other cost which has not been mentioned by those who have claimed that the cost of a referendum would be greater than is justifiable is the cost to good government of the operation of an electoral system which is demonstrably incapable of delivering to the electorate what it wants. Against the immense costs of poor government and clumsy electoral systems, opponents of the referendum now in the ACT claim that the potential cost of something less than $1m or approximately $1m is just too much.

If $1m is too much to spend on bringing about a more workable electoral system for the ACT, then we can assume that that is the extent to which representative democracy has been devalued by such commentators. If we really believe in representative democracy, we should be taking every opportunity to improve the system by which we elect our representatives. If we are parsimonious to the extent that we will not spend $1m to bring about an improvement, then our belief in representative democracy should be questioned.

The drafting of this complicated legislation for this one election could not even be justified on the grounds of being of any interest to electoral commentators or political science students or even the advancement of electoral studies within Australia. After this concoction is made redundant, I doubt that there will even be passing interest in such a thing. I doubt that anybody would want to examine the process for any reason other than idle curiosity. I cannot see any reason why any other group of citizens throughout the world would ever want to copy it or take an example from it.

If this Government were really interested in saving every possible dollar in the pursuit of a resolution of this problem, we would have seen greater efforts being made to negotiate amendments to this Bill before bringing it to this chamber and then sending it off to a committee. Mention was made earlier of previous negotiations with the Democrats on this matter. That is as well as may be. That was conducted in a different situation with different principles in mind.

At this point, the negotiations have bogged down with a similar sort of description as Senator McMullan gave about the Democrats' position previously. The position, as I understand it, from those representing the Government on this matter has simply been that single member electorates is its preferred position, that it would like to reach a situation where it could at least run that argument through, and that a referendum would allow it that possibility, but a referendum could not be conducted too soon because it might expose the argument over self-government or non self-government again. If that happened too soon, it might detract from the process of the election. That situation was described on behalf of the Government by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Simmons, in the other place. He said in his speech on the matter that:
. . . any referendum result is unlikely to identify clear electoral support for any single system.
Further he said:
. . . and may merely serve to regenerate earlier debates on the merits of self-government.

Apart from the cost matter, that was given as a justification for not conducting a referendum. It seems to me that the debate on self-government or non self-government has been accepted with greater maturity by the electorate of the ACT. The myriad press comments on this matter and the continual re-emergence of this discussion on talkback radio news items, et cetera, have not generated that discussion. Yet each of those media opportunities could have been taken by any one of those commentators to regenerate that argument. I do not think that that argument has been taken with the immaturity to which the Minister referred in his speech.

The electorate of the ACT has gone past that. The electors of the ACT are concerned about the system which will be foisted upon them. They are concerned, informed and wish to see that problem resolved. All we are doing here is putting several steps in the way of that process of resolution. We could have simplified it better still within our capacity by introducing a referendum as soon as possible. I have outlined what I consider to be some of the not inconsiderable costs which will be associated with going through the hoops that we have here. Those costs come very close to outweighing the cost which it is claimed the referendum would bring.

The Australian Democrats' position on this has been consistent over some years and essentially coincides with the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in that a referendum should be held in the ACT to choose between a system of proportional representation and single member electorates. We believe that that should be held as soon as possible and, if possible, before the next election is due.

We believe that the d'Hondt system has been and will continue to be rejected by the ACT electorate. As was mentioned in passing by Senator Macdonald, we are also pleased to note that several political organisations within the ACT have developed this matter a little further to the extent that representatives of the Liberal Party of Australia, the Proportional Representation Society of Australia, the Residents Rally and the Australian Democrats met and agreed on the type of Hare-Clark system that they will endorse in the forthcoming referendum. The group has written to me and informed me of its unity on this matter. The fears that Senator McMullan has are quite well founded. The group is particularly unified. Its degree of sophistication and understanding of the possibilities has allowed it to put aside the technical difficulties and arguments which one might expect of such a widely representative group. Its unity is on simplifying Hare-Clark in its description to the electorate of the ACT and to stick with the aspects of Hare-Clark which have been refined in the Tasmanian electorate to such an extent that it is easily understood and truly representative. This group has paid particular attention to what has worked well in Tasmania. I will mention a couple of points about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Robson rotation as well?

—This is the point. I will accept that interjection and address that because quite often we hear the Robson rotation mentioned in a derisory way with the implication that it is somehow a crazy system which complicates matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I will admit it sounds an attractive phrase to use if we are trying to confuse people. The Robson rotation system sounds as if we are going to turn everything on its head. It fact, it simply means that the names of the candidates are rotated on the ballot-paper. The effect is that the party machinery-the party apparatchiks, the faceless people-do not determine who gets into parliament; the electors do. That is an immensely powerful tool. It is a wonderful adaptation of the electoral system so that the power is returned to the people. Rather than ridiculing and trying to nullify the sophistication of such a system, the Government would be well advised to put that criticism away and to endorse the Robson rotation system as a very good thing for the electorate to be able to use.

Since the introduction of that system in Tasmania, the power of the faceless decision makers of party machinery has been reduced greatly. The people who vote have taken the trouble and the time to learn about the candidates so that they can choose whom they select as No. 1. The donkey vote which can be derided, and is worthy of derision, no longer applies in Tasmania. It does apply where the Robson rotation system is not used.

Senator McMullan spent some time extolling the virtues of single member electorates and suggested that, because the rest of mainland Australia understands SMEs, that was the only way to go. Of course, Tasmania has single member electorates for the House of Representatives seats but wisely, in the election under its own jurisdiction, Tasmania uses the Hare-Clark, complete with Robson rotation. Like the rest of Australia, Tasmania uses a style of proportional representation (PR) for the Senate. Senator McMullan should recognise that all of Australia is familiar with the Senate PR system and that should not require a great deal of education and explanation.

The SMEs can easily be demonstrated as being entirely undemocratic in the way in which they operate. It is an easy demonstration to point out that this system of which Senator McMullan is so enamoured effectively disfranchises more than 1.1 million Australians in the House of Representatives election. They are the people who vote No. 1 for the Australian Democrats in the lower House election. Those 1.1 million people-the number is actually in excess of that-remain unrepresented by our Party in the lower House. In that place more than 700,000 people voted for the National Party of Australia and they are represented by a considerable number of National Party representatives.

There is a great inequity in that and it has been brought about entirely by the existence of single member electorates. It is not to do with the total number of people who voted for one particular political philosophy; it is to do with the electoral system that has delivered that inequity to the lower House. However, in the Senate the more than one million Democrat voters are represented by about the right proportion of senators who hold seats on their behalf. That is proportional representation. That is true and fair democracy.

On reading briefly the debate which took place in the other place on this matter, I was not enlightened greatly by the contributions of those honourable members who took part in that debate. I think the debate fell short of recognising that what this Bill was doing was complicating essentially what could be a simple issue.

We were reminded by Mr Simmons in his contribution that this Parliament has a constitutional responsibility to ensure the good and stable government of this nation's capital. In response to that statement, I ask why the electors of this nation's capital are being subjected to at least two, probably three and perhaps even four different electoral systems in as many elections. If that is good and stable government, I think the Federal Government should be looking closely at its definitions of good and stable government and listening more to the definitions which the electorate of the ACT would provide to it.

The contributions that I read on this subject also included those from the Opposition. Some mention was made of the amount of time that was being devoted to or allowed for the debate. There was criticism of the fact that the Government sat on the matter for some 18 months and then seemed to rush it through into the lower House without much preamble. It was said that that demonstrated the kind of contempt the Labor Party had for that chamber when it came to seriously debating some of the proposals put forward.

I do not agree with that. I think it reflects the inability of the Government to negotiate seriously a position which would be shared by all parties on this matter. There was a great deal of uncertainty on behalf of the Government for some 18 months before this position was brought about, and perhaps it reflects an exasperation, a frustration, at being unable to come up with an agreed position. But, rhetoric aside, I think that that exasperation was caused just as much by the Government's commitment to, and belief in, single member electorates rather than the intransigence of either the coalition or the Democrats. I have a problem with some of the contributions from speakers on the Government side in the lower House debate. A Government member said:

This Bill may not be ideal, but it is the system that the Government had thought that the Opposition was going to agree to and that, therefore, had a reasonable chance of being passed by the Senate. The Opposition has now gone back on that agreement, but the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill, although it keeps in place a form of the d'Hondt system, involves a considerable improvement, a simplification of the d'Hondt system, and therefore is a Bill that I support.

In other words, the honourable member thought the Opposition might support the Bill so it was worth trying: it was not really the best thing that could happen but it was worth putting up. That is the sort of attitude that leads to us not knowing where we are going. It leads to great uncertainties and to the need to send the Bill off to a committee. There is the potential for huge waste with that sort of confused uncertainty on the Government side. If that is the best that the Government can offer, that sort of meandering and wishy-washy stuff, no wonder we are faced with such a waste and no wonder the ACT electorate is disappointed and disgusted with the efforts that this Government is making on its behalf.

I conclude by repeating what I said before. There is no demonstrable need to go through this concoction, this contrivance. It could have been resolved quite simply by having a referendum as soon as possible. It is still possible to have that referendum, and I contend that the expense of that referendum would be almost matched by the inordinate expense of drafting an electoral system which will become redundant the day after it is first used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991 seeks to amend a Bill that was passed by this Parliament which became known as the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988. This came about at the same time as the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, which conferred upon the Australian Capital Territory the opportunity and responsibility of governing itself in many areas, but the electoral system was one which was determined, as was totally appropriate, by this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues which is relevant to the debate that is taking place now is: at what point is it appropriate for this Parliament to pass to the people of the ACT the responsibility for their own electoral system? It seems strange indeed that at this stage, as Senator Bell has mentioned, we are fiddling with the system for the next election and saying that the responsibility will pass to the ACT after the next election. It has not been clearly explained, to my satisfaction, why the responsibility would not have been passed to the ACT between 1988 and 15 February 1992, when the election will be held; it could have had the responsibility then. We can only conjecture why the Australian Labor Party took the view that it wanted to have another go under this system, or a slightly modified system, and then hand the responsibility over to the ACT.

I want to look through some of the things that have occurred on the way through. The first ACT election was held on 4 March 1989. It is well-known that it took about nine weeks to count the votes and that the declaration of the polls occurred on 8 May 1989. It was very clear during that election campaign that many Canberra residents did not want self-government. The outcome of the vote was as the people of the ACT wanted it to be. They voted for parties known as No Self-Government and Abolish Self-Government. Of course, as a consequence, representatives of those parties were elected. Of the 17 candidates elected, there were four from the Liberal Party, five from the Labor Party, four from the Residents Rally, three from the No-Self Government Party and one from the Abolish Self-Government Party. There were 117 candidates.

People tend to think that it was because of the number of candidates that it took so long to count the votes. There can be no doubt that that was the case. But when we think of the number of countries where people will kill each other for the right to have a say, we ought not to decry the fact that there were a number of people who wanted to be a part of it. I felt it was quite understandable that for the first election there would indeed be a large number of candidates. There were 108 candidates representing parties and nine independents.

Some of those who put their names forward as parties were, I think, attempting to ridicule the system. That is my interpretation of it in any event. There was the Party! Party! Party!, the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party and the Surprise Party. I think that was a pity because it seemed to me that it was a consequence of the huge ballot-paper-it was about a metre wide, with 139 boxes-and those aspects tended to dominate the coverage.

There was some confusion about the system of voting, although I am not quite certain why that was the case because it seemed to be fairly widely discovered. One of the results was that the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats distributed how-to-vote cards which were, in fact, at odds with the electoral legislation. So it has to be accepted that there was some confusion about the voting system. There was a higher proportion of informal votes than is normally the case in a Senate election, which normally has about a 2.95 per cent level of informality. The proportion of informal votes in the ACT election was 5.69 per cent.

There were complicated rules for formality and for deeming preferences. For example, votes were deemed formal if preferences after the first number followed any ascending unrepeated series of numbers. That is meant to be simpler, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think most voters would have understood it better if they had followed the normal system of numbering consecutively for the vote to be formal. Eighty to 90 per cent of voters in the ACT used the ticking of the box system and in the ACT 60 per cent of ballot-papers followed what was termed `no consistent' pattern. That is not surprising when one considers that there were 117 candidates.

The scrutiny under the modified d'Hondt system, as it was called, required eight stages and ballot papers had to be sorted into an astonishing 209 categories, whereas for a Senate vote only 140 categories would have been required for the same number of ballot papers-still a large number of movements of ballot papers in any event. There was an inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory election by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and it is worth looking at some of the things that the Committee concluded. It said that, because of the way the Australian Capital Territory electoral system had evolved, the outcome was:
. . . an unacceptable system which has brought the never popular self-government concept into further disrepute in the Australian Capital Territory.
The report went on to note that:
. . . the current system was considered unacceptable in its present form by all witnesses who expressed an opinion-
although, as the Chairman commented:
. . . the first twelve witnesses proposed twelve different electoral systems to replace modified D'Hondt.
It sounds like a meeting of accountants and economists. The Committee went through the matter fairly thoroughly. It claimed that:

. . . because of the difficulties associated with the first Australian Capital Territory election, namely the size of the ballot paper, the length of the count and the near impossibility of understanding how to cast an effective vote, the Committee was unable to come up with changes to the modified D'Hondt system which would be considered acceptable.

It is clear from studying the report and other data about electoral systems that there is no such thing as a perfect electoral system. The Committee considered the merits of various different proposals, but was influenced, it seems, by the expressed concern of the Australian Electoral Commission about the undesirability of `an excessive proliferation' of electoral systems in Australia. The report concluded that the choice should be between the familiar alternatives of single member electorates or a Hare-Clark system of proportional representation with multi-member electorates. It said:

The Committee is however unable to recommend either system as one that would at present be likely to secure passage through both Houses of Parliament. For that reason it recommends that the choice be put to the Australian Capital Territory electorate in a referendum.
It has taken the Government a long time to come to the view that a referendum is the appropriate way of dealing with it.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) earlier in this debate said that the D'Hondt system was not a bad electoral system. I agree with him, but I also recognise that the system has been so criticised in the Australian Capital Territory that it is almost impossible for the good within that system as a proportional representation system to be sold. I would prefer it to the Hare-Clark system, but it would take a brave person to embark on the course of persuading the people of the Australian Capital Territory that that was the case. It looks as though we are moving in another direction.

We must recognise that, while the Government says that it is coming here with an amendment to the 1988 Bill with a view to simplifying things, it is taking away from Australian Capital Territory voters some of the value of the vote that they had in 1988. If the Government's view were to prevail, their vote in 1992 would be less valuable than it was. The Government is now saying that voters can only vote horizontally within the list they start with; whereas in 1989 when we voted one could put one's number one vote where one pleased and then proceed with the rest of the value of the vote across the ballot paper among the candidates who were standing in the order that one chose. The reality of what we are looking at today is a reduction in the value of the vote that we had previously. It is not a refinement to make the vote more valuable or anything of that kind; it restricts a voter who votes Labor to sticking with Labor, and clearly that is what the Government prefers.

Senator McMullan in his speech criticised widely those who wanted systems other than that which he preferred. He seemed to be attacking everybody in general who did not agree with him, and the Australian Democrats in particular, I thought, suggesting that everybody else only wanted the electoral system that best suited him or her. I invite Senator McMullan to contemplate that he is doing precisely the same thing in that he wants his voters to stick strictly to the system that he is presenting, that is, to vote one for Labor and stick with it. He, too, if anyone else is, is presenting an electoral system which best suits the Australian Labor Party. The one Labor most prefers, as we know, is the single member electorate. Obviously now the Labor Party, after a very long time of not wanting a referendum, has decided that a referendum may well deliver it single member electorates so that it can find the money and the time to have a go at it. Talking of the timing, I point out that to hold the referendum at the same time as the election is totally inappropriate. If there was going to be a referendum it should have been held long before this so that 15 February could be devoted to electing members on the relevant issues of governing the Australian Capital Territory.

It is now put to the Senate that that is very difficult and that it could not be done before then because it would be very costly. It would cost more, but honourable senators in this place have been aware for months and years of the extravagances of this Government. The Government can find money for any cause it really wants to find it for. The number of examples could take up the rest of the morning. Kodak is one name to mention as sufficient to indicate how this Government will find money for the causes it wants to pursue when it wants to do so, but not in this instance because it does not suit the Government. That is all right, as long as those opposite do not come in here moralising about what they are trying to do and how everybody else is behaving. Let us be quite honest about what is going on.

Let us look at this amendment Bill of 1991. It provides for a revised system to elect the Legislative Assembly. It is the pure d'Hondt system, or as near to that as I can interpret pure d'Hondt to be, whereas in 1988 the system that was put in place gave more value to a vote than would be the case under the proposed system. We do not want the same sort of delays that occurred in the 1989 election, and I do not believe that they would be the same. In any event, the consequence of delay is not the same in that there is a government and a Chief Minister in place. When the election is held on 15 February, 1992 the new government will take its place at some time after that when the poll is declared, but in the meantime there is a government that will stay in place and stay in charge. That was not the case in 1989, when no government could be formed until such time as the poll had been declared.

The Opposition supports a system of preferential proportional representation to enable the electors of the Australian Capital Territory to have as wide as possible an opportunity to express their preferences within the party of their choice or across party lines. It has been said that single member electorates is the form of election most commonly used in this country, and that is the case. But, apart from Queensland, in the other instances there are two chambers to the parliaments, which I think makes a considerable difference. It is the case in this Parliament that there are single member electorates in regard to one place, proportional representation in another. We are talking about an electoral system for a parliament which has only one chamber. If, as has been widely said to be the case, Labor would get 16 out of 17 seats with single member electorates in Canberra, that can hardly be said to be a system which gives a fair representation of the views of the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

We know pretty well how they vote. Luckily, one-third plus a bit usually vote for the Liberal Party of Australia in Senate elections; 40 per cent or so vote for the Australian Labor Party and, of course, there are others whose first preference candidate is not elected to the Senate. However, it indicates that the ACT community is not one that clearly divides itself into two camps when it comes to voting. Therefore, with that knowledge, proportional representation for a single chamber is the fairest way of ensuring that the electorate will have an opportunity to express its view.

There are other amendments which are being put forward to raise the deposit $100 to $250, which is the same as that for the Senate. That seems a sensible and reasonable amendment to the 1988 Bill and all political parties, other than the parliamentary parties, will be required to demonstrate a minimum membership of 100 eligible ACT electors. That arises from the names of some of the parties which I read out earlier, which were registered as parties in 1988. It may be said that that is taking a heavy handed approach to minority groups. I cannot accept that because a group which is able to form a party with 100 members will be able to run candidates and express its view. However, I do not think that I have to take seriously as a contender for governing the people of the ACT a party that seeks to register itself as `Party! Party! Party!'.

In addition, individuals will be prevented from being the registered officer of more than one party. My comprehension of belonging to a political party is such that I cannot see that restriction as being regarded as a hardship. I cannot imagine how one could possibly be committed to two separate philosophies and be the registered officer of two separate parties in any event. So I am happy to support that. However, the coalition does not support the proposal to restrict preferences to a party list, and I have dealt with that sufficiently.

When the Bill was debated in another place it was said that the Government was sending the message to voters that to vote for an independent candidate or minority party would be a wasted vote. I have also said sufficient on the issue of the value of the vote to indicate that I do not regard that attitude to a vote as being an appropriate one. It is cynical when one thinks that at the last election 60 per cent of the voters opted to depart from the party line and voted as they saw fit across the ballot-paper. Although with the size of the ballot-paper those who embarked upon it faced quite a task.

The voters in the ACT are an educated and informed group. They have shown repeatedly how they wish to vote selectively amongst all candidates who put themselves forward. Our proposals are aimed at ensuring that voters have the freedom to direct their preferences as they choose.

I want to refer also to the matter that Senator Bell raised, of sending this Bill to a committee. I do not understand his criticism of that action. I certainly do not interpret the Bill going to a committee in the way that he does. At the end of the second reading debate, the Bill will go to the appropriate committee, pursuant to the selection of Bills procedures that we are presently operating under. The amendments will be dealt with there in what is, I hope, becoming the normal way. I personally feel that the selection of Bills process that we are trialling at present is working extremely well and is assisting enormously with dealing with legislation and the opportunities that people have to look at the details of Bills. I see it as a necessary step with this Bill. We have to be sure that we get it right. We have to be sure that the amendments being made to the 1988 Bill are absolutely correct and as they should be. So I have to totally dissociate myself from the approach that Senator Bell took to that.

I do not agree with him either when he said that the question of the electoral system should not be a matter for this chamber to decide. The electoral system is still the responsibility of the Federal Parliament and until we hand that over to the ACT Government, that remains the case. It is not a matter that can be determined by any outside groups or by anyone else but us. It may be very fair criticism to say that is should have been handed over to the people of the ACT before now, but that is not the case and we have the responsibility for the system for the election on 15 February 1992. When referring to that, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) in his speech in the other place indicated that it would be handed over after that election. It has not been satisfactorily explained why it could not be handed over before. The ACT Liberal Party and the Legislative Assembly itself support the repatriation of the legislative system to allow the Assembly to design its own electoral system. We think that should have been done before 1992. I can only conclude that it is a cynical approach of the Labor Party to try to use the modification to this electoral system to its advantage in the hope that it will be in charge of putting in a new electoral system after 1992.

However, since this debate was held in another place and the Bill was passed, the Government has announced that a referendum will be held. I welcome the statement by Senator McMullan this morning that the other parties and interested groups will be consulted about the form of the referendum and that if a document is presented to the electorate it will follow the normal practice of including a sample of the ballot-paper et cetera. That announcement was a welcome beginning to the debate after the somewhat flippant way that Senator McMullan dealt with the questions that were raised last night on the referendum. He asked: what sort of a Hare-Clark system; what is the Hare-Clark system? He quoted various views of what it should be, whether it would be the Buchanan model et cetera.

So at least the adjournment of the debate from last night until this morning was valuable in one respect, but some of these questions remain and need to be answered. If they are not answered properly in a way that the electorate understands, the Government may well be accused of setting up a referendum where the answer to it is almost determined by the way it is presented.

How will the questions be framed? It is clear that only Hare-Clark will be included and not d'Hondt as well, even though it was suggested today that that was not a bad system. It perhaps has to be left out, but not even that has been explained adequately. How much will be spent on advertising the case to the electorate? Will it include the Robson rotation system? That matter has been mentioned today and it was mentioned by Senator Bell. A couple of weeks ago I heard Senator Aulich talk about the Robson rotation and the Hare-Clark system on local radio. He claimed to have been the person who introduced the Robson rotation system in Tasmania and he certainly advocated it most strongly. However, he conceded that it introduces some instability in that Ministers are always at risk within the electorate because they are so busy looking after their portfolio responsibilities that they do not have the same time for electorate work as other members do, which means that they are more vulnerable during an election under the Robson rotation system. That is obviously something that Senator Aulich rejects as a serious disadvantage, but it is an aspect of the system that needs to be considered carefully because one thing we do need is stability in government. If that is a serious matter of instability one has to consider carefully whether it should be advocated.

When will we see the documentation about the referendum? When will be know what is happening? When will we know how many electorates will be the basis of the Hare-Clark proposal, and how many will be in each of the electorates? Yesterday Senator McMullan said that time was moving on and that we are getting very near to the election, and that is absolutely right.

It is not long from now until 15 February and, as he said, the election is rapidly approaching and the referendum too is rapidly approaching. In that case, I say to the Government that it has a very clear responsibility to see that the matter that will be put to the people by way of referendum is known very soon and that it will be clear to the people what is being asked of them.

The Government may well consider a ballot-paper which rotated the questions so that not everybody in the electorate received an identical ballot-paper, and so eliminate any preference. But which of the two would be put on top? Is it drawn out of a hat? How is a decision made on which of the two questions is on the top of the ballot-paper? Maybe they should be rotated so that when a voter gets the ballot-paper randomly he or she cannot be certain which way the questions will appear on it.

There are a lot of things outstanding and it is a pity that so much time has been lost already. We do not agree with the approach the Government is taking to the amendment to the original Bill in this amendment Bill. As has been clearly stated, our position is clear. We believe the people of the ACT should be able to use their vote to the maximum extent of its validity and express their preferences across the ballot-paper so that that is the outcome for each vote which is cast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill because I do have some personal knowledge and interest in the Hare-Clark electoral system, which appears to be the system favoured by both the Australian Democrats and the Liberal Party of Australia on this occasion. But before I make some comments about the Hare-Clark voting system and the issues that I believe should be examined by those who are proposing it on this occasion, I have to say that, as I am speaking in this debate for the Government, I reject the accusation that we are acting out of self-interest in supporting the single member electoral system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government does not act out of self-interest. We act in the best interests of the country and the nation. There is clear evidence that our decisions have been based on fact and have been taken in the best interests of the running of the country. It is very clear that at both the State and Federal level the vast majority of elections are conducted under a single member electoral system.

In Tasmania, it may well be that we got it around the wrong way in the sense that we have a proportional representation system known as the Hare-Clark system for elections to our lower House, but we do have single member electorates for our upper House. I suppose that, if we were proposing single member electorates on the basis of self-interest, we would need to be a little cautious. In Tasmania, with the single member electorates in our upper House, and because Tasmania, like the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), is so small and has a very small voting population, rather interestingly there has not been dominance by large political parties. In fact, it has produced a dominance by Independents. In the Tasmanian upper House, out of 19 members, there are only two members of political parties-one Liberal and one Labor. The rest are Independents. So it certainly cannot be said that we are supporting single member electorates on this occasion out of self-interest, and I reject that charge.

Turning to the Hare-Clark voting system-I have been involved in many State elections in Tasmania both as a campaign manager of some of our candidates, as a scrutineer on behalf of the party and also on my only one try-a failed attempt-to be elected to our State parliament. So I have some personal knowledge of the way in which the Hare-Clark voting system operates and can highlight some aspects that those opposite should very carefully examine before they embrace the system, as they appear to be doing.

The comment has been made that the Hare-Clark system is a very fair system and that it is as near close to perfect as one can get in terms of the outcome. That is necessarily so. If the Liberal Party in Tasmania were asked today what it thinks of the result of the last State election as a consequence of the Hare-Clark system, I think it would be very critical of the outcome. I well remember, when the Labor Government, I think in 1972, lost office to a combined Liberal Party-Independent coalition, the Labor Party had won a majority of the votes and yet ended up not being in government. So, it is not correct to say that the Hare-Clark system is perfect in that it reflects the will of the people.

In any Hare-Clark system with a number of seats-two, three, four or whatever is adopted if it should be the preferred option of people in the ACT-it is very easy to obtain the majority of members in a particular electorate but it becomes very difficult to go beyond that. If the vote is concentrated it is quite possible, as has occurred in Tasmania, for the party receiving the majority of the vote not to end up being the Government. So, it is not necessarily correct to say that the Hare-Clark system will mean that the party with 50 per cent of the vote plus one will be in government.

A lot has been said in this debate about the so-called Robson amendment. The Robson amendment was introduced by Robson, who was a Liberal member of our State parliament. In Tasmania until that time, the names of the candidates in our elections appeared in alphabetical order. It is certainly true that this did result in some fairly quaint outcomes.

I can recall on one occasion when our former Premier, Doug Lowe, received a massive vote which was, I think, the highest personal vote on record of any candidate in a State election. As the then Premier he received well over 50 per cent of the vote and four quotas. But, underneath him because of the way in which the names were allocated on the list, there was a candidate who received between 200 and 300 votes and many other candidates received far more than 200 or 300 votes. But because the name of this candidate was under the name of the Premier, who had received some four quotas, he was elected on the basis of the donkey vote. A significant proportion of electors, regrettably, voted for our Premier and then continued on down the list which resulted in a candidate with only a few hundred votes being elected. This very clearly was not the result of persons making a selective choice but was the result of the so-called donkey vote.

As a result of that, Robson, who was a member of the Liberal Party, introduced-as a private member's Bill which was subsequently adopted by the Government-the concept of the rotating ballot. It is not a perfect rotation and I think those opposite should be aware of that. The names are rotated but they are still kept in an order. They are not randomly selected so that every ballot-paper is totally different. So that point needs to be made about it.

Also, in the subsequent election, it does cause some confusion when one goes to vote. As we know, it is quite traditional for families to go in, collect their ballot-papers together and talk about how they are going to vote. It does cause some confusion when people end up with different ballot-papers which have names in different orders. I am sure that that had something to do with the fact that the informal vote increased at the subsequent election using the rotational ballot-paper.

Another aspect that those opposite might like to consider, if they are in favour of Hare-Clark system, is whether or not how-to-vote cards will be allowed to be handed out. In Tasmania it is not permissible to hand out how-to-vote cards or to engage in any form of political propaganda within 200 metres of a polling booth, which does make it somewhat difficult to hand out how-to-vote cards. That is another aspect of the electoral system in Tasmania which those opposite might like to consider.

Another aspect which has not been mentioned, and which is very important, is the issue of a countback. It is certainly true that the Hare-Clark system does result in a very close reflection, in terms of parliamentary representation, of party support. All elections in Tasmania are inevitably close in terms of the number of seats. It did not occur in the last State election, but in the previous two State elections the Liberal Party very clearly had the majority of votes-I think between 53 and 55 per cent of the primary vote. It was very clear that it was the party of first preference of the majority of Tasmanians, but it did not have the major parliamentary majority. It did not enjoy-as one does under a single member electoral system-a majority of landslide proportions. That is an inevitable outcome of the Hare-Clark system and many people would argue that it is a desirable outcome because it reflects the will of the people.

However, it does have one drawback in that if there are-as there will be under the Hare-Clark system-very close results in an election, it will have to be decided whether in fact by-elections will be allowed under the system or whether there will be countbacks, as we have in Tasmania. If there is a close result under the Hare-Clark system and there is clear evidence that that will be the case, inevitably every time there is a by-election, if that is the system that is adopted, it is likely that the whole future of the Government will be determined at that by-election.

Some people might argue that that is a good thing; but, on average, at least once a year-as occurs in the Tasmanian system-we have a countback because a member retires. Some people would argue that it is desirable that we have by-elections in order to obtain the latest views of people's thinking. However, the fact is that the by-election will inevitably turn into a general election. So there can be a certain amount of instability if the by-election method is used to fill vacancies. I certainly urge those opposite to think very closely about that system.

With regard to the countback method, a lot has been made of the freedom to select candidates right across the party groupings and that this is what voters do in Tasmania. I certainly refute that. In Tasmania, where we normally run seven or eight candidates, it is the better known candidates-who tend to be existing members of parliament-who do very well. Two or three candidates tend to make up the list, because it is simply not possible for any party to elect six or seven of its candidates. These two or three candidates-if you like, the second grade candidates from an electoral point of view-who usually do not obtain more than a few votes, because of the countback system, can quite often be elected to Parliament.

I recall that the Labor Party was faced with some minor embarrassment because we had a number of resignations and we were facing the prospect of running out of Labor candidates under the countback system. We got down to our last candidate who had received only 200-odd votes. Unfortunately, he had been expelled from the Labor Party, and we had to re-admit him pretty quickly. I have to say that that was the cause of some embarrassment on that occasion. But I question whether, when we get down to the last three or four candidates, we are really reflecting the will of the people in that sense; given that, on many occasions, they receive only a handful of votes.

I believe it is highly improbable that the majority of Tasmanian electors obtain all of the information on all of the candidates for whom they have to vote and that they actually sit down and select their seven candidates, or more if they so wish. I believe they vote for the candidates whom they know and, obviously, whom they believe will represent them the best. They then fill out the remainder of the ticket: they might do this at random or they might donkey vote. I do not accept when people vote under the Hare-Clark system that they are necessarily electing candidates with knowledge of all the options they have.

One of the great problems with the Hare-Clark system is that members do not have an electorate of their own; there are seven members representing the electors. Quite often, that causes some difficulties in that the members who are elected to parliament-the parliamentarians-then have to serve an electorate that is, in the Tasmanian sense, often widespread geographically. This leads to candidates concentrating on particular parts of the electorate; they do not represent the whole electorate. In a political sense, some candidates tend to select small parts of the electorate that they are `representing', and they quite often tend not to go into other areas of the electorate. So there is a situation where Labor candidates tend to concentrate on areas which are known for their strong support for the Labor Party and vice versa: Liberal members concentrate on those areas where the Liberal vote is highest. I do not necessarily believe that is a desirable practice.

In concluding my contribution to this debate, I believe it is appropriate that the ACT should adopt the single member electoral system. I do not believe that we are advocating this for any selfish reasons. We are advocating it because that is the system which is understood most by the vast majority of the people-not just in the ACT, but all over this country. If we had our time over again in Tasmania, I believe we would have single member electorates. However, we have a Hare-Clark system and there is certainly no need, and certainly no practical advantage, in attempting to reverse what is now fact.

For the reasons I have outlined, I certainly urge those opposite to examine very carefully the ground that they are covering and the various aspects of the Hare-Clark voting system. It is not a panacea; it is not the total solution. If honourable senators opposite are not careful, they may end up with the sorts of undesirable results-as it appears from the attitude of the people in the ACT-that eventuated as a result of the now discredited d'Hondt system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's view with regard to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991 has, as usual, been carefully and skilfully put by Senator Parer and Senator Reid and I do not wish to repeat what my colleagues have said in relation to the substantive parts of the Bill. However, I rise very briefly to draw the Senate's attention to the report of the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills about this particular Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues upon which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is called to report is whether any Bills, by express words or otherwise, trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. That is, of course, a mainstream of our democratic heritage; it is something which we must protect at all costs, at all times. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee exists to look at every piece of legislation which comes into this chamber, to see whether that legislation trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties. It also scrutinises the legislation for other reasons relating to the same matters.

The right to vote is of course a fundamental right and involves an individual being able to ascertain very readily whether they have an entitlement to vote. In this particular piece of legislation it becomes very confusing for the ordinary person, who does not have legal training, to work out just what this legislation will mean, whether they will be entitled to vote and how in fact the legislation will operate.

I say the average person would find difficulty: I might also say that even those with legal training-and some with quite skilled legal training-find an enormous difficulty in following through this particular piece of legislation.

The Bill proposes to amend the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988. It contains in a schedule a series of modifications to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 in order to apply a large part of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to elections in the Australian Capital Territory, subject to changes effected by the schedule.

The legislation before us contains four schedules in all-three new ones. Schedule 1 proposes to amend the modifications which were made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act by the schedule to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act; schedule 2 proposes to substitute some modifications which were made by the schedule with other modifications; and schedule 3 proposes to repeal some other modifications.

That all sounds rather confusing, and it is. It makes it very confusing for anyone who is attempting to find out just what this legislation is all about. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee indicated that it was of the view that a person wishing to look up the electoral law that applies to the Australian Capital Territory would be left with a very confusing task. A person would have to refer to three separate pieces of legislation, including cross-referencing four different schedules, in order to establish what the electoral law is.

This is a very important piece of legislation for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. It is my view, and it is the view of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, that it would have been far better for the Government simply to rewrite the legislation containing the same form, but in one freestanding piece of legislation, so that if people wanted to know what their rights were they could pick up a separate piece of legislation, read it then and there and see what rights and entitlements they had.

The Government, for some reason, has chosen not to do that. Why it has not done that mystifies me. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee wrote to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) suggesting that it be rewritten in a single piece of legislation. The Minister responded as follows:

The decision not to introduce a free standing Australian Capital Territory electoral bill at this time is consequent upon the fact that the Principal Act, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, contains a schedule modifying and applying the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to Australian Capital Territory elections.
The Minister went on to say:

I note for your information that early drafts of the Bill contained only one schedule amending Schedule 1 to the Principal Act. However officers within my department in consultation with officers from the Australian Electoral Commission were concerned that such an expression of the modifications to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was awkward. Accordingly, Parliamentary Counsel provided a revised draft of the Bill with four schedules each listing amendments of a consistent nature in order to enhance the intelligibility of the Bill.

That seems to be a rather curious comment. It misses the point that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was raising, and that is that one should not have to refer to three or four pieces of legislation to find out what this is all about.

I think it is critical that we, as citizens of this country, can find out what law applies to us and how we interpret it. I know there are a lot of things said at times about the high cost of obtaining justice and the high cost of getting advice from a lawyer. I can say, as a practising lawyer in the recent past, that a lot of the costs involved in giving legal advice are brought about by legislation such as this, where one has to sit down for an enormously long period of time just to sort out what the legislation is before one can then read it, interpret it and give advice on it.

Of course, as with any other job, in the law time is money and the longer one takes the more expensive things become. From that angle as well the Government should seriously look at putting this into a piece of freestanding legislation. There is a myriad of Acts around which have the same problem. It becomes an impossible task for anyone to try to advise on the taxation legislation with the continuous stream of amendments coming through. It just takes so long to find out where the Act should sit before one starts reading it to try to understand it and advise on it. That same problem applies to this Bill before us.

All too often, in our present day and age, the rights of citizens are being trammelled more and more. The Government's attempt to ban free speech with bans on electronic advertising is yet another step along that path towards restricting the freedoms that we used to have in this country. Those sorts of things should be opposed or drawn attention to at all times. That is why I rise on this occasion to bring to the notice of the Senate that this is very important legislation which relates to our fundamental right to vote, and is very important for people in the Australian Capital Territory, but if it was given to people in the street to find out what it was all about and how it affected them, it would be impossible for them, by reading this Bill-and the Act if it becomes law-to find out what their rights are.

I urge the Government to look at it again. The Government has a team of very well qualified and highly paid draftsmen who would find no difficulty in putting this into a freestanding Bill. I wonder why it does not do it. I urge the Minister to consider that and see if we can have a piece of legislation that we can all understand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991. I do so as a member of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters on whose report the Bill is largely based. I was not a member of the subcommittee which was primarily responsible for the detail of that report.
