I speak also as an unequivocal supporter of a system of single member electorates, which I will return to later.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I think we need to recapitulate on why we are here now and what has happened to bring us to the point where we are now suggesting that the next election in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) should be based on the d'Hondt system with some amendments, and a referendum to decide what the system will be in the future.

Leaving aside the long and convoluted movement towards self-government, and the arguments that went on in relation to that, once the decision had been made to give the ACT self-government, legislation on the electoral provisions was introduced in October 1988. The Bill was introduced against a backdrop of unsuccessful attempts to achieve, firstly, a single member electorate system which the Government at the time supported or, alternatively, and again unsuccessfully, a hybrid single member electorate system with a Senate-style proportional representation (PR) top-up-a single electorate which would top up the single member constituencies in much the same way as some European systems do.

As a result of a failure to gain support for either of these proposals the Government was forced to look further afield and came up with the d'Hondt system. The d'Hondt system, I believe-and a couple of speakers have already conceded this point-is probably unfairly the subject of abuse because of a number of other factors in this last election which have led to some almost comic opera situations for which d'Hondt is blamed.

It is a respectable system used in a number of European countries. For example, it is used in France, Germany, Finland, the Netherlands and Israel. It was seen by the Government-having failed, I remind the Senate, to gain acceptance for either a single member constituency system or a single member constituency system with a top-up from a Senate-style PR system-to be a unique system for a unique city State around which we might get support. It was acknowledged at the time that it was a compromise, and there were no bones made about the fact that that was so.

It also needs to be recognised that no electoral system is ideal. I think this was well summed up in the Committee's report where at page 38, paragraph 2.72, it quotes from Harrop and Miller, Elections and Voters: A Comparative Introduction:

To determine which of the available electoral systems is best for an electorate is a difficult task. No one electoral system is the best for all countries and in all contexts. A good electoral system can be defined as one that performs a range of tasks reasonably well in a specific context even at the expense of doing none of these tasks superbly well.
That is as much as saying that there is no ideal system. The Committee goes on to say in that same paragraph:
Conversely a bad electoral system is one which performs none of these tasks satisfactorily.
Earlier on in its report, the Committee tried to establish criteria for a good system. On page 16 at paragraph 2.5, it says that:
An electoral system should:
* result in the legislature that reflects the electorates' wishes;
* result in a government that reflects the majority opinion of the electorate;
* allow for stable government;
* ensure the election of members whose personal qualities best fit them for legislative responsibilities;
* be easily understood by the electorate;
* ensure a quick result.

The Committee, while making some recommendations for changes to the current modified d'Hondt system, also proposed a referendum. It did so because there were such heated arguments and entrenched views on the question of the voting system in the ACT and because it is a genuinely difficult thing to decide what is best for the ACT and, importantly, which system will ultimately have the confidence of the ACT electors. So that the referendum would be an understandable one and would not be bogged down in the complexities of the minutiae that are concerned with electoral systems, it proposed a simple choice between two alternatives, the single member electoral system or a Hare-Clark proportional representation system similar to that in Tasmania.

While the referendum was not on the agenda following the Government's initial response to the Committee report, following negotiations it is, as you are aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, now back on the agenda with the suggestion that it be held at the same time as the next ACT election. The Government's reasons for not initially including the referendum were nevertheless sound. The Government was concerned that the referendum at that time was unlikely to achieve a definitive outcome. It was concerned that there was no guarantee that the results of a referendum would be accepted by the parties concerned. It was concerned also that the referendum would serve to regenerate debate on the merits of self-government, which is a debate that we have had and which should be put aside. Of course, it was also concerned about the cost of a stand-alone referendum at a time of economic restraint.

The current proposal to hold the referendum with the election is a sensible compromise. It makes more sense, given that the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) also proposes with this Bill to hand over to the ACT the power to control the Territory electoral system from the time of the election onwards. It also overcomes the problem of costs for the stand-alone referendum, as the costs of holding the referendum with the election will be minimal.

I take this opportunity to put the case for the single member electorate system. I favour it because of its simplicity. People know who their local representative is; they can identify with him or her. They can identify with the system. It is a system that most people in Australia know and most people would opt for if given a choice. Polls have shown this.
The main objection seems to be that Labor will win a majority. This point is summed up, I think very well, by a letter to the Canberra Times on 5 October last year by Hugh Dakin:

The objection to single-member electorates for the ACT seems to be that it would result in a large Labor majority. This would occur only if a large majority voted Labor, in which case it seems a curious objection to our electoral system that it gives the result preferred by the majority.
He adds:
Incidentally, I am a member of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is wrong.

—I say to Senator Bell that the system would not guarantee a Labor majority. Seats of 8,000 or so are highly responsive to local factors, particularly in a city State the size and nature of Canberra with a highly literate and politically aware group of electors. Any well-known independent or minor party candidate could easily win in a seat that is regarded as a safe Labor seat. There are examples of this even in larger seats in State general elections all around the country. The plethora of independents that were elected in the last round of State elections attests to this. When local issues arise, when there is a notable local candidate or when people are fed up with major parties, minor party candidates and independents have every chance of getting up, even in larger electorates than were being proposed in the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: In another letter to the Canberra Times Senator McMullan summed up the situation particularly well when he was challenged to show a former correspondent with the Canberra Times one electorate in the last election which could have given a party other than Labor a better than even chance of winning. Senator McMullan said that he could do better than that and that he could show him:

. . . that on the 1989 results, a party other than the ALP would have had an even chance of winning 15 seats. Only two seats could have been considered to be safe Labor and even those relied on preferences from the Residents Rally.
He went on to give a hypothetical example:

We could look at a hypothetical ``city'' electorate including Reid, Braddon, Turner, Acton, Civic, Barton, Kingston, Yarralumla and part of Ainslie. On the 1989 results after distribution of the unsuccessful parties (based on the actual distribution) the Abolish Party had 6.3 per cent, Residents Rally 25.8 per cent, ALP 26.72 per cent, No Self Government party 11.4 per cent and the Liberal Party 21.2 per cent.

Assuming that the Abolish and No Self Government parties distribute relatively evenly or expire (as is probable given their registered tickets), then the Liberal preferences would give the Residents Rally . . . a comfortable win.
He says that this example could be repeated in several electorates, based on figures from the last election.

I am unashamedly a supporter of the party system, which has relevance in this debate. Any system in which parties exercise strong discipline over their members makes for more stable and decisive government. I think that this stability and decisiveness is necessary in developing the sorts of coalitions we need to make tough decisions in the national interest. This is infinitely better than a system similar to that in the United States, where parties have little discipline and where congressmen become populists responding to the parochial demands of local constituencies.

Classic examples of this in recent times in the United States are the fact that the Americans have not been able to cope with the deficit; the fact that they have never been able to cope with farm subsidies; and the fact that they have never been able to cope with drastic reductions in defence expenditure. That is because they have a group of members who are acting as local populists in their own constituencies without the protection of disciplined parties to give them the support that is needed in making difficult decisions in the interests of the nation as a whole.

By contrast, the Hare-Clark system is not the ideal held up by many. While I could go into this in detail, it has already been covered much better than I could by somebody with a lot more experience of it in Tasmania-Senator Sherry. Essentially it militates against parties-which is the strength of our system-in favour of undisciplined independents such as occurs in the United States. It is a system that is specifically designed for Houses of review, and has a number of other technical difficulties to which Senator Sherry has already referred.

There is also a need to recognise in relation to the comic opera nature of the ACT's first Legislative Assembly election-Senator Reid has already drawn attention to the fact that there were 117 candidates for 17 positions, that the ballot-paper was a metre wide, that we had parties such as the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party and the Party! Party! Party! and that it took 65 days to count the ballot-that these comic opera aspects and some of the aspects of the ensuing government, which have also been equally comical and best described in the 60 Minutes program of 7 October last year, are not totally a product of the electoral system. In fairness to d'Hondt, which has its faults, this is a product of any new electoral system. The modified version of d'Hondt that was introduced certainly has its faults, some of which will be picked up by the proposed amendments. I remind honourable senators that the first Federal Senate election attracted 50 candidates in New South Wales, whereas the second election in 1903 attracted only 12. Any first election will attract a range of candidates trying themselves out. There are some self-regulating elements in the second election and this pattern will apply in the ACT.

The Government does not have the support for a system of single member electorates. Instead, as a compromise, it has proposed, firstly, a series of amendments as suggested and broadly supported by the Joint Committee. As has already been mentioned, those amendments go to raising the candidate deposit to try to discourage frivolous candidates and making a requirement that, in order to register as a political party, a group must have 100 members who are eligible to vote, which again tries to deter the frivolous establishment of parties. It also has a provision that individuals are able to register only one party and it simplifies the formality provisions.

Secondly, there is a provision for a referendum to put to ACT electors a choice between single member electorates and the Hare-Clark system, as proposed by the Joint Committee. Thirdly, there is a decision to hand over to the ACT Assembly the power to control the Territory electoral system following the next election. In the circumstances, those are sensible compromises and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that I need to traverse all the ground covered by honourable senators in the course of the summing-up. I thank them for their contributions. We should all be thankful that, at the end of the day, the people of the ACT will decide by referendum which system they prefer.

SPEECH.PARA: However, a couple of responses to matters raised by senators might be appropriate. In response to the comments of Senator Macdonald in wanting to put the whole thing into one Bill, I point out that the form of drafting of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991, on which the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills commented, reflects the fact that the bulk of the mechanical provisions applying to the ACT elections are the same as those that apply at Commonwealth elections. The Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 accordingly applies the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 with a number of modifications, rather than just repeating slabs of text from the Commonwealth Electoral Act. This Bill makes a relatively limited number of changes to the modifications which appear in the ACT Act. The position of a person seeking to construe the Act is really no different from that of a person who seeks to read any Act which has been amended since its last consolidated reprint-and, as we all know, there are a few of those.

In respect of Senator Bell's comments in noting the position of the Australian Democrats regarding the proposed referendum being held as soon as possible and the preferred system then identified being utilised at the next ACT election during February 1992, I suggest that it is a matter of just being sensible about costs. Irrespective of whether he thinks it is a good idea, I would have thought that the great majority of people in the ACT would have thought that the stand-alone referendum, costing $600,000 more than holding one in conjunction with the 1992 election, would be just too much money. There is no justification for spending that $600,000 when it does not have to be spent. That is a position that the Australian Labor Party would share with the Opposition.

I note Senator Sherry's comments on the Hare-Clark system as a whole. I have always found it a somewhat mystical system and not one that I would urge upon any elector. If the Tasmanians have it, that is well and good; I would not seek to roll back Tasmanian history. But I note that it has made no advance in lower House elections anywhere else in the Commonwealth. I would have thought that that is a very good thing. It is not a system I would seek to inflict on anyone.

Senator McMullan and Senator Beahan have really outlined the Government's position far better than I could. I do not seek to add to their comments. I look forward to attending the Committee at which we might then iron out just what will occur from now on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No.1) 1991SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 April, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1991 and Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 to be debated cognately. Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1991 is actually part 3 of the luxury car tax saga in which the Government has decided at last that parts 1 and 2 were a huge blunder and are best forgotten. As a result, the luxury car industry now finds itself reverting to the tax arrangements which were in place before this saga began. Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 implements a Budget undertaking to amend the wholesale sales tax laws to give small businesses and other small sales taxpayers the option of lodging and paying tax on a quarterly as opposed to a monthly basis.

SPEECH.PARA: In making this and other changes to the wholesale sales tax, as announced in the March statement, the Government is admitting that the present system is inefficient and full of anomalies. However, it has not had the courage to bite the bullet and to scrap the wholesale sales tax and to replace it with a goods and services tax as proposed by the coalition.

The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.1) 1991 is the first in the cognate debate. As a result of the Government's March economic statement, we now have before us this amendment Bill which, as I said earlier, is part 3 of the Government's luxury car tax saga. This saga has been going on for almost 12 months. In May 1990 the Government put before the Senate the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1-9) to increase from 30 per cent to 50 per cent the rate of sales tax payable on motor cars and station wagons, including four-wheel drive vehicles, with a wholesale value exceeding $28,793.

The anticipated revenue gained from the increase was in excess of $100m per annum. It was anticipated to increase the total revenue raised from this source from $450m to over $550m per annum. Luxury car sales surged during the period between Mr Keating's sales tax announcement in February 1990-that was a election ploy I remind honourable senators-and its implementation in May. What a naive statement for a Treasurer to make! Sales during this period pulled forward and estimated $54m in duty and sales tax. Announcing sales tax increases in advance was a naive policy.

I remind the Senate that, when the sales tax amendments were debated in May, the coalition said that it did not believe that the increase in the luxury car sales tax would raise anywhere near the amount of revenue which was claimed by the Government. That is on the public record. The coalition also argued that it would have a negative impact on employment and on business viability. The Government went part of the way towards admitting that we were correct when it introduced the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) in 1991 in accordance with changes announced in the August Budget.

The overall effect of this second Bill was to reduce the rate of tax applicable to lower priced luxury motor vehicles by applying a progressively increasing rate commencing at 30 per cent. The amended tax system commenced at 30 per cent for vehicles priced at $30,234 and increased to a maximum of 50 per cent for vehicles with a wholesale price equal to or greater than $54,419. The Government's reason for changing its mind in August was that the luxury car sales tax changes had encouraged wholesalers to adopt a number of undesirable practices to artificially reduce wholesale prices below the threshold level, in some cases by removing safety options from the vehicles. I remind the Senate that these are almost the identical words that I used about six months earlier.

Many within the car industry had referred to the increased sales tax as a tax on safety, not only because it led to the practice of removing safety options from vehicles in order to bring down the price but also because it had prevented safety items on cars filtering down to the less expensive models for fear of pushing the price of the cars over the threshold and also making them uncompetitive. The Government also cited as a reason for the change the plight of primary producers and others living in remote parts of Australia. I remind the Senate that this point was very strongly made by my colleague from Western Australia Senator Panizza who, very emotionally at the time, pointed out the problems it would have for the outback. He is in the chamber today and no doubt will also remind the Senate of his prophetic words.

Obviously, in parts of Australia the terrain necessitates the use of four-wheel drive vehicles. The heat demands extra accessories, which in some areas might be deemed to be a luxury. The price of such vehicles places them in the luxury category, even though they are in this instance considered to be for day-to-day use rather than for luxury purposes. In other words, it shows just how out of touch Canberra can be with some of the remote parts of Australia.

There were two points that the Government did not admit to back in August. The first was the impact that the increased sales tax had on the sales of Australia's two home-grown vehicles which fell into the luxury car category. I refer to the Ford LTD and to the Caprice of General Motors-Holdens Ltd. Catching these Australian-made cars in the higher tax net and jeopardising their sales prospects was described by Mike Kable of the Australian as nothing short of absurd, particularly given the Government's commitment to the Buy Australia campaign.

The second fact the Government did not admit to was that the increase in the luxury car sales tax had resulted in a negative impact on revenue. It is disappointing that Senator Walsh is not here today because, had he been around, he would have applied some basic economic reasoning. There is the question of certain products that have elastic and inelastic demands, luxury vehicles vis-a-vis common purpose items.

We have had to wait until today, since the announcement of the Bill in the August Budget, for this admission of guilt, fault and rectitude. What the industry and the coalition have been trying to tell the Government for almost 12 months has finally hit home. We thus have the announcement in the March industry statement that the Government has decided to review the higher rate luxury sales tax and to revert to the pre-May 1990 arrangements. If Senator Button had anything to do with that, I thank him for his part in it, because at least it has seen a return to commonsense and rationality.

The Government, in announcing this change of heart, also conceded that since the introduction of the higher rate of luxury sales tax in May 1990 there has been a dramatic contraction of sales in this sector. Monthly sales are now running at less than a third of the level of the years before the tax change-surprise, surprise! This has had a serious consequence for the overall business of these motor vehicle importers and their level of employment and sales.

Vehicle importing is only part of the Australian operations of luxury car companies, such as Mercedes-Benz (Australia) Pty Ltd and JRA Ltd. These companies also have major bus and truck operations in Australia and are large employers of highly skilled labour, including many apprentices. The downturn in their car sales has put at risk these operations and their capacity to grow in Australia. That is indeed unfortunate. What a pity it was that the Government had not thought through the full implications of its tax arrangements before the initial announcement 12 months ago. If we put it in perspective, perhaps that is one of the costs of election promises that went very badly wrong.

The Bill currently before us cancels out the previous rulings of the 50 per cent or the graded 30 per cent to 50 per cent tax levels, and the car retail and importing industry now goes back to where it was less than 12 months ago, but in a far weaker state financially because of what has happened. We started with a tax change which was going to increase revenue from $100m to $550m per annum. We then had an alteration which was expected to diminish tax revenue by $8m to $10m in a full year. Thus revenue was reduced to approximately $540m.

The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) stated in his second reading speech that the reduction in the rate of sales tax on luxury vehicles will cost $15m in 1991 and $45m in 1991-92. I am uncertain from which total revenue base the Minister will deduct this latest reduction of sales tax; it seems that he is still looking at the total revenue of approximately $500m. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) may wish to give us a clarification in the summing up.

The last time that I had the pleasure, if it was a pleasure-I am not a vindictive person who is berating the Government on the sales tax issue-to speak in a debate such as this, honourable senators may recall, or have read in those speeches, I predicted a total revenue of only $280m for the year. Most car retail executives say that the market is now so depressed that their best hope-I emphasis `their best hope'-as a result of this Bill is for a levelling off of the sales decline rather than a widespread recovery. On this basis, my estimate of $280m, or 50 per cent of the Government's initial revenue of $550m, still stands.

I trust that the Government is highly embarrassed and shamefaced by this luxury car tax saga. At least this amendment Bill is a sign that there is still some belated hope-hope that the Government will recognise many of the other stupid decisions that it has made, and had the guts to acknowledge, and make some other appropriate changes. Regretfully, it seems that it is only those decisions which have a negative impact on government revenue that the Government bothers to admit to as erroneous and decides to amend. But what about all the other serious matters that have an impact on ordinary people and their lives?

I turn to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1991. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology completed a report entitled Small Business in Australia: Challenges, Problems and Opportunities. The report has been named the Beddall report, after the Minister for Small Business and Customs who was Chairman of the Committee. The Committee made some 60 recommendations which it believed would better the operating climate for small business. Several of these recommendations dealt with taxation matters.

The amendment Bill before us picks up one of those 60 recommendations; specifically, No. 28. The Committee recommended that the Australian Taxation Office reduce the remitting frequency of sales tax for qualifying small business-that is, small tax remitters-from a monthly to a quarterly basis, with a view to reducing compliance costs for their businesses. So far, so good.
The Bill will implement that recommendation, giving qualifying small businesses the option to remit sales tax on a quarterly or monthly basis, effective from 1 August 1991.

I add at this point that it is a pleasure to debate legislation prior to its operative date because this is indeed a rare occurrence in this place. I give the Government credit for that because the last time we debated this type of legislation we debated it subsequent to its introduction.

The Government has proposed in the Bill that the qualifying threshold will be $50,000 for 1991-92. For any subsequent year, the threshold for the previous year will be adjusted in line with movements in the consumer price index. I am yet to be convinced that the threshold of $50,000 adequately covers those traditionally placed in the small business category. The category to which I refer is the definition by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of small business-that is, a business with fewer than 20 employees in all sectors, other than in the manufacturing sector where the figure is 100 employees.

However, the fact that some relief to small business is to be achieved in terms of compliance costs is to be welcomed. It will be interesting to see whether the Government, having now legislated to enact recommendation 28 of the Beddall report, goes on to recommendation 29 which, for those who are not familiar with it, recommends that compensation in some form be provided to qualifying small businesses for the cost of sales tax collection and remittance to the Australian Taxation Office, possibly by providing a tax credit based on an agreed reasonable compliance time spent in dealing with the sales tax paperwork.

The Government accepted recommendation 28 and has rejected recommendation 29. There is still an opportunity for a recognition by this Government of some of the costs incurred in complying with its legislation. A Government Minister has put forward that recommendation; the Government has not accepted it.

The other advantage which I see arising from this Bill, despite its limitations of sticking with the wholesale sales tax and not doing away with it totally, is the assistance that it will give to new businesses. This is a point that I believe is worth taking up. If a company commences business on 1 July 1991 and has a sales tax liability of $120,000 for that financial year, which is in excess of the $50,000 threshold, it will nevertheless still be a quarterly remitter for the 1991-92 year, though not for future years. This should certainly assist with the cash flow in the first year of operation. I think these are the sorts of incentives that businesses need in order to get off the ground in the first place, because lack of cash is the main impediment to small business at the present time.

I now have two concerns arising from this Bill, Madam Acting Deputy President. The first is the fact that the Government continues to fiddle around with the wholesale sales tax system trying, through various pieces of legislation and announcements, to address the anomalies and inefficiencies which plague it. As I said in my introduction, the Government has not had the courage to bite the bullet and scrap the wholesale sales tax and replace it with a goods and services tax, a new system which has the backing of the business community around Australia and of the professional community as well.

The second concern is something that I alluded to earlier when I said that I have yet to be convinced that the sales tax threshold of $50,000 adequately covers those traditionally placed in a small business category. I can think of two other changes that the Government has made in recent times which it has billed as assisting small business but which fail to affect all that fall within this category as per the generally accepted definition of small business. The first of these changes is the company tax payment requirements, proposed initially to begin from 1 July 1990 but deferred by Government amendment to 1 July 1991 or substituted accounting periods.

From 1 July, companies with company tax bills in excess of $20,000 will no longer be able to pay that amount in four instalments over the year. Instead, they have two options: either to pay 85 per cent of the bill 28 days after the close of the financial year and the remaining 15 per cent nine months later, or to pay 100 per cent six months after the financial year's end. This $20,000 threshold is meant to exclude small businesses from this remittance requirement which will put a huge strain on cash flow, especially in the first year of its introduction. Small businesses which have a company tax bill of less than $20,000 are either tiny or certainly on the way out. Therefore, I do not believe such a threshold to be indicative of the level of company tax which a small business would be paying and it does not, therefore, exclude small business from the negative impact which this change imposes.

The second change that I refer to is the announcement by the Government that, from 1 July 1990, small group employers who pay less than $10,000 per year in quarterly tax instalment deductions will be able to remit pay as you earn (PAYE) tax on a quarterly rather than a monthly basis. Recommendation 42 of the Beddall report addresses this matter. The Beddall recommendation, however, was that group employers with an annual PAYE remittance of less than $100,000, not a mere $10,000, be allowed to remit PAYE tax on a quarterly rather than a monthly basis.

If this Government were really serious about improving the operating climate for small businesses, it would have used the Beddall recommendation figure of $100,000 as the threshold figure, and not one-tenth of that amount. Likewise, if the Government were really serious about small business, we would have had more than two or three recommendations from the Beddall report acted upon by now. The support from small business for the Australian Labor Party and this Government is virtually non-existent at this moment. That is not surprising. When one looks at the sales tax Bills before us today and goes into the detail behind these Bills, one is not surprised by this growing lack of support.

Some time ago I received a letter from a colleague which illustrates the burdens and obstacles in the way of small business. I am sure that this is but one of many examples with which members of this Senate are really quite familiar. I will give an abridged version to demonstrate what I have been saying:
. . . as a taxpayer who is attempting to do something in our country, I would like to inform you of my disillusion with the Government-Federal and State.

My current situation is (thus) following a trip to the United States I recognised a business opportunity for myself . . . The business concerned is setting up a chain of shoe shine stands in the lobbies of five star hotels; airports and even city executive buildings or arcades. With a Sydney based partner, I am in the process of forming a company `Shoe Shines Australia Pty Ltd' . . .

Since beginning to set up this company, I have found myself beset by government charges (State and Federal) which makes me wonder whether the Government is really committed to supporting those trying to provide job opportunities in this country. I give you the following examples:-
The first chair cost $2000 to be constructed. You add on the charges for registering a business name, (and) forming a company . . . and you get some idea (of) how I feel!

In order to construct our chairs we were forced to import, from USA, samples of the footrests that are an integral part of each chair. These are `cast' in a foundry-and samples are needed to make the mould. No such animal exists in this country. I find myself billed $43.24 (customs duty) and $67.08 (sales tax).
In order to provide an authentic shoe shine it will be necessary for me to bring in one of the polishes used in this area . . . I have been told that the customs duty on shoe polish is 5%.

The writer of the letter states that there will be an additional sales tax rip-off levied in addition to that. And these charges apply despite the fact that the goods are not manufactured in Australia-they are imported. I would like someone to justify to me why this person has been billed double what the cost of the polish would have been in the United States. He goes on to say:

I am only `small business'-attempting to fight `City Hall'-but my current thinking is that our country is apparently bankrupt and attempting to take a bit of any opportunity for raising dollars-with no thought to the potential long term gains of securing further employment opportunities for its citizens, if people like me are given a fair go.
This example outlines the range of taxes, including sales tax, which beset small business nowadays.

I think it is opportune to mention this at a time of a lot of government activity in terms of raising new revenue, a time of recession and a time of growing unemployment. Something must be done to assist small business to start employing people once again. I remind the Senate that this letter was written at a point of sheer frustration with the system, a point which many small business will have reached many, many times-perhaps one too many times and they have given up.

The Government is the party best placed at the present time to do something positive for small business. I think it has lost the opportunity that is available here today to provide some positive assistance. It has gone part of the way. But I think this is the story of this Government: its one step at a time is not bold enough and not big enough; it is too timid. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) amends one dire government induced situation. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) may give small business some hope but, again, like the industry statement, it is one of lost opportunity.

However, I do remind the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer that there is hope for more improvement. But I remind the Senate that it is up to the Government to get its act together and to have these potential improvements realised. Both Bills, despite their limitations, have the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: -I am afraid that on this occasion I cannot join my colleague Senator Watson in his eulogy of the Government's quite extraordinary decision to launch the Rolls Royce-led recovery, rather than making some carefully targeted interventions which Senator Button admitted yesterday could be appropriate. He gave us a whole list-the provision of additional finance for small business, advancing exports, providing additional assistance to research and development, and gearing up our education system.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we could also have expected this Government to take some measures to assist all those people who are now suffering from its engineered recession, including the wheat farmers that Senator Panizza represents who would benefit from a floor price and from cheaper vehicles. Four-wheel drive vehicles were mentioned. It would be a small matter to exempt from the increased sales tax on luxury cars such a class of vehicles used by primary producers. If Senator Panizza is interested, I am prepared to offer him my assistance in promoting such an amendment. But it is quite another matter to introduce measures which will reduce the price of Rolls Royces and BMWs, not to forget Ferraris. We believe that this quite extraordinary matter cannot be defended on the grounds of either social justice or economic rationalism.

Before I return to the mistaken motives behind the Government's decision, let me advert to some of the facts which constitute the background to this decision. A luxury car is one with a current retail price of $45,060 or more. It is the price above which the motor vehicle depreciation limit for income tax purposes is constituted. This line was established by the Fraser Government to limit the tax advantage available to business from the purchase of very expensive cars. So the road goes back to the days of the Fraser Government.

I have to give some credit to Mr Malcolm Fraser for recognising that people who can afford to buy cars for $100,000-plus should not do so at the expense of the taxpayers. The wholesale sales tax on all motor vehicles was 20 per cent until the 1986 Budget when a rate of 30 per cent was imposed on luxury passenger vehicles. That excluded utilities, panel vans, mini-buses and tray trucks. As I said before to Senator Panizza, it would be a simple matter to exclude four-wheel drive vehicles used by primary producers.

The luxury rate was then increased to 50 per cent on 8 May 1990. It was estimated that this tax would raise $105m in a full year. However, because of the vast increase in sales immediately before the rate increase and the sharp decline in economic activity since, a revenue shortfall has occurred, as Senator Watson has documented. The Government meanwhile had modified the all-or-nothing aspect of the 50 per cent rate by adopting a split rate system from the date of the 1990 Budget Speech. This has no great significance to the issue now before the Senate and I shall not pursue it any further.

The recent industry statements by the Treasurer and Senator Button announced that the luxury car tax will now be reduced to the pre-9 May 1990 rate of 30 per cent. The Prime Minister's statement made no mention of the proposed rate reduction. I wonder whether the Prime Minister was a little ashamed of that decision and did not want to associate himself with that announcement. In that context I advert to the statements-made quite frequently by Senator Maguire-that put the ALP's position on the detrimental effects of the consumption tax, and the examples, to which Senator Maguire quite often adverted, that it would put an extra tax on bread, milk and education materials but would make Rolls-Royces cheaper. Where is the social justice in the consumption tax, then, when we have a situation here that is completely analogous? It seems to me that with this measure, the Government has implemented a substantial chunk of the Opposition parties' consumption tax.

The new rate will apply from 13 March 1991, and there are a number of consequences arising from that. It is estimated by the Government in its statement that it will cost $15m of tax revenue in this financial year and $45m in a full year. It is unclear how these figures have been arrived at, but that is what the Government has put on the table.

In addition to that, there will obviously be a detrimental effect on the merchandise trade component of the current account. That is estimated, based on the Government's figures, at between $290m and $420m. Here we are trying to improve our balance of trade and trying to bring down our foreign debt, yet the Government institutes a measure which not only reduces tax revenue but also increases the unfavourable balance of trade of this country.

But let us look at another effect of this measure: that at least half of that amount will now be added to the unfavourable trade balance-because these cars will now be imported again in ever-increasing volume-and the buyers of these cars, faced with the higher tax and the higher price, may well have decided to buy instead Australian made vehicles; so why--

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are available.

—Well, Senator Panizza, all you have to do is look at the car yards in front of Ford, Toyota and Holden, and look at the cars that are being produced by Australian manufacturers with Australian workers which are available here through Australian distributors. There is absolutely no doubt that cars which get you from point A to point B are readily available in large numbers. Not only that: they are cars which it is acknowledged now are rivalling overseas products in the quality of the workmanship that has produced them, the engineering and the finish. We are doing a disservice by supporting a measure-as the Opposition does and the Democrats do not-which encourages people to buy cars which are manufactured offshore.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's rationale for this policy reversal is that the vehicle importers-people such as Daimler Benz and JRA-also have major bus and truck operations and motor vehicle component operations in Australia and are large employers of highly skilled labour, including many apprentices; and the Prime Minister and the industry Minister claim that these firms would cease these other operations, or alternatively not undertake further investment, or both, if they are curtailed in importing luxury vehicles. The Government appears to have taken that threat seriously.

I wonder to what extent we can place some value on these statements, on these threats, because I note, from recent media reports, that JRA is now selling its luxury car trading division. It will, of course, receive a much higher price for its operation now that the luxury car tax has been reduced. All that is happening is that JRA will achieve that higher price. So, where and how will it subsidise its other operations? Senator Panizza is asking why. Obviously, its profits will be larger, the volume of sales will be larger, it will sell more cars and, clearly, its operation is, therefore, in much better competitive shape. It is a fairly simple economic pricing argument: if you make a higher profit, you will get a higher price for your capital investment that produces that profit.

That is all that will happen in terms of JRA, which is one of the firms named by the Government that is using its luxury car division to cross-subsidise other activities. So now we are losing that. We shall not get that cross-subsidisation. But in any case, is the Government suggesting-and I understood it to suggest that cross-subsidisation is a bad economic principle-that we should rely on such cross-subsidisation? This example shows that we cannot; that cross-subsidisation of this type is an extremely uncertain and unreliable reason to allow people such as JRA to reduce the cost of the luxury cars which they are selling.
To give the Minister some guidance as to the media report: it appeared on 4 April 1991 in the Australian.

But there is another report that I would like to draw the Minister's attention to. It appeared in the Australian Financial Review in the business and investment section and it dealt with the Daimler-Benz Company, which is the other large distributor of luxury cars in Australia. That statement quotes Mr Bernt Schlickum of Daimler-Benz saying:
Future sourcing and export contracts will not be confined to the automotive industry.
The key to renewed interest in Australia as a supplier is the proposed amendment to the Federal Government's export facilitation scheme, a central plank of the existing motor vehicle plan.

The Industry Commission has recommended that vehicle import companies, such as Mercedes Benz, should in future be able to earn dollar for dollar export credits for value added goods they supply to foreign trading partners instead of the current 50 1/3 in the dollar they are entitled to.

Here we have further evidence that firms such as Daimler-Benz that are traders in luxury cars will rely not on their trade in those cars but on the Federal Government's laudable-and supported by the Democrats-export facilitation scheme. So the argument that the Government has put forward is rather spurious.

It is instructive to look at some of the price reductions that will result from this Government's measure. The top model on the Jaguar scale is priced at $180,960. That will achieve a reduction of $20,220, therefore now costing $167,040. Similar reductions occur in the other lines. The top model in the Mercedes line will be available at $28,000 less. The top model in the Porsche line will be reduced by $17,557, and the top model in the Range Rover line by $11,260. These examples show clearly where the priorities of this Government are. The economic arguments have been shown, as I have outlined, to be quite spurious, and the economic justifications are not there. The social justice aspect of this measure is laughable.

This measure characterises the Government as a government for the wealthy, not as a government for the worker and for those people who are suffering under the government-induced-admittedly induced-recession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1991. As with Senator Watson earlier, I rise to speak on this amendment with rather some relish, because I, alongside a lot of my colleagues, pointed out the fallacy of this so-called luxury car tax or jealousy car tax that was introduced on the run last February. Worse still, not only was it on the run, but it was during an election campaign. I know from what I have read that the recommendation did not come from within the Government; it came from an adviser outside the Government. It was a way to be seen to be hitting the rich and so it was a good idea to bring it on during an election to get some supporters of the Senator Spindler-type to vote for the Government rather than for the Opposition on this line. Of course, it was a sugar-coated pill because it was going to raise $100m extra to be used on road funding in regard to black spots, mostly in New South Wales and to a certain extent probably in other States. It was explained at the time that it would raise, as I have already said, an extra $100m. However, the explanatory memorandum we have today says that the cost to revenue will be $15m in 1991, in this financial year, and $45m in 1991-92.

SPEECH.PARA: When it was introduced it was $100m and it sounded pretty good to be socking the rich for an extra $100m. And it sounded equally as good to be putting it into black spots-and I am all for extra road funding at any time. But I believe extra road funding should come from the fuel excises that we are forced to pay so liberally. But it seems peculiar that $100m was going on but only $45m was coming off. All the arguments that we have made along the line were correct. I would also like to know-and this is by the way-whether the extra $100m was actually put into place for those black spots, because it certainly did not come from the luxury car tax. Did it come from other revenue, or was it amongst the disposable promises made by the Government during the last election that have been forgotten?
I did ask Senator Button, the Minister representing the Treasurer, a question a few weeks ago, but we have not got an answer on that one. However, that is not the point of this debate.

The Government had already backed down, as Senator Watson has said, on four-wheel drives used in remote areas. These four-wheel drives are used in remote areas for safety in people transport as well as for goods transport and children's transport to school and that sort of thing. Initially they were included in the luxury sales tax net. But the Government saw its folly and they were taken off.

As Senator Watson pointed out, there were a lot of things removed from vehicles to get them below the threshold. Some of those things were safety aspects, unfortunately, but other things were not totally safety aspects. Amongst those was air-conditioning. In most remote areas air-conditioning is not a luxury; it is a necessity. It is hard enough to keep people out there as it is without taxing those sorts of things that make their life out there a bit more bearable.

Unfortunately, even with this amendment and the Government having seen the folly of its ways, there is still a certain amount of luxury tax, or jealousy tax, on vehicles that are priced at over $45,046 retail. There is a discrepancy of 10 per cent.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, 23 March just past was a very important day for democracy in Queensland. It was the day that 2,367 citizens of that State offered themselves for election to the local authorities in Queensland. There were some 245 candidates for the positions of mayor and shire chairman of the various authorities throughout Queensland, and some 2,122 candidates for the positions of aldermen or councillors on the city and shire councils throughout the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government-the third tier of government-is really one of the most important and significant forms of government that we enjoy in Australia. It is the form of government that is the very closest to the people. It is a form of government where actions are taken, where the matters of immediate concern to the citizens of our nation are dealt with by people who offer themselves and give of their time and efforts to make sure that the wishes of their communities are implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no reward.

—And no reward, as Senator Panizza says. It is a level of government that is sometimes sneered at by the purists and the intellects: they indicate that it is not a quite proper form of government. But I disagree with that often held view. I think it is the most important form of government. It is a form of government that is directly and immediately accountable to its electors. It is a form of government where electors can immediately, without having to search around office buildings in cities or here in Canberra, get in touch with their local representative, the person who can do something about the problem that they have.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a form of government that is comprised of people who, more often than not, volunteer their time. Often they are citizens of smaller communities who are well known as being worthy people dedicated to a task and to their community. Local authorities are comprised of people who work simply to help their fellow man by making sure their communities operate properly.

As Senator Panizza has said, and I know he speaks from personal experience, it is a form of government which costs the taxpayer very, very little. There are no $60,000, $70,000 or $100,000 payments for these legislators. In many cases, these councillors work without any remuneration. In other instances, particularly in the smaller shires, they are recompensed only by way of a meeting fee. There are many elected councillors and aldermen who spend their own money simply to be there to serve and help their fellow man. I know. I was on a shire council for 12 years and the meeting fee we received for a whole day was considerably less than even I could have earned in a hour.

In the same vein, the former shire chairman of our particular locality was a medical practitioner. He could have earned quite a lot of money in his business practising medicine but he chose to devote a considerable part of his time to being practically a full time chairman of the shire for the benefit of its inhabitants. He did so at enormous financial cost to himself. Those sorts of situations are repeated throughout Queensland and, I am sure, throughout the rest of Australia.

Not only do these elected people receive little or nothing in the way of remuneration; they seldom receive any thanks at all. They are on call day and night, at weekends, and on weekdays during working hours and after working hours. Quite often, it seems to me, just as one is sitting down for tea, the phone rings and an elector wants something done. All of these things are looked after diligently and with good grace by these many, many people right throughout Australia who offer themselves to serve their fellow man.

In Queensland there are some 134 positions of shire chairman or mayor and some 1,188 positions of councillor or alderman. These positions are all filled by people wanting to do their bit for their community. And they do a mighty job. They devote their time. One can imagine what the cost would be to the public purse if they were paid for all of the work they did. If a Commonwealth public servant, for example, were to do the amount of work that these elected officials are doing every day of the week, weekends included, the cost would be enormous. But these people do it in a voluntary capacity. They do it well, they do it honestly, and they should receive much more recognition than they get.

In Queensland on 23 March some 60 positions in the Aboriginal councils throughout the State were also filled. There were 220 nominations for those as well. We do owe those Aboriginal councillors-in fact, councillors right throughout the State-a debt of gratitude.

People in local government, with the expertise that they have, should be more involved in looking at the bigger picture in our nation. I subscribe to a view which some of the peak organisations have put, that local government should be involved in Premiers Conferences and in the gatherings of the Prime Minister and the State leaders. I do concur with the view put forward that representatives of local government should also be involved in those forums of major decision making that affect all levels of government within Australia.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I want to pay tribute briefly to the former Lord Mayor of Brisbane, former Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson, who for 12 years did a tremendous job for the people of Brisbane. She carried out her role as a leader of that community with distinction and style. She worked ceaselessly to pursue the interests of the community she served, and she did it very, very well. She put Brisbane on the map. She made Brisbane a world recognised city, a city that is proud of itself.

In addition, Sallyanne and her team initiated much progress in the city. I do not come from the Brisbane area but on my rare visits to the capital it was noticeable that every couple of months new roads had been sealed, improvements had been made to parks and streets had been kerbed.

Sallyanne will certainly go down in history as one of the great leaders of the civic community in the Brisbane area. I am sure that Sallyanne will be back to serve again the people of her community with the distinction that she has shown in the past. I am sure that the people of Brisbane are already lamenting the fact that she is not there. I do wish her successor the best of luck and I congratulate him on achieving the position of Lord Mayor.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will need it.

—As Senator O'Chee says, he will certainly need every ounce of luck he can get. He will need every bit of luck that he can muster as he takes on that job. He was not equipped for the job and he was not trained for the job. The ALP could not get anyone to stand there. All its high fliers-Alderman Hinchcliffe and all the rest of these people who think they have some future in ALP civic halls-were not game to stand. They were not prepared to throw their hats in. They wimped out the back because they thought they would get thrashed, so the ALP found someone-it did not really matter who-threw him into the job, and through a quirk of fate he is now there leading the team. And isn't the ALP embarrassed about that! As press reports show, he goes everywhere with a minder who tells him what to do. So he will need every bit of luck he can have. I certainly wish it to him, particularly for the sake of the people of Brisbane, and I hope that he is able to make some sort of a fist of the job. He has very, very big shoes to step into, but he has my best wishes as he moves into the job.

SPEECH.PARA: It was an interesting set of elections in Queensland. Some people said it had political significance. Some idiots-people who obviously have no idea of the political system-were saying, `The Liberals have lost in Brisbane; therefore John Hewson is in trouble'. That sort of rubbish was the sort of thing that the ALP tried to trot out at the time. But of course, the ALP forgets that in the same election in Queensland there were a number of ALP councils and mayors who were also defeated, so it was quite an unusual election. The Labor mayor of Rockhampton was defeated at the polls. Some Labor councils were elected. While the Gold Coast runs as an independent council, the Labor Party and the people that support it were trounced there.

I mention the little shire of Cardwell, which is up near where I live and which is based on the towns of Tully and Cardwell. There, the sitting council was not popular with some of the locals so a team got together. That team comprised a well-known Labor man, a well-known Liberal man-the chairman of the Liberal branch up there-and a well-known National Party man. They got together, ran as a team, and swept the polls. So that is the way--

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be a good national solution.

—Yes, Senator Button, maybe it would be a good national solution; but you are always welcome to come and join us as your ship sinks slowly into the sea. We would welcome someone with your talents on board.
—We are not too sure of that.
—Okay, if we are not sure of that I will take that back.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other political election campaign fought in Queensland in the local authorities was in the city where I have my principal office, Townsville. In that election the Liberal Party did very well, picking up a lot of votes in the area and increasing the number of seats it held on the Townsville City Council. I particularly congratulate the Liberal aldermen who succeeded in the Townsville City Council: Alderman Peter Lindsay, who has been there for some time; Alderman Jim Cathcart, a real stalwart who won comfortably despite predictions to the contrary; and a new alderman, Alderman John Francis, a local solicitor from Townsville, a man who will contribute a great deal of expertise and ability to the running of the Townsville City Council.

I congratulate the Labor mayor, Alderman Mooney, on his re-election to the position. Alderman Mooney and I had some tiffs in the run-up to the election. He got quite annoyed at one time and was threatening to report me to everyone-report me to Dr Hewson and other people-but that was all part of the election. It was all done with the best of intentions. I certainly do not hold it against Alderman Mooney that he has threatened me with all sorts of things. I want to work with him and I have told him that. He is the mayor of the City of Townsville and he will have my support, as will his council, in anything he does to promote the interests of that major city in far north Queensland.

I also wish to congratulate the other leaders of local communities in north Queensland: Alderman Tyrell, who is the new mayor in the Thuringowa region, replacing a long serving Alderman Dan Gleeson, who had served his community with distinction; Alderman Pine in Mulgrave; Alderman Cleland in Cairns; Alderman Williamson, the new mayor in Mackay; Councillor Overton in Innisfail; Councillor Honeycombe from my town of Ayr; Councillor Rae Brown in Hinchinbrook; Councillor Patulo from the Whitsunday shire; Councillor White in Pioneer; Councillor Leather in Bowen; and Councillor Dot Bingham from Charters Towers. I extend my best wishes to all of these people as they take on the challenge of leading their communities in the next three years.

Finally, I wish to congratulate all of those people who succeeded in the elections. I congratulate also those who were not successful. They certainly have my admiration for offering themselves for a role in their community and they deserve the congratulations of the community as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I want today to express again, briefly, the concern of many of my colleagues on this side of the chamber about the Government's failure to provide answers to questions on notice within the time specified by the Senate Standing Orders, namely, no longer than 30 days. If one looks at the Senate Notice Paper for the start of this week, one sees that it contains a very large number of questions on notice that have not been answered within that required timeframe.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of my colleagues have drawn attention in recent sittings of the Senate to this slackness by Government Ministers. I know that Senator Alston also raised this matter a month ago during the public interest debate. Not only did he not receive timely answers to, I think, three of his questions but also he expressed concern about the adequacy of the explanations given for the delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or not given.
—Or not given, as he rightly points out.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important matter, because it reflects on the Government's attitude towards the processes of parliament and towards the role of parliament in our democratic system. There is no doubt at all that this Government has increasingly shown a disregard for both of those.

I want to draw particular attention today to two questions on notice that I have not received answers to. One of them was put to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, and the other, through Senator Button, to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Those questions were put on notice on 6 February; it is now 11 April, 63 days later.

The question to Senator Bolkus related to the Government's national prices network (NPN). In that question I sought further details of the Government's funding and outfitting of the national prices network. In particular, I sought details of whether the Government was maintaining its support of the NPN, whether additional staff were being provided for NPN activities and whether any members or senators had received still further additional computer equipment, staff or other assistance for their involvement in the activities of the national prices network.

That network, of course, is the Australian Labor Party's political propaganda tool, funded over and above Remuneration Tribunal recommendations for conditions for members of parliament. No coalition members or senators, of course, have received any extra computer facilities for the national prices network, or additional staff, and nor should they. The disgraceful thing is that there have been seven or eight members of parliament on the Labor Party side who are continually receiving additional computer facilities and funding for additional part time staff which is costing the taxpayer many thousands of dollars per year and which has not, in essence, been made public.

The information that I am seeking is really information to update the material that we have been seeking and receiving from the Government-under pressure, I must say, and in response to questions asked for a number of years in Senate Estimates committees and elsewhere since the network was set up.

Really, the information that I have requested of Senator Bolkus, who is in the chamber now, should be readily available to the Minister and to the Senate. I can think of no legitimate reason at all why answers have not yet been provided. I will be interested to see what explanation the Minister gives when I finally do receive the information.

The issue, therefore, in my view, is about why the Government is deliberately seeking to hide the facts on what it is doing to prop itself up at taxpayers' expense to enable it to increase its electoral appeal in the community through this propaganda scheme of the national prices network. What it is all about is Labor trying to give itself electoral advantages through the backdoor. We are seeing this par excellence at the moment with the proposed ban on electronic media advertising and in a whole host of other ways. I am very concerned about the failure of the Minister to provide answers to my questions. I ask again that that delay be terminated and that those answers, which should be readily and very easily available, be provided. This matter should not be allowed to drag on any further.

The second question, the one to the Treasurer through Senator Button, relates to grants to the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO). Once again, the material that I have asked for should be readily available and easily obtained by the Department of the Treasury. Once again, it is essentially an update of material that we have requested and dragged out of the Government over recent years. I am concerned about the level of funding that AFCO is receiving from the Government and, more particularly, whether that funding is being properly acquitted.

The history of AFCO accounting for Federal grants is not a good one. That is of very significant importance, given that we are talking about the use of taxpayers' money by an outside lobby organisation, a special interest group, and the fact that that funding comprises virtually all the funding available from any source to this consumer organisation.

As well as the money that AFCO has received in this form, we are talking about a considerable amount of funding for a body which is not representative of all consumers, as it claims to be. We have raised this matter on a number of occasions in the Senate and through Senate committees. For example, in 1989-90 AFCO received something like 95 per cent of its total revenue from the Federal Government and that ran into several hundred thousand dollars.

AFCO, of course, also wields considerable influence through being represented on many government boards and advisory committees. Answers that I have received in the past to questions asked at Senate Estimates committee hearings show that AFCO had representatives on 11 of these boards or advisory committees. But that was a gross understatement because there is other information available which shows that as at April 1989 a former director of AFCO, a Robin Brown, was listed as being on no less than 48 boards and committees. That is an enormous amount of involvement in a whole network of government advisory and other bodies by one person representing one organisation.

So, my questions regarding AFCO are very important if the Parliament is to perform its proper scrutiny of government funding and the allocation of taxpayers' resources. They are important also in determining the amount of influence that organisations such as AFCO can have on the general advice coming to government on a very wide range of issues.

I am also concerned about whether the Department of the Treasury is properly monitoring grants like the one to AFCO for national price network activities. There is a link there between AFCO and the national prices network. Indeed, AFCO has its national prices network funding provided by a grant from the Government.

The failure of the Treasurer and his Department to ensure that my latest questions on these matters are answered is a matter of concern. I am certainly not reassured that the Treasurer and his Department have this area of their activities under control at all. Again, I will be very interested to see what explanation is given to the Senate for the failure to answer the questions in a timely manner.

I will not pursue the matter further at this stage, other than to point out again to the Senate that this is a very important issue, not just in terms of the questions on which I am seeking answers but more particularly in terms of the whole attitude of this Government towards the observance of the Standing Orders of this Senate which require that the Government responds to questions on notice in a timely fashion. But I regret to say that those Standing Orders are being more honoured in the breach than the observance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to take the opportunity to talk about one of the few bright points on the agricultural horizon in Australia at the moment. I am talking, of course, about Australia's cotton industry. It is a little-known fact that last year the cotton cooperative based in Wee Waa in New South Wales produced in excess of $300m of export earnings for this country. That figure is roughly comparable with the export earnings of the Ford motor car corporation in the preceding financial year. In the same period, a small cotton cooperative can earn for Australia as many export dollars as Ford did with its exports of Capri cars to the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: One might well ask, `Why is it that the public does not know about the significant contribution being made by this outstanding Australian agricultural industry to our balance of payments?'. Why indeed. It seems that too much of the public's attention of late has been taken up by the manufacturing sector and not enough attention has been paid to the importance of agricultural industries in combating Australia's balance of payments problem.

The interesting thing is that 20 or 30 years ago there was hardly any cotton industry at all in Australia. Cotton has taken off like a bushfire in northern New South Wales and in southern and central Queensland. This agricultural industry is earning us hundreds of millions of dollars every year-vital dollars for this economy and for the people not only of provincial Australia but of Australia as a whole.

I was very grateful for the opportunity that I was given by the cotton cooperative to look around the gin, to meet cotton producers and to look at the way in which cotton is classed and shipped overseas. The classing of cotton is particularly important because the higher quality the cotton, the better the primary producer gets paid for the crop.

At Wee Waa the cotton cooperative is currently involved in processing and classing the cotton using computer facilities so that there can be very little dispute about the quality of the cotton and the characteristics of the fibre which is sent overseas. Of course, the higher the quality of the fibre, the better the export earnings and the better the money that comes back to the producer.

There is always a bit of an argument between buyers and sellers as to the quality of the cotton in question. It is intrinsically a subjective argument. This computer grading facility reduces the grounds upon which the buyers can say that the cotton is not of the quality that they ordered. Of course, they are still going to use this argument anyway in order to try to get a couple of extra dollars from the producer. The computer classing and grading facilities at that cotton cooperative are excellent.

People have always said that American cotton is the best in the world. Mr O'Brien, a classer at the cooperative who has worked in the United States cotton industry and is an American by birth, told me that Australian cotton is in fact the finest cotton that is produced anywhere in the world. He said that that is not just because of the micron count, the evenness and length of the cotton fibre, but also because Australian cotton tends on the whole to be very low in dirt and contaminants.

However, it is not just in New South Wales that I have visited cotton growers over the last couple of weeks; I had the great pleasure of visiting cotton growers in Cecil Plains in my home State of Queensland and also cotton growers near Theodore in central Queensland. What they are doing is very exciting. The contribution that these people make to Australia's export earnings is superb and the productivity of the cotton industry around Cecil Plains is absolutely brilliant. We are getting very high yields of cotton of very good quality. That, of course, is a sign that progress is being made in the Australian cotton industry and that every year, barring accidents of weather, we can expect improvements, not just in the volume of cotton produced but also in the quality, and therefore improved export earnings for this industry.

What is absolutely critical, therefore, is that the Government does not go and kick the cotton industry in the teeth, as it has done to so many other export industries in this country. I hasten to add that we would be selling so many more dollars worth of agricultural exports were it not for the fact that the Government has an overpriced Australian dollar and this affects the export earnings of the cotton industry, as it has affected the export earnings of beef, wheat, wool and so on. It is absolutely critical that the cotton industry be allowed to grow and continue to produce export earnings for Australia. The real danger is, of course, that when you get a bad year-when it rains at the time you want to pick the cotton, or when it is too dry and the cotton is not able to grow properly-and the farmers' production is marginal, the added costs that the Government imposes on the cotton producers and the added costs that are imposed on the waterfront are going to take valuable dollars out of the farmers' pockets.

The problems we have on the waterfront intrinsically affect the value of the crop to the farmer because in an internationally competitive market, when every dollar and every cent of the price of a pound of cotton are of major significance, the added cost at the waterfront through lack of reform of excessive and unproductive practices not only harm the farmer but harm the community. I am very concerned, at a time when we have a rampant rural recession, that every single dollar we can send back to those farming communities makes its way there.

As far as I am concerned, it is an outrage that too many farmers' dollars get tied up at the wharves as a result of uncompetitive and unproductive shipping agreements, especially across the Tasman. It is of concern to me that the Government takes its fair whack out of the farmers' profits-hard-earned profits, I hasten to add-through its sales tax on the road freight industry. The 20 per cent sales tax on road transport is a major impediment to substantial improvement in the cotton industry, as it is in every other agricultural industry in this nation, especially with the level of fertilisers and chemicals needed to protect the cotton plants as they grow to maturity. The added cost as a result of the 20 per cent sales tax on the road freight to get those necessary chemicals and fertilisers to the farmers takes dollars out of the farmers' pockets and dollars out of those communities, and those dollars are lost to particularly hard-hit areas of provincial Australia.

I conclude by saying that the cotton industry is a bright light for Australia's agricultural exports. It is a shame and a damnation of this Government that there are not more substantially profitable agricultural industries. We know the reason why-we know it is because of the Government's failed economic policies-but we have, at least in cotton, a fine export earner for Australia, an industry that produces a natural product second to none anywhere around the world and an industry that we must all support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As politicians we ask people to trust us to make decisions which affect almost every aspect of their lives. The opinion polls tell us that people generally believe that politicians, of recent times, have let them down. To put it simply, the community at large no longer trusts us to act always in the best interests of the people. The recovery of that standing, that credibility within the community, will be established only by performance, by actions of politicians to re-establish credibility and standing within the community. Over the past four months I have witnessed a prime example of why people do not trust politicians. Yet again, the Hawke Government has been promising and not delivering. Because of Government action such as that, politicians of all parties are being branded as untrustworthy; that is why the standing of politicians within the community has been reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply want to put on the record what Senator Michael Tate promised, yet did not deliver, to the beleaguered citrus growers of the Riverland in South Australia. I want in doing so to let other politicians-and, importantly, the media-know that we have here a weak Minister who has caved in at the expense of a group of people who work hard for this country and who, sadly, trusted him to do what he had publicly stated he would do to help them.

As a senator for South Australia I have been involved with the problems of the citrus growers for some time. They have had enormous problems with fruit juice and pulp being dumped in Australia from countries such as Brazil. The situation has been made worse by the fact that these growers, immensely proud of their product, know that within that dumping of juice concentrate from overseas there has been-and because of Government inaction still is-illegal adulteration with inferior pulp wash.

What Australian consumers have been buying without knowing it, and because of this Government, is fruit juice contaminated with overseas produced, poor quality juice extracted from the peel of the fruit instead of the endocarp of the fruit-a frequent happening in dumped material from overseas.

In Australia peel juice is limited to cordial products and is illegal for use in any other juice.
