But it needs country of origin labelling to discourage such abuse, which the Government and the industry both know is rampant in dumped fruit juice product. At the same time, industry research has clearly identified that consumers want to know exactly what they are buying, what they are eating and what they are drinking. In other words, there is obvious concern, and there is certainly consumer demand, for country of origin labelling. Last November Senator Tate thought so too. On 28 and 29 November, Senator Tate, as Minister for Consumer Affairs, put out two most decisive press statements. On 28 November he said:
Australian consumers have a right to know the country of origin of the foodstuffs they buy.
Some fruit juice being sold in Australia with the marking `Product of Australia' in fact contains only 25 per cent of local fruit juice.
I strongly support the proposition that consumers are entitled to know the truth about the origin of the food and beverages they buy.

He finished off his press release of that day with the now almost laughable claim that growers will be encouraged to promote their all-Australian product, confident in the knowledge that any imported competitors will have to make full disclosures.
That was an admirable stance by the Minister. The next day, 29 November, he was still being the strong man. He said:
The change in regulations will make it compulsory to show a declaration on the package of any juice or juice product to identify the country or countries of origin of the product.
And if there is a mixture of local and imported ingredients this must be declared.
Senator Tate was so adamant that this was all going to happen that he finished the press release with the statement:
I expect the amendments to the food standards code will be gazetted early next year, which is ample time for importers and distributors to make the necessary changes to their packaging.

So what happened to all the Minister's fine words? Basically, they were not worth the paper they were written on. The South Australian citrus growers contacted me in January. They were angry, disillusioned, and rightly suspicious of political input. They told me that the gazetting of a national standard for fruit juice labelling, as promised in November by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, was not going to happen. Interestingly, my office checked on this through the Parliamentary Library, which in turn contacted the Minister's office. Senator Tate's staff denied there was any change from what was announced in the press releases of November last. But the citrus growers were right: it was not going to happen. They had found out, when South Australia gazetted its own labelling regulations on 20 December last year, that it was all rhetoric by the Minister. Those regulations simply required that, where fruit juices contained some imported fruit, this had to be stated on the container-not how much imported fruit juice was in the product; and they most definitely did not order country of origin labelling on the package.

In his press statement of 20 December, the South Australian Health Minister, Don Hopgood, alluded to a national standard to be announced the next year which would `bring in similar labelling controls'. The standard he was alluding to was the very standard that Senator Tate had promised Australians, just four weeks previously, would definitely, positively contain specific country of origin labelling, and nothing less. The citrus growers saw the warning signs. They wrote to South Australian Health Minister Hopgood, and he replied in February, telling them that many groups, including manufacturers, had decided that country of origin labelling was too expensive. It was a remarkable backdown.

Yet still Senator Tate was denying publicly that it was going to happen. When the regulations were not gazetted within the time frame that his staff had indicated to the media, by the first week of March, I asked the honourable senator, in Question Time, whether he was going to back down from his November statements. I suppose, in what you would call typical Hawkespeak, he said no, but yes. He said:

It may be difficult to indicate exactly which countries of origin contributed to a particular bottle or container of fruit juice, and it may be sufficient for the consumer to know that the ingredients are imported.
I repeat what he said:
. . . it may be sufficient . . . to know that the ingredients are imported.

Why, I asked, was it suddenly sufficient in March 1991 to know just that there was some imported product when in November 1990 knowing only that fact was the very reason the Minister gave for strengthening the regulations to very specific country of origin labelling? I will tell honourable senators why. He was pressured to water them down, to back down, by another vested interest group within the community.

It gets worse. I have received a letter which Senator Tate wrote to the Murray Valley Citrus Marketing Board, dated 25 February. That letter seeks to blatantly ignore, totally, all public statements he made on the subject in the previous November. Senator Tate's letter stated:
Your letter expresses a strong preference that . . . the actual country of origin is specified rather than allow the more general statement that the product is imported.
I can understand and appreciate your desire to see your stated preference as the only form of labelling. However there are reasons why alternatives have been proposed.
Senator Tate continued with a list of manufacturers' excuses about why they could not label their packages with the country of origin.

What we need to recognise is: if we can get a uniform set of laws applying in all the States in Australia, there will be no major additional cost for people processing orange fruit juice, for example, in having to include on the package the range of countries of origin of the product. So it is wrong to suggest that such labelling will be too expensive. Provided we get uniform laws for all States, which is an objective which we ought to pursue-I stress that point-the main part of the problem that the processors are confronted with, in terms of cost, in this country will be solved.

So, bluntly, country of origin labelling is not only essential but completely and easily possible. It is feasible. That Senator Tate should cave in to industry pressure about it supposedly being too expensive because different countries of origin need different labels for different batches of products will not wash. It will not wash with the citrus growers and it will not wash with the Australian public asking for truth in labelling. As someone put it to me, we go out and encourage people to buy Australian and then we are not prepared to insist that there is a description on the package that demonstrates whether it is Australian. As Minister for Consumer Affairs, he has not shown himself worthy of his position for he does not have the good of the consumers at heart in this instance. He has delivered us a prime example of exactly why the electorate views politicians with suspicion-promise much, deliver little; promise much, change your mind. I hope he realises the seriousness of his decision.

Frankly, I am tired of hearing from the media that the Minister's staff say he was at the mercy of the State health Ministers. Technically he was, but only technically, for we all know that in practice he could have made the manufacturers toe the line by gazetting a national standard for labelling. He has not done so, and it does not look as though he will. In the meantime, the Australian public yet again is let down by a Minister not prepared to fulfil his commitment, his undertaking, to the public of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to plead for some sanity, not for some sanity in this place but for some sanity to return to the governing of my State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania is in crisis. We have a minority Labor government teetering on the brink of collapse and we have the Green Independents, on whom it relies, set to move a no-confidence motion on a senior Government Minister. Such an atmosphere is creating an aura of great uncertainty in my State and it is affecting the business and community at large. It is time that this issue was resolved by giving the people of Tasmania a fresh opportunity to decide who they believe is the best equipped to govern our State.

There are two clear losers out of this present crisis: the Green Independents and the Field Government. Almost every week since Premier Field took up office the Government has been under threat by its former accord partners on some issue or other. The Tasmanian Parliament simply cannot continue to operate under this air of uncertainty.

The no-confidence motion which is shortly to be discussed is aimed at the handling of the education portfolio by the State's Deputy Premier, Mr Peter Patmore, the number two senior politician in the present Labor Government. This whole issue places questions about the credibility of the so-called Green Independents. Early this week a no-confidence motion in Mr Patmore as the Minister for Education was moved by the Liberal Opposition. This motion, which was essentially the same as the one to be moved by Mrs Milne on behalf of the Green Independents, was rejected by the Green Independents, who have chosen to pursue some other method of attack. It is inconsistent to support one no-confidence motion whilst at the same time rejecting another which is couched in similar terms.

It is apparent that one way or another it will be shown that the Deputy Premier, the Minister for Education, Mr Patmore, no longer has the support of the State Lower House, and under these circumstances the Premier has no choice but to sack Mr Patmore or replace him with an alternative Labor member, or to accept the vote of no confidence as a trigger for a new State election.

Naturally, one does not call for a new State election lightly as there is considerable cost involved, particularly for the taxpayers. However, if an election is inevitable, it is preferable for my State that the issue be determined immediately. Further deals, further grandstanding, only continue to show both the present State Labor Government and the Green Independents in a very bad light. Should this no-confidence motion urged by Mrs Milne proceed in its present form, there is sure to be considerable legal debate as to the possible outcome. This is one further reason why the State Government should support the calls for an election.

I mentioned earlier the credibility of the Green Independents who are members of the Tasmanian House of Assembly. Yesterday the State Liberal Opposition education spokesman down there, Mr John Beswick, made the claim that the Green Independents were guilty of putting woodchips before children. It is this type of attitude which has characterised the Greens' behaviour since they entered the State Parliament. If they are serious about the crisis in the State's education system and if they are serious about the massive waste of taxpayers' money on redundancies in the Education Department only then to find the need to hire additional staff to replace those paid off on redundancy packages, they should follow this matter through.

Any member of parliament has an obligation to his or her electorate to give a commitment on all issues. We cannot enter a parliament simply to pursue a single aim, as the Greens have done. It is time for the Green Independents to stand up and be counted as politicians who are there to fairly represent the electorate, rather than opportunists who seek to achieve one-sided deals.

I note with interest that there has been some talk around this place about the possibility of the Greens forming an alliance with the Democrats. This idea is being welcomed in some areas of the Democrats Party, but I urge most strongly that those Democrat members who have any sense at all consider the matter very seriously before they make any decisions. They should look at what the Greens have done to Tasmania. They could very soon find their particular party in the same place. The Greens in Tasmania, since they entered State Parliament, have proven themselves to be unreliable and unpredictable. I would not see any advantage to the Democrats taking them on board.

Since Senator Bell has come here from Tasmania I have served on committees with him and I have found him to have a range of views on a range of subjects, which is more than I can say for some of the Green Independents in Tasmania. If such an alliance were to come about, I would suspect that Bob Brown, for instance, would replace Senator Bell representing Tasmania. Tasmania would not be as well served by having a single issue candidate in this place as it is by having a person such as Senator Bell, who has quite good opinions on very wide-ranging matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they agree with yours.

—It does not matter. I implore Senator Kernot to pass on to her party my concerns that it will lose its identity. Just have a look at what has happened in Tasmania with these single issue candidates. I need say no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to congratulate the organisers of the exhibition One People, One Destiny, which is at present on display in the Senate exhibition area in Parliament House. It was opened by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator the Hon. Michael Tate, last Tuesday evening. I found the display most interesting, relating as it did to the National Australasian Convention which was held during March and April in 1891-100 years ago-to consider and report upon an adequate scheme for a federal constitution. This Convention was a meeting of 45 parliamentarians from the six Australian colonies and New Zealand, which met in the Legislative Assembly chamber of the New South Wales Parliament. I certainly seems to me appropriate that this exhibition should be arranged 100 years after the Convention for the Constitution was held.

SPEECH.PARA: At its conclusion, the Convention had succeeded in drawing up a draft constitution for a new nation, the Commonwealth of Australia. It would be 1900 before this draft Bill of 1891, considerably revised, would pass into law as an Act to constitute the Commonwealth of Australia. Not until then would the six British colonies become six Australian States, united under a federal parliament.

In March 1891 these six colonies were still in search of nationhood. Their parliaments reflected the system of government inherited from the British, who had commenced the colonisation of Australia in 1788. But the predominantly British settlers, widely scattered over a continent previously owned and cared for by its indigenous people, the Aboriginals, had early established a large measure of political independence.

The draft Bill to constitute the Commonwealth of Australia, drawn up by the delegates to the National Australasian Convention in 1891, was the outcome not of revolution but of a developing sense of Australian nationalism and the practical necessity for the colonies to speak with one voice, rather than six, on issues such as defence, tariffs and postal services.

The decision to outline a plan for a federal government was not a sudden one. The federal movement had been gradually gathering momentum throughout the second half of the nineteenth century, and by the 1890s it appears to have gained fairly wide acceptance. It was the structure of a federal government which now had to be decided. This was the task before the National Australasian Convention when it assembled at Parliament House, Sydney, on 2 March 1891.

The 45 delegates to the National Australasian Convention met during a period of economic upheaval and political change. Australia was about to enter a severe depression. A shearers strike threatened the wool industry-so it was in trouble even then, just as it seems to be in trouble at present, but this time not due to a shearers strike-and unemployment was rising. While the delegates to the Convention could be described as being either liberal or conservative in political outlook, there were also among them one or two radicals. It is important to remember that in March 1891 political parties, as we know them today, were not established. There were instead loose alliances of like-minded politicians, sometimes centred on issues such as free trade or protection.

The six Australian colonial parliaments sent seven delegates each to the Convention, each delegation being led by its own Prime Minister, as the Premiers were sometimes described in those days. It is interesting to note that there were New Zealand delegates there as well. They appear to have been more in the role of informed observers. There were only three of them. Apparently it did not convince them that they ought to belong to Australia, as it was known then.

Many of the delegates had travelled around the coast to Sydney by steamer or train, and-would you believe it, Mr Acting Deputy President-they were all men. Women did not even have the right to vote, let alone to sit in the Parliament. Perhaps some of our women might say that they have not done too much better since those days. But at least there are quite a number of women senators, even if there are not quite as many women in the House of Representatives.

Some of the delegates had been born in Australia. Most had spent the greater part of their lives in this country. All were in favour of an independent Australian nation, still aligned with Britain but not subservient to Britain. The youngest of the delegates was the Victorian politician Alfred Deakin, who later wrote that the Convention was `by far the most important representative gathering which had ever met in Australia'.

However, I found it interesting that not all the work of the National Australasian Convention took place in formal debate or in the committee rooms of the New South Wales Parliament. When the Convention rose for Easter, Sir Samuel Walker Griffith, from Queensland, invited some of his colleagues to join him on board the Queensland Government's steamer for a working cruise down the Hawkesbury River. It seems very interesting to me, as a senator from Queensland, that in those days, way back in 1891, the Queensland Government owned a steamer. Now it owns an aeroplane. Quite a lot of the politicians in Queensland who sat on the opposite side to my husband were always complaining about the fact that the Queensland Government owned an aeroplane. But in those days it owned a steamer, the Lucinda, and it was decided that a working party would be held on the steamer.

There is a very lovely model of the Lucinda in the display in the exhibition hall upstairs. It has been loaned by the Queensland Museum. I hope that all senators have taken the opportunity to have a look at the display upstairs. I think the folk who helped to put it together, Rosemary Lang and all the others, deserve a great deal of credit.

It is very good that Mr Bartholomai, the Director of the Museum up there, went to a lot of trouble to send it down in a case so that it could be preserved and protected and so that it could form a very important part of this display. The Lucinda was the boat on which the members of the Australasian Convention went off to have an Easter weekend on the Hawkesbury. They left on the Good Friday and returned on the Easter Monday. All the people who went off on the ship were lawyers. They sailed out of Sydney Harbour in rough seas. Reaching Broken Bay, the Lucinda anchored in an estuary off the Hawkesbury River. At Refuge Bay some of the delegates took a shower under a waterfall-I thought that was rather cute-before they got down to the business of constitution making. The version of the Constitution Bill which was revised on board the Lucinda was subsequently debated at length by the Convention but few alterations were made.

However, it was not only on board the Lucinda that delegates encountered rough seas. The reason for Australia becoming a federation rather than having one single government lies in its history. What are now the six States of Australia were originally six colonies. None of these colonies would have been prepared to give up its political entity, but they were prepared to yield up some of their powers to a Federal government. Influenced by the Senate of the Congress of the United States, the delegates conceived the Australian Senate as the House which, in providing equal representation to the future States, would protect the interests of the smaller States against the heavily populated and wealthier New South Wales and Victoria. That is what the whole Senate has been about. That is what the aim was in those days.

What of the powers of the Senate in relation to those of the House of Representatives, the House to which, under the British system of parliamentary democracy, Ministers must be responsible? Early in the debate the astute Sir Samuel Griffith put his finger on this problem, which was to be by far the most difficult one before the Convention. He went on to say, `It is absolutely new to us that every law shall receive the assent of the majority of the people as well as a majority of the States. We are launching upon an unknown sea'. Happily, the delegates were not wrecked upon that sea. They came up with what is now known as the compromise of 1891. That was that the Senate would not be able to amend financial legislation proposed by the House of Representatives, but-honourable senators will be pleased to know-it could make suggestions. This compromise remains the basis of section 53 of the Australian Constitution. In all other legislation the Senate and the House of Representatives would have equal legislative power.

The President of the Convention was the veteran Premier of New South Wales, the Honourable Sir Henry Parkes. I have looked at all the photographs that are upstairs, and one that I was really impressed with was a picture of the lady photographer. There were not very many women associated with the Convention. I take it she was a lady because it says she was a woman-Laura someone; I have forgotten what her surname was. There is a model of her taking a photograph of all the delegates to the Convention. One never has any trouble recognising Sir Henry Parkes by his great big, flowing, white beard. That was very interesting. Unfortunately Parkes did not achieve his dream of becoming the first Prime Minister of a united Australia. He died in 1896 at the age of 81. But his efforts in 1890 and 1891 to activate the federation debate can be said to have earned him the title `The Father of Federation'.

I pay a tribute to these men who, in those early days, had this great vision, one people, one destiny, and who convened the National Australasian Convention in Sydney. How good it is that this most interesting exhibition has been arranged. I hope that all senators will have a look at it. They will find it very worth while and very interesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak once again on the necessity for a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. Honourable senators would know that I have been pushing for some years-I think ever since I came into the Senate-for a third runway. Each year Kingsford-Smith Airport has 13 million passengers passing through it. It employs more than 19,000 people and contributes about $2 billion each year to our national economy. Despite all those things, it is in a crisis and it needs something done about it and a third runway built. It is in a crisis because it handles some 200,000 aircraft movements a year and is at saturation level. It is ranked as the third most congested airport in the Asia-Pacific region. In good flying conditions it can handle about 60 aircraft movements an hour, but, of course, in bad weather this drops considerably.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been saying for some time that it will build a third runway, but having said that it has done everything in its power not to build it. We have had report after report, public inquiries, surveys, analysis of every conceivable aspect of construction, but still nothing being done. There have been eight separate reports on the question of improved air services in New South Wales and only one of those eight has opposed construction of a third runway. But, as I say, nothing is being done about it.

Where does this leave Australia's tourism industry and where does it leave country commuters? Already commuter airlines have been forced into a peak period surcharge, which has resulted in increased air fares, reduced services at convenient times, and a subsequent drop in the rural traffic estimated to be as high as 20 per cent. International travellers are expected to continue to put up with substandard service, queues both in the air and on the ground, and a vague promise that things will get better. But what is actually stopping the Government from going ahead and doing something about Kingsford-Smith Airport? Is it kowtowing to the members of parliament who have electorates that border the airport? Is there a lack of commitment on the Government's part to really improve services for rural Australia and our international visitors? What really is it?

The Government cannot continue to sit on the fence on this issue. It has already spent millions of dollars of taxpayers' money on acquiring land in Badgerys Creek. It has dislocated people's lives and businesses in that area, yet nothing much seems to be happening there. Yet Badgerys Creek is promoted as a reason why a third runway should not be constructed. The Government is allowing or promoting that the two ideas become intertwined and confused, probably in an effort to disguise its total inaction in both those areas.

There is no excuse for delaying any more the construction of the third runway. It can be up and operating years before a second airport is constructed, and in any event studies have shown that both the third runway and Badgerys Creek will be required. We cannot allow rural services to decline any further and we cannot continue to have Kingsford-Smith Airport as the bottleneck of our nation rather than the gateway to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald spoke earlier about local government elections held in Queensland on 23 March. I want to make some comments about those as well. I support what he said about the importance of the tier of local government and the selfless efforts of many Queenslanders in this regard. I join with him in congratulating all those Queenslanders who have been elected, especially Mary Hopkins, the Democrat elected to the Inglewood Shire Council in south-west Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: However, not surprisingly, Senator Macdonald omitted to acknowledge one of the important developments of this election, and that is the emergence of the Green Alliance. The Green Alliance is an alliance of Australian Democrats, the Rainbow Alliance and other environment and social justice oriented people from Queensland. We should acknowledge that this city council election proved a very strong debut for this alliance. The Green Alliance lord mayoral candidate, Drew Hutton, attracted 7.5 per cent of the vote, and, as we know, the preferences of those who voted for Drew Hutton proved crucial in the outcome. Democrat candidate Bob George from Kianawah secured 26 per cent of the vote; Doug Yuille from the Wilderness Society, who ran in the inner-city ward of Paddington, scored 17 per cent; and Democrat candidate Andrew Bartlett, who ran in Taringa, managed 15 per cent. All other Green Alliance candidates achieved over 10 per cent in the 12 of the 26 wards in which they ran.

The significance of the success of the Green Alliance campaign cannot be underestimated. This was a model for us to trial. I am pleased to say that it worked well. Very important issues had to be decided by cooperative action, issues such as preferences and where specific candidates would run. All of this was done on a shoestring budget with limited media coverage, and a very credible campaign was run.

There are some lessons for all of us in the fate of former Lord Mayor Atkinson. The first thing is that, as politicians, we need always to be aware of the difference between public perception and reality. We need to address ourselves to the success of smear campaigns which are run in the name of freedom of speech. To me, one of the great ironies of this campaign was that the Labor Party, which is proposing that we consider banning electronic advertising, ran really offensive television advertisements, and the Liberal Party, which is mounting a very strong support of what it sees as freedom of expression in this case, complained about these offensive advertisements. So the Brisbane City Council campaign was timely in that it has given all of us an opportunity to examine the power of electronic advertising and it has brought home the need to address honesty in advertising.

The Green Alliance, this new venture in cooperation between the Democrats and other environment and social justice groups, has forged links which will be strengthened by our good showing in this campaign and the experience gained from working together.
Sitting suspended from 1.58 to 2 p.m

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reports that Ambassador Brian Burke has decided to return to Australia to appear before the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in the next few weeks. Did the Ambassador discuss this decision with the Minister? Was the Minister aware yesterday that Mr Burke was intending to return so soon? How long is the Ambassador expected to be here? Is he returning to Australia on recreation leave and who will pay his travel expenses? What arrangements have been made for Australia's representation in Ireland during this period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the matter has not been the subject of any discussion between me and Mr Burke-
—It was all done between lawyers, was it?
—Order!

—Nor was I aware yesterday of the intention, that has now been stated publicly, for him to return to appear before the Commission before the end of this month. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been in contact with Mr Burke subsequent to that indication becoming public early this morning about Mr Burke's leave arrangements. Mr Burke has told my Department that he will be in a position to advise his preferred leave arrangements within the next day or so. Until then I am not in a position to indicate what the nature of those arrangements will be or to deal with questions relating to remuneration and so on. They are matters for determination in the light of Mr Burke's stated preference.

ANSWER.PARA: As to arrangements for the administration of the post during Mr Burke's absence, the intention is that the second-in-charge in the post will become the charge d'affaires. Since the person in question used to be the foreign policy adviser to Dr Hewson, I do not think there will be any complaints from the other side of the chamber about his qualifications to perform that job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you are deliberately interjecting at every stage.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister any indication as to what time for the remainder of this year he anticipates Mr Burke will be unavailable to fulfil his diplomatic duties in Ireland?

—No, I do not at this stage, because I do not know the duration of his likely appearances before the Commission or things that might bear upon that in terms of preparation time and so on. I am endeavouring to find out, and when I do find out I will be in a position to let Senator Hill know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. What is the Government's response to the stated opposition of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to its proposal to ban free time offered to political parties during elections? Does the Government agree with the Chairman of the ABC, Mr Somervaille, that the ban could substantially reduce the Corporation's power and editorial independence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's proposal will include a ban on paid and unpaid political advertising and free time currently provided by the ABC. I stress that the ABC's editorial independence in determining to what extent and in what manner it broadcasts news and current affairs will in no way be diminished. But the ABC, like all other broadcasters and users of the public airwaves, will not be able to broadcast free time advertisements for political parties. A ban which did not include free time access through the ABC would lead to an unfair position in that existing political parties would be in a position of privilege.

ANSWER.PARA: Having decided that the only effective way of curtailing the corruptive influences of increasing campaign costs is to apply a comprehensive ban on political and third party political advertising, the Government will not allow a situation where political parties have an advantage over the rest of the community because of access to ABC free time.

If one looks at recent years, the content of free time on the ABC has progressively shifted from party political broadcasts to recycling of political advertising that has been used in other commercial avenues. So for those reasons-the desire, firstly, not to have an unlevel playing field and, secondly, to ensure that the ban applies across the board in such a way that we can effectively curtail the increasing campaign costs to the political process-the Government has taken this decision.

I also stress, in closing, that the ban on advertising in no way impinges upon the manner in which the ABC broadcasts its news and current affairs programs, the way it decides to so broadcast them and to what extent it so decides to broadcast them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether we could ask the Minister to table the document which he just read because it is very hard for us to understand exactly what he says when he speaks.
—Order! Will the Minister table the document?
—No.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade received any advice from his Department on the wisdom of Ambassador Burke continuing in his diplomatic posting while allegations of such consequence are being made before the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters? If he has received such advice, what was the nature of that advice?

— On those matters the Department takes the view that it is a matter for my own judgment and I have received no such advice that I can recall. The question is one, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, and as I indicated also yesterday, as to whether Mr Burke can properly discharge his duties as Ambassador in all the circumstances. Certainly, I have taken the view that, at least until now, Mr Burke's ability to discharge his duties has not been inhibited. I will, of course, keep that situation under review in the light of further developments and I am sure that Mr Burke would not hesitate to advise me if he believed that he could no longer properly discharge his duties.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does the Department maintain a manual relating to the performance of duties by diplomatic officials and their proper conduct? Is there some document in existence and circulating to ambassadors about the nature of their duties, how they should be performed and so forth?
—Not that I am aware, but if anyone has a copy of such a document I would be quite pleased to see one at the moment. I do not have one.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister this question against the background of the damaging impact of the Gulf war on the economies of a number of developing countries. How has the Australian Government responded to the additional pressures created by the conflict in the Gulf on those developing nations which participate in Australia's aid program?
—Somebody has given me the wrong answer to that question. Could I take that on notice until the end of Question Time?

—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the Canberra Times article by Rod Campbell on 8 April entitled `No Extradition for Hand' and the fact that a royal commission by Justice Donald Stewart spent two years investigating the activities of the failed Nugan Hand Bank. That Commission reported that the bank had breached foreign exchange regulations and had been involved in tax evasion schemes and other fraudulent conduct. In view of the fact that the bank's director, Michael Hand, has now been found and that a warrant for his arrest is still in existence, firstly, does the Minister find it extraordinary that there is absolutely no interest being shown in him by any law enforcement or regulatory bodies in Australia, other than minor interest by the Australian Taxation Office; and, secondly, does the Minister intend to take any action to reactivate this issue? If not, why not?

—The question of whether any charge should be laid or pursued is a matter for Commonwealth or State investigating or prosecuting authorities. As I understand it, in the event of either the investigating or prosecuting authorities of the State or Commonwealth making the decision to lay a charge then, before extradition proceedings could be set in train, they would approach the Commonwealth Attorney-General to seek extradition. At present no application has been made to the Commonwealth Attorney-General by any Australian prosecuting agency to seek the extradition of Mr Michael Hand from the United States of America. So that is the situation as far as the Commonwealth Attorney-General is concerned. He is not in receipt of any request concerning the possible extradition of Mr Hand.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Would it not be unreasonable for the Australian public to construe this as utter indifference on the part of both the Government and the responsible authorities of this country concerning the legality of bank practices in Australia?

—The fact is that there has not been indifference. There was a joint New South Wales-Australian Federal Police (AFP) task force which originally investigated matters to do with the Nugan Hand Bank. The carriage of that investigation and all the material it had was handed over to Mr Justice Stewart when he conducted his royal commission into the Nugan Hand Bank. I am informed by the AFP that it has no outstanding matters against Mr Hand. The only interest that Australian police have in Mr Hand is an outstanding New South Wales police warrant for Mr Hand's arrest for allegedly wilfully making a false statement on oath and knowing that the statement was false. That is the extent of the situation, as I understand it. The key, as far as the Commonwealth Attorney-General is concerned, is that he can only act on a request from a prosecuting or a charging authority and that request has not been received.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Jack Evans, from Western Australia. On behalf of all senators I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It relates to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) re-entering the Australian wool market this week and also to the inquiries from China. I ask: can the Minister advise what effects this will have on the recent wool crisis? Under these arrangements is the USSR able to obtain credit to buy Australian wool? What are the ramifications for the Australian economy if the USSR delays or defaults on the payments for wool purchases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that I had an indication that a question of this nature might come up.

—It is an important question and I am sure that Senator Boswell is interested in it. I have a response here from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. To answer the first part of the question, the problems of the Australian industry are, of course, deep-seated and will take several years to resolve. However, the Government is heartened by the re-entry of both China and the USSR to the Australian market. We understand that since the market reopened on 25 February this year the Chinese have, once again, become significant buyers, purchasing around 10,000 tonnes of products so far.

ANSWER.PARA: The USSR has paid virtually all the money owing from its shipped product. Letters of credit approaching $A50m have been opened by the Soviet authorities for a product which was contracted for prior to the closure of the market but not shipped. The filling of these contracts was probably prompted by the re-entry of the USSR into the market. Top officials from the Soviet wool importing agency Novo Export will be in Australia next week for discussions with the Australian traders. They will address any outstanding issues relating to unshipped product and discuss arrangements for commencement of new business. The credit arrangements established with the Soviets following Mr Kerin's visit to the USSR last November are available for use in respect of contracts for unshipped product and for new business.

Since the market reopened, the Australian Government has been pleased with the response of our wool customers to the suspension of the reserve price scheme, evidenced by the steady improvement in the market indicator and the higher level of clearances to date. The market indicator currently stands at 462c per kilo. The return of the USSR to the market will provide a further boost to market confidence in the post-Easter period, which is traditionally a quiet period in the year's trading.

I now turn to the second part of the question. Under the credit arrangements in place for the USSR, all purchases of wool, both for unshipped products and new contracts, are eligible for credit. The details of any contract are determined through commercial negotiations between the contracting parties, and finance is available through normal commercial channels. The Soviet Bank of Foreign Economic Affairs issues letters of credit and guarantees payment on behalf of the Soviet Government. Contracts can be up to 240 days and the Commonwealth, through the Export Finance Insurance Corporation, provides a further payment guarantee. At this stage Novo Export is the single importing agency for wool in the Soviet Union.

Lastly, should the USSR default or delay payment beyond the 240 days that are available under the credit arrangements, there is provision for the suspension of its facility. If payments are not made within four months of the due date the Commonwealth is liable for payment on the unpaid contracts. This does not preclude the possibility that the money would be recouped by the Commonwealth when the USSR was in a position to make the payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to today's disastrous unemployment figures which show that a further 38,800 Australians were consigned to the economic scrap heap during March. In view of the fact that the national unemployment rate has now exceeded 9 per cent, and in two States is already in excess of 10 per cent, does the Minister stand by the categorical assurance given by the Prime Minister on 4 December last that, `Unemployment will not reach double digits'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say one or two things about today's unemployment statistics in the context of the question which I have been asked. At the time of the industry statement the Prime Minister did say that, as at 12 March, the recession was steeper and more extended than anticipated. In a sense, the 9.2 per cent figure confirms that view. The Government regrets very much the pain and difficulty which the recession is causing in the community. But, as was argued here on a number of occasions in 1989 and in early 1990, the Government had little alternative but to slow down an over-heated economy, and there was little dissent about that view in the community and particularly in the Opposition.
—That is incorrect. We were complaining about the interest rates and the other problems that were occurring.

—It is absolutely correct. No alternative was offered by the Opposition. Let us look at the alternative offered as of today by the Opposition. Anybody who has been nine months unemployed knows what would happen to him under Opposition policy. Opposition senators know that and everybody out there ought to know that. In answer to a question about what it would mean for those people, Dr Hewson said that they would be left to their own resources. That is what the Opposition is on record as saying about this matter.
—You engineered the recession.

—My remarks seem to have caused a bit of active employment on the part of the Opposition. The fact of the matter is that the sharp deterioration in the economy has led-and we have debated the issue in here often enough-to a progressive change in economy policy settings. Monetary policy has been loosened considerably over the last year or so and official rates are now down by 6.5 per cent. Tax cuts have been provided. Labour market conditions, of course, generally lag behind economic activity, so conditions may continue to deteriorate over the coming months. The Prime Minister and other Ministers have said that over the recent period.

ANSWER.PARA: I might make the observation in the context of this question that in the 1982 recession--

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again.

—I have been asked about the 10 per cent figure. The unemployment rate of 9.2 per cent now compares with a peak of 10.3 per cent in the 1982-83 recession, and the unemployment rate stayed above 10 per cent for eight months during that recession.
—Don't hold your breath.

— I thank Senator Hill very much. He can see how we go, and if he can remember in 10 months time, maybe he will have a question he will want to ask me. I do not think so, which is the point that I wanted to make.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said, labour market conditions lag behind other indicators. I want to make the point that leading indicators and anecdotal evidence about current market conditions give some ground for improved prospects towards the end of this year. I do not want to make too much of, for example, the Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, don't say it.

—I said I do not want to make too much of it, but it is worthwhile noticing in that survey, which was published today, a modest rise in the leading indicator. This coincides with some evidence of improving business confidence which I, personally, have gleaned from many discussions with business people in recent times. One cannot rule out a higher unemployment figure, but I confidently predict that it will be unlikely to happen in the same order that it did in the previous recession.

—I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister well knows, my question did not ask for any historical analogies. I simply asked whether the Prime Minister's statement of 4 December is no longer operative and, if the Minister now takes the view that one cannot rule out anything, could he please explain the basis on which the Prime Minister gave such an unequivocal assurance so recently, and whether it was for anything other than a cynical desire to mislead for short term political gain?

—I have already answered that question in the last part of my answer to Senator Alston's main question. As usual, whether it is by interjection or supplementary question, Senator Alston approaches these problems in a very vocal way.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to figures recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in its publication Industrial Disputes, Australia, December 1990 in relation to days lost because of industrial disputes in 1990. Do these figures show that Tasmania and Queensland, with Labor governments, have by far the best performances in Australia? Do they also show that New South Wales, the only Australian State without a Labor government, has the worst performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Australian Bureau of Statistics published figures for the month of December of the incidence of industrial disputes in Australia. They show that for the calender year 1990 the level of industrial disputes in Australia is still among the lowest levels ever recorded by the ABS--
—What do you expect in a recession?

—I will answer that interjection because it is germane to the question. The question about industrial disputes is not that the market in a recession holds down the level of disputes; the question is also about how in the recovery-which this economy will go through in the latter part of this year and next year-the level of industrial disputes remains locked down and moderate wage outcomes are achieved. That is the vital element which has to be considered-not the short term political point which the Opposition wishes to make, but how it is intended to manage this economy in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go back to the record. The measure of working days lost per thousand employees-the incidence of industrial disputes-is virtually off the bottom of the graph now. It is 216 per 1,000 employees, which is still 62 per cent below the level of industrial disputes in the Fraser period. Tasmania had 67 disputes per 1,000 employees and Queensland 102 per thousand employees. Those States are the best performers in Australia. New South Wales had 280 disputes per thousand employees, which is above the national average. The size of the population in that State distorts the national average upwards. The figure shows that New South Wales has the worst record of any Australian State in industrial disputes. Yes, it is true that New South Wales is a Liberal governed State and that Queensland and Tasmania are governed by the Australian Labor Party.

An analysis of the industrial dispute figures shows two quite significant points that need to be brought out. The level of industrial disputes in Australia now continues to be well below the level of industrial disputes in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. As well as that, on analysis the figures show that the nature of industrial disputes, the cause of them, has now significantly changed.

In the past, about 50 per cent of disputes were over wages and working conditions and about 18 per cent were over managerial matters. Now we find that 11 per cent of the industrial disputes in Australia are over wages and 75 per cent are over managerial questions. Lest anyone thinks that that is an attack upon management, might I say that it is an indication of the focus of industrial activity. It is not under an accord about wages any longer; it is about reorganising work in the workplace, achieving the flexibilities of award restructuring, achieving the flexibilities created by workplace reform and ensuring that the workplace is made more efficient. There is never any silver lining in industrial dispute figures, but that shift in cause is a significant shift that shows that we are now grappling industrially with the problems of making the workplace more effective.

I conclude by going back to the fact that the level of industrial disputes in Australia is now significantly below the level of industrial disputes in OECD countries. On a comparison of the Hawke period with the Fraser period, the dispute level is now down by 62 per cent. On a comparison of the Hawke period with the Thatcher period in Britain, our dispute level is 30 per cent below that of Britain. The OECD average during the Hawke period of government was 270 working days lost per thousand days; our figure for the whole of the period is 250 working days lost per 1,000. Australia has a celebrated index, one with which we are belaboured constantly from the Opposition, and frequently a wrong picture is painted in the minds of our trading partners. Australia is an industrial quiescent country compared to the average OECD country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to a question asked of him yesterday concerning his visit to Ireland and discussions with Ambassador Burke. I further refer the Minister to a question asked of the Prime Minister yesterday concerning a fishing trip held in 1987, also attended by the Minister and Mr Laurie Connell. Was the Minister aware that Mr Connell was to be a member of the fishing party before the trip, or was he as surprised at his presence as the Prime Minister has indicated he was?
—Order! I am not sure that this is an area within the Minister's portfolio responsibility, but if the Minister wishes to answer it I will let him.

—I am happy to answer that question, Mr President. The fishing trip in 1987 was one of a regular series that has been held over the last few years. When that trip occurred, I was shown a list of those who would be attending. I cannot recall exactly how many were on that list; I think there were about 10. Mr Connell's name was not on that list. However, I discovered on the day that I was departing for Western Australia that it was. I think that was the same day the Prime Minister was leaving, so he would not have known about that at all. My notice of the fact that Mr Connell was coming was given a matter of some hours before I left for Western Australia.
—Who asked Laurie?
—Mr Connell basically asked himself.

—Do Opposition members want to hear the answer or do they want to talk over it? At the time, one of the 10 who was attending was working for a company that Mr Connell had an interest in and had obviously told him that the trip was on. So Mr Connell rang the person who was organising the trip, got himself included-there is nothing untoward or wrong about that-and we went fishing for three days.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can he inform the Senate of proposed discounts being offered by both Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd on Anzac Day this year?
—I have good news. I have been advised by Telecom that over the Anzac holiday--
—Did it ring you?

—Yes, Telecom rang me. Over the Anzac holiday Telecom will discount the cost of STD calls by up to 60 per cent. The discount rate will apply to calls made between 10 p.m. on Wednesday, 24 April and 8 a.m. on Friday, 26 April. OTC will discount the cost of IDD calls to New Zealand by around 30 per cent. The discount rate will apply to calls made between 10 p.m. on Wednesday, 24 April and 7 a.m. on Friday, 26 April. The Anzac Day promotions by Telecom and OTC will provide significant savings for thousands of Australians and Australian-based New Zealanders who like to make personal contact by telephone with relatives and friends over this period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I ask whether it is a fact that his Government introduced in 1985 a Bill entitled the Australian Bill of Rights which sought, by article 8 of clause 8, to protect freedom of expression in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Every person has the right to freedom of expression, including the freedom of the press and other media of communication, and the freedom to seek, receive and impart ideas or information of any kind in any form, without interference and regardless of frontiers.
How does he now justify seeking to abolish the freedom to impart political ideas through the electronic media in the form of paid advertisements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone put out a press statement yesterday. The not-so-rhetorical question at the start was, `Does Nick Bolkus think we are stupid?'. I think she has just answered that question. Two very clear points need to be understood and they are two that Senator Vanstone refuses to accept or contemplate in any way. Firstly, what we are talking about in terms of banning political advertising is not free speech; we are talking of bought speech. We are talking of speech that costs in some instances $13,000 a minute to exercise and which, in its exercise, is inherently undemocratic. That is the real problem that we face in this issue. We do not expect the Opposition to understand this, because the Opposition, at all turns over the last seven or eight years, has refused to accept any proposal from this side of Parliament or from the Australian Democrats that would in any way reduce the impact of the cost of campaigning, would ensure full and adequate disclosure and would lead to an open, transparent system of campaigning.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vanstone's question is based on the contention that we are infringing upon free speech. As I say, it is not free speech; it is bought speech. The level of one's participation in our community depends on the size of one's bank account. Let me just quote one conservative politician from the United States. His point is quite telling. It is a point that very much goes to the basic premise of the Government's position, that is, that our process is leading to a much more democratic, level playing field. Senator Barry Goldwater of the US Senate-no friend of mine and never has been-in respect to the costs of campaigning, which is very much an integral part of the Government's motivation, said:
It's not . . . the people . . . but moneyed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day.

When we have that sort of recognition by a conservative politician in the United States and when we also have the fact that the cost of advertising is such that most of the community is denied access to the process, what the Government is doing in no way impinges upon freedom of speech.

Let me just make one point. This particular contention comes from the Opposition. Let us look at its record in terms of the area of civil liberties, of human rights, and whatever. It has opposed, at every turn in this Parliament, any attempt by this Government to enshrine in legislation or to enshrine in our Constitution a charter of rights for the Australian people. Regardless of whether it has been anything as innocuous as freedom of religion, trial by jury or fair compensation-nothing controversial in terms of the community-the Opposition has opposed it. It really strikes very much at the Opposition's credibility and highlights its hypocrisy where, out of this particular issue, it is trying to make itself out as the defender of civil liberties and freedom.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is silence over there.

—Of course the Opposition is silent because its record is stark and clear. It has opposed civil liberties at every turn through campaigns such as this one based on imagination, based on mistruths and based on misrepresentation. In conclusion, the Opposition's record stands for itself. Opposition members are failures. They are no defenders of civil liberties. On this side we recognise the inherent dangers in the political process and we are doing something about it to ensure that people in this community live under the basic system that protects their rights and their role in the community, that is, one person, one vote and one vote, one value-something that the Opposition has never respected and does not want to know about.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister referred to the well-known fact that these parties have disagreed in the past on the best--
—Ask the question. What is the question?

—The Minister referred to the well-known fact that the parties in this chamber have disagreed in the past about the way to protect civil and political rights but the parties have not disagreed about the existence and importance of the right and freedom of expression. The question that the Minister was asked--
—You are debating the issue. Ask the question.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.

—The question which the Minister has not answered is: how does the Government now justify walking away from its previous commitment to maintain the right to freedom of speech and does Senator Bolkus, his Party and his Government believe that a proper definition of free speech is speech--
—Give us a definition.

—I will give it-any speech other than that which is paid for. Is that the Minister's view? Is that what free speech means-any speech not delivered through a paid medium? Is that the Minister's view? Does the Minister understand the question?
—No! No chance! No-one would understand it.
—Mr President, if the Minister understands the question I am happy to sit down; if not, I am happy to restate it for him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just keep on reflecting on that press statement that went out yesterday, `Does Nick Bolkus think we are stupid?'. I do not have to think at all; the evidence has been produced to us this afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to this repetition of the earlier question-a rather incoherent one at that-I shall make just two points. I made the point that we are not talking about free speech; we are talking about bought speech. If this is so important to Senator Vanstone, let me refer her to the comments of Mr Phillip Adams, a political commentator, which are worth reading, and then I will refer her to someone else. I will not read out the whole article; I will just read the last paragraph:
In getting rid of electronic advertising, we're not jeopardising free speech but defending it. We're eliminating one of its enemies.
If Senator Vanstone is not satisfied with what Phillip Adams says, let me read out two other lines:

We reject as absurd the assertion that political advertising is a social good. We have seen no convincing evidence of any co-relation between election results and either the quality or quantity of political advertising on electronic media.

Where do those comments come from? They come from the Opposition's own representatives on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Senator Short being one of those representatives. I do not need to quote Phillip Adams; I can quote Opposition members themselves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services, who I understand is the appropriate Minister. How much has the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody cost the Federal Government to date; what is the estimated total cost; and are liabilities still being incurred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government regards this Royal Commission as an extremely important manifestation of the principle that justice not only must be done but also must be seen to be done.
—Answer the question.

—Senator Panizza will get the answer. I am giving the answer in the way that I want. As Senator Walsh would be aware, the reports of the Royal Commission tabled to date have identified a wide range of unsatisfactory practices adopted in relation to the confinement of Aboriginal people in custody. Implementation of some of the measures recommended in the Royal Commission's interim report have already led to the prevention of the deaths of several Aboriginal people in police or prison custody.
—How much?
—Just hang on. I would expect that the Royal Commission's final report, dealing as it will with the causes underlying the deaths of Aboriginal people in custody, will be no less important a document.

—The Opposition claims some interest in people and their lives, yet it is not prepared to listen to an answer about something that is most basic in life-that is, the life and death of Aboriginal people.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—The total expenditure from the Administration Services portfolio for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is $32.5m. This is made up of running costs of $25.9m, financial assistance of $5.9m, and $0.7m for the instructing solicitors. In the Additional Estimates, $150,000 for running costs, $380,000 for financial assistance and $90,000 for instructing solicitors will be sought. These figures are included in the total expenditure figures.

ANSWER.PARA: No commissioners are now being paid and the final report is with the printer. The remaining staff of the Royal Commission are winding the inquiry down. With regard to that part of Senator Walsh's question directed at the spending of other portfolios on the Royal Commission, I suggest he direct his question to the relevant Ministers or place it on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has claimed on numerous occasions that his proposed complete ban on political advertising in the electronic media will cut election costs. How can the Minister justify that claim when there is no limit on other forms of campaign expenditure such as direct mail and the print media?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for his question. At least it is not full of the emotive rhetoric that comes from other Opposition senators. If one looks at the cost of campaigning historically and focuses on some of the major increases in the costs of campaigning, as the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters did a couple of years ago, one would see that, for instance in terms of broadcasting, over the six years from 1984 to 1990 there was an increase in broadcasting costs from $6m in 1984 to $17.5m in 1990. In anyone's terms, that is an explosion in the costs of campaigning. The Government in its approach has tackled these costs and, as a consequence, has targeted this area where there have been explosive cost increases as one that can be appropriately readdressed and in a way, as I have always said, that enhances the democratic system.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Calvert referred to the question of printing and direct mail. Our disclosure legislation will have a direct impact on the level of funds available to Opposition and Government parties. I am sure that the two major parties will be affected by that. With the impact of disclosure provisions, and the fact that saturation level would be reached very quickly if one went through print media advertising or direct mail-only so many letters can be sent to electors, both during an election period and at any time during the three-year term of government-a natural level of campaign expenditure would be reached in those two areas.

If one compares the national level that would be reached with an explosion in broadcasting costs in this country and also considers the way broadcasting costs have increased internationally, particularly in the United States--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—If one looked at the costs of campaigning in the US and the costs of electronic campaigning, one would see very clearly why we have targeted this area and not others. In the US, for instance, members of Congress spend something like three-quarters of their time raising funds for campaigning purposes. We do not want the Australian system to reach that level.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I remind the Minister of a commitment he made while he held his previous responsibilities as Minister for the Environment. That commitment was to initiate an environmental impact study (EIS) into forestry operations in the Buckland training area in Tasmania. Such a study was felt to be necessary to answer questions such as: what activities are permissible in the Buckland training area; who will supervise such activities; what codes of practice might guide the conduct of such activities; and will those activities include such things as forestry, road building, other building and land clearing? I ask the Minister: when will this commitment to an environmental impact study, which was made in Hobart on 20 March 1990, be met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not surprise Senator Bell too much to learn that I do not remember everything I said on 20 March 1990. I doubt very much that I would have used the phrase that I would initiate an EIS on the Buckland training area because the actual power of initiation comes from the action department rather than from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT). So technically the department which would have to go to the Minister, Mrs Kelly, on this question would be the Department of Defence. Nonetheless, on the score of the Buckland training area, I am advised that arrangements have been put in place to ensure that it is used in an environmentally responsible way. As Senator Bell would be aware, the majority of the training area is Tasmanian land. It has been leased to the Commonwealth and is administered by the Department of Defence for the Army.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth-Tasmanian forestry industry agreement of November 1988 made provision for the shared use of the training area and for logging to take place under the control of the Forestry Commission of Tasmania in all but the areas being directly used by the Army. The Forestry Commission and the Army subsequently agreed that a management plan would be developed. An extensive EIS covering woodchipping and associated forestry operations across Tasmania was conducted in 1985.

I understand that the Army agreed in early 1990 that logging could occur in accordance with forestry management plans developed by the Forestry Commission, subject to an annual review and site inspection of the logging areas. I also understand that the Army is about to seek tenders for the preparation of a land management plan for the whole of the training area which would presumably build upon the forest management plan drawn up by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission.

In view of what I said earlier, that the action to initiate the kind of thing that Senator Bell wants done has to come from the Department of Defence, I will take up with the Minister, Mrs Kelly, the possibility of her raising this issue with the Minister for Defence and suggesting to him that it is an important environmental issue and that the Department of Defence should refer it to DASETT to enable an impact study to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and relates to the tragic labour force statistics which were delivered this morning at 11.30, showing near record unemployment, that the decrease in male and total seasonally adjusted employment was the largest monthly fall since the monthly survey began in 1978, and that youth unemployment in my State is over 30 per cent. Does the Minister not consider that this Senate, the people of Australia, and particularly the unemployed, deserve a fuller explanation of these figures than was given earlier today in answer to a question from the Opposition? Does he not think that we deserve some response by the Government as to the immediate action it will take to reverse this tragic situation? Will the Minister answer the questions that I have asked him over a period related to the fact that the problem and the crisis will not be overcome solely by a reliance by the Government on economic and training measures, but that action should also be taken on the social issues concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Senator Harradine means by action being taken on the social issues concerned. When he has asked me about the social issues concerned before, and he has done over a long period, the social issue with which he has been predominantly concerned is the high participation of married women in the work force. Senator Harradine, having looked at the figures in respect of unemployment today, will probably have observed that the participation rate has fallen significantly in the figures which have just been announced; otherwise the overall figure would have been worse. This point has been raised on a number of occasions and I probably cannot satisfy Senator Harradine on the question of the female participation rate because I think changed social views have emerged over the past 10 years or so. I disagree with his view that it is an economic factor as much as a changed social view which has emerged over a period of time. There is nothing I have to add on that point to what I have said previously.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the rest of Senator Harradine's question, in the statement of 12 March significant Government expenditure was announced in respect of programs which had to do with the retention of skilled employees, particularly apprentices, in the work force. I have to accept his estimate of youth unemployment in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my estimate; it is from the ABS.

—I accept the premise in Senator Harradine's question-let me put the matter that way-in relation to youth unemployment in Tasmania. I query it only because Senator Harradine said the figure was 30 per cent and somebody else on the other side said that it was higher. I did not know which statistic Senator Harradine's figure was based on.

ANSWER.PARA: Unemployment and youth unemployment have been higher in Tasmania for as long as I can remember. That is substantially associated with the fact that Tasmania does not have significant industrial employment. Sadly, many Tasmanians seem to want that situation, and that is something which cannot be resolved by the Government at a Federal level. Apart from those points which I have made, on a previous occasion in answering a question from Senator Short I have made a number of points relating to changes in Government economic policy settings which are very much related to the recession.

In terms of Senator Harradine's request, as he put it, for immediate action, I have to be frank and say that there is no immediate action which can be taken or magic wand which can be waved by a government which will cure this morning's unemployment figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. As a result of an unfair characterisation of views that I do not particularly hold, I refer the Minister to previous questions and ask him specifically for a response to those questions. Would the Minister not agree with a statement made by the Prime Minister some years ago that pressure on the labour force could be reduced by giving people wanting to leave paid work the choice to undertake socially constructive alternatives? Does he not consider that is an important matter to be considered? What more socially constructive work is there in Australia than the nurturing, care and development of one's own children? Would the Minister not agree that there is a substantial number of mothers in the paid work force; in fact, in the last 10 years the number of families with at least one child under four years of age whose parents were both in paid work has increased by 65 per cent? Would the Minister not agree that a large--
—It is a very long supplementary question, Senator Harradine.
—It is an important question and I am going to ask it.
—That is not a supplementary question.
—I am going to ask this question because it is very important.
—Do you want to stop women going into the work force?
—Order! Senator Collins!
—Do you want the Government to pass a law saying that they cannot work?
—I will answer that interjection because that is where he has been characterising--
—Order!
—I want a true freedom of choice--
—Order! Senator Harradine!
—And Senator Collins ought to withdraw and apologise over that.
—Order! Senator Harradine will resume his seat.
—I am going to ask this question--
—Resume your seat!
—because it is a tragedy. This unemployment situation is a tragedy.
—Resume your seat! Senator Harradine, I pointed out that that had been a very long supplementary question and I am asking you to conclude it.

—It is my only question this week and I am going to ask it. I want to ask the Minister whether the Government has not considered that many of these people have been forced into the paid work force against their will because of the Government's own economic policy, including its interest rates policy. When is the Government going to give a true freedom of choice to mothers who decide to stay at home to perform this socially constructive alternative?

—I think most senators in this place are concerned about the unemployed, and the Government is certainly concerned about the current unemployment situation. I would like to be able to say that we could redress the present unemployment situation by some, as I said, waving of a magic wand, but we cannot. However, I do not think that the unemployment situation will be addressed by stunts from any senator. Let me say I agree with Senator Harradine entirely, that it is a matter for socially constructive consideration whether some people are in the work force in circumstances in which they do not want to be, particularly mothers of young children. That is a socially sensible question to examine. But to come in here and pretend that in the last 10 years, or 15 years for that matter, there have not been significant changed preferences by women-married women-in relation to employment is to really pretend--
—I am not suggesting that and you know it--
—It is far from clear--
—I am suggesting that you give a fair go and stop discriminating against single income families. That is what I am saying. Stop discriminating against single income families.

—My question is to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Given that it is now some two months since I asked the Minister about the effectiveness of peak period scheduling at Kingsford-Smith Airport, can he report on the results of the Federal Airports Corporation review which was due at the end of March? Can the Minister also inform the Senate when construction of the third runway at Sydney Kingsford-Smith Airport is likely to start?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just very quickly correct one thing that Senator Brownhill said in his question. The report was not due at the end of March. The commitment that was given by the Federal Airports Corporation, which is being discharged, was that the operation of peak period pricing at Kingsford-Smith would be reviewed at the end of March; in other words, after a complete three-month period of operation. I can advise Senator Brownhill that that is in fact being done now.

ANSWER.PARA: The trial period at the end of March, of course, has expired and the statistical analysis of the effect of peak period pricing on the airport is currently being conducted by the Department. I know that Senator Brownhill has been following this question because he has discussed it with me not just in the Senate but outside the Senate on a number of occasions. I will ensure that as soon as the report is to hand he will get a copy of it, along with other interested senators.
