I stress, as I have done in the past, that the imposition of peak period pricing has been introduced at Sydney Airport as a regulator. It is not a revenue raiser; it has been introduced as a regulator. If the analysis shows that it has not succeeded as a regulator it will not be proceeded with. That is the position I have taken on this matter all along.

So far as the third runway is concerned, Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd is currently hard at work engaged in preparation of the supplement to the environmental impact statement (EIS). That will be concluded, on current estimates, by about May this year so I expect that the Government will be in a position to consider the entire matter, that is, the complete EIS with the supplement, by the end of June or July this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December and 20 February 1991 Senator Alston asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, questions relating to the taxation status of the invalid pension. These two questions were mentioned earlier today. I have an answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. It is not a very long answer but I think at this stage if Senator Alston gets it later today it will probably be all right.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Up until 1973 all social security pensions were tax exempt. The tax exemption for age pensions was withdrawn in 1973.

On 20 May 1976, the then Government announced withdrawal of the tax exemption for widows' pensions and service pensions other than those equivalent to invalid pensions, with effect from July 1976. The rationale for not also withdrawing the exemption for invalid pensions was not stated at that time. The Government has maintained the arrangements in this area put into effect in 1976.

The current cost to revenue of exempting the invalid pension is dependent on whether a rebate similar to that available to age pensioners would otherwise be made available to recipients of the invalid pension. If that was the case, the current cost to revenue of exempting such pensions is likely to be in the order of $20 million.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time Senator Loosley asked me: what response has the Government made to assist developing countries adversely affected by the Gulf war? Will additional funds be allocated to the aid program? I am now in a position to give him an answer which is in the following terms.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the effect of the Gulf war on developing countries, the Government has so far committed a total of $16.2m in aid expenditures. This includes: $11.2m channelled through the World Bank, plus $5m for emergency and refugees programs. This $16.2m has been allocated without cutting back other parts of the ongoing Australian aid program; $6.3m will come from savings from an expected repayment on our capital contributions to the World Bank due to exchange rate movements; another $3.4m is from savings due to a slower drawdown of Australia's commitments to the World Bank's normal operations; $5m has been provided from funds previously set aside for a possible contribution to an International Monetary Fund multilateral support package for Vietnam; and the balance of $1.5m has been provided through a top-up for the aid budget.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The worsening plight of the ever increasing number of victims of the Hawke Government's economic mismanagement.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —These figures released today, as I think is acknowledged on both sides of the chamber, are a disaster; not just an economic disaster but a social disaster. They are a disaster for which this Government is solely responsible. We now have that from no lesser personage than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who, in Question Time today, went as close as he could to being repentant and almost contrite. What he said was that these are simply bad figures-no getting away from that. He said that he could only regret the great hurt that is being suffered by Australians who have to bear the brunt. Then, of course, in the usual mea culpa in attempting to justify this Government's disastrous economic mismanagement, he went on to say that, of course, they were an inevitable consequence of the transition to a higher saving, more productive, lower current account deficit and lower inflation economy.
—That is rubbish.

—Putting aside that sort of rubbish-as Senator Chapman rightly characterises it-what we have is a damning admission from the Treasurer himself that not only were these figures beyond anyone's wildest contemplation but also they are seriously hurting. I think even Senator Richardson, who occasionally applies himself to social security issues, is acutely aware of that fact.
—A bit more often and effectively than you.

—I am sorry that Senator Richardson had to spend most of Question Time yesterday answering a dorothy dixer. He claims that he does not do that in this chamber, but he has had about three in the last two months. Yesterday's question came about in an attempt to try to patch up the inadequacy of an answer that he had given me to a question on notice. If he cannot do any better than that, I suggest that he stay home instead of tripping off. He should get his feet out of the bucket of champagne and stay home instead of wandering off.
—I have not had a drink for four weeks; I'm on the wagon.
—We will see what happens when Senator Richardson gets to the fleshpots of Europe.
—Order! I think comments should go through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. There is no doubt that even the likes of Senator Richardson ought to have their priorities right. He ought to cancel the feet in the bucket of champagne trip to Europe and stay home and do something about the disastrous social consequences of this Government's economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is now quite clear to everyone that this will not be a short term recession. Indeed, figures released last night suggest that some of the major industry groups in this country are on the verge of a total loss of confidence. I think that is probably one of the most cynical aspects of the Government's response. On the one hand, we get this genuflection towards compassion-the suggestion that somehow it is unfortunate but nonetheless inevitable; but, wait, hope is around the corner-and, on the other hand, we get these cynical suggestions that things are not as bad as they could be. Even Senator Button got into this mode yesterday when he suggested that we had seen the worst. Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told Caucus yesterday that, `There is further evidence that we are moving in the right direction'. This is, yet again, more cynical, misleading political pap which is designed to mislead the unwary and the very people who are the victims of these circumstances which have been created by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another big lie.

—Yes, a big lie; a series of small lies amounting to a consistent eight-year lie that somehow this Government knew what it was doing when it was elected in 1983. I can remember how we used to get bagged for having the temerity to suggest that somehow what had happened three or four years back was the fault of the Whitlam Government. But now here we are eight years down the track and we cannot find a Minister who does not start off speeches by-the knee-jerk response-comparing current circumstances with what might have happened in the early 1980s. I think the Australian public understands that that is a pretty desperate and bankrupt response to a circumstance which is entirely of the Government's own making. It is no use trying to kill the messenger.

SPEECH.PARA: Syntec Economic Services said yesterday that an industry survey has warned of another 100,000 job losses and unemployment figures topping 10 per cent. Syntec is respected on all sides as an objective economic commentator and it rejects clearly and emphatically the Government's increasingly optimistic view about economic recovery. I do not share the view of those who say that the response ought simply to be to throw more cash at a whole series of targets because, in many respects, that can perpetuate the problem. For example, if we were simply to ratchet up the list of welfare benefits we would have them locked into place even when the economic recovery arrived. I do not think that is the solution, but I do find it disappointing in the extreme that this Government's short term emergency response has been so pitifully inadequate.

Senator Richardson, with all his renowned or reputed political skills, ought to be aware of the opportunities which exist to achieve some recognition and appreciation from the voluntary agencies which do so much wonderful work in this country. They are the ones that are best placed to assess the effect of the current crisis and the impact that it has on the people who come through their doors. Yet all this Government has done to date is give out something like $7.6m in the Budget and another $2m recently. That is pitifully inadequate, demonstrated by the response of the agencies themselves. The Brotherhood of St Laurence put out a press release yesterday in the name of its new Executive Director, Bishop Michael Challen. Bishop Challen said:
The social cost of family breadwinners losing their jobs is enormous-and the safety net the Federal Government provides, the social security system, needs to heed the lessons of this recession.
He went on to point out what I think are very valid facts. They show that even the Brotherhood itself has had to turn away 577 people asking for help-mostly material aid-since January of this year.

I think it is not overstating the case to say that the Brotherhood is recognised throughout Australia as an agency that is very well placed and very well regarded by its clientele, and it would be much better suited to the distribution of assistance. Yet this Government has not seen fit to respond other than by making available a miserable $2m some months after the need first arose. The press release continued as follows:

In the first three months of this year the Brotherhood's two material aid services in Fitzroy and Frankston have given clothing and furniture to 4,809 people in need. ``Our supplies are limited and we cannot keep up with the growing demand'', Bishop Challen said.

Bishop Challen makes the very important point that it is one or the other. On the one hand, general assistance is provided through the welfare system so that the levels of rent assistance, unemployment benefit, sole parent pensions and the like are increased. That is basically the Australian Democrats' approach to life. It is a very expensive approach. It is not particularly targeted, and it would set in place a regime that I do not think would be of assistance in the longer term.

The stark alternative that Bishop Challen identifies is that if that is not going to be done-if across-the-board assistance is not going to be given-at the very least, assistance ought to be given to those people whose need is dramatic, to the point where they are actually going into voluntary agencies and asking for assistance. Yet this Government is choosing to deliberately send away those people empty handed. There can be no other explanation for the fact that this Government has refused to heed the requests and the pleas for help from a range of voluntary agencies whose reputations are beyond repute. If the Government can explain to me why it is prepared to condone the Brotherhood having to turn away 577 people asking for help since January, I would be very interested to hear about it.

The Fairfield City Community Aid and Information Centre in Sydney reports that it is in a severe cash crisis even after receiving its share of the extra $2m. The Sydney Morning Herald of 12 March reported that for the first time in the five-year life of the Sydney City Mission's Campbelltown centre, money for emergency relief food vouchers has run out. Indeed, staff at the mission agreed to a voluntary 10 per cent cut in salaries to put towards helping the destitute.

I am not suggesting that Senator Richardson should travel second class to Europe or stay in youth hostels while he is away, I am simply suggesting that there are very obvious ways in which emergency relief can be provided in a manner that will ensure that it goes to the people to whom it ought to be provided, in the most efficient and responsible manner, and that that can be done with complete confidence in the voluntary agencies concerned. Yet that is the response we simply do not have, and we end up with the worst of all possible worlds.

We have a government that, on the one hand, makes a fleeting reference to the social consequences, then immediately turns around and tries to paint a dishonest picture of how things will get better and how recovery is around the corner. It is like, `I will fix child poverty by 1990' or, `Interest rates will come down just after the election'-a whole series of fraudulent political promises, and this is really just another one of them. If the Government is going to make those sorts of promises why can it not at least in the short term do something tangible and give some meaningful assistance to the people who need it?

There are reports that in Sydney some Department of Social Security offices have large backlogs of people to put on the dole, and such people have to approach the Smith Family for help until the DSS finally comes up with the first payment. Bishop Challen makes that point as well.

Again, we cannot have it both ways. If there is going to be a waiting period for entitlement to benefits it ought, at least, to be recognised that even though not every one of those persons is thereby going to be disadvantaged, if some of them feel sufficiently disadvantaged-and they are probably the best judges of their own predicaments-to pay a visit to the local voluntary agency, then it should be ensured that those agencies are in a position to do something about it.

I regard them as by far the better judges. I certainly do not think the Government has the capacity to try somehow to decide from Canberra who ought to get relief or, indeed, from the nearest regional office. Voluntary agencies are by far the best placed to make those judgments, but unless this Government is prepared to come to their assistance, then it is doing nothing. It is not even offering them bread.

The industry statement allows for an increase of 15,000 to 20,000 places in the labour market training programs, yet there are now 770,000 unemployed people and 596,000 people on the dole. The dole numbers that came out today show that the increase over the past year is 52.5 per cent. As Senator Button conceded, had the participation rate not fallen in the past month, the levels of unemployment would indeed have been even higher. We know that they are in fact over the magical 10 per cent figure in two of the six States. On a national basis they are higher than were predicted by the commentators, and most would now say that things will get worse. Even Mr Keating conceded that in the almost apologetic explanation that I referred to earlier.

He said that he agreed with Mr Howard, the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, that there was no quick fix, that the situation would get worse before it got better, that there was a need to boost investment and restore confidence, and that unless we boosted our savings ratio none of these things would happen. If Mr Keating is in effect agreeing with Mr Howard that the situation will get worse before it gets better, there is a clear concession that the unemployment figure is going to exceed 10 per cent. If that is so, I think we all want to know what this Government proposes to do about the social consequences of the catastrophic economic mismanagement that has brought us to the pass.

I am not suggesting that the Government throw hundreds of millions of dollars at interest groups-which is Senator Richardson's usual response to a perceived political problem-but, unless we get a sympathetic and at the same time financially meaningful response, not only are the Government's words hollow, but its actions underline the hypocrisy of its current pretence that things are going to get better.

At a time when we have one job vacancy per every 29 unemployed people, there is very little prospect that any of the so-called initiatives announced in the last Budget will make much of a difference. The active employment strategy is virtually dead in the water before it is supposed to get off the ground on 1 July. The Government will no doubt pretend that somehow there will be jobs for most of these people, but the reality is that the bulk of the so-called active employment strategy consists of trying to entertain people, keep them amused, whilst they are sitting out of the work force indefinitely. That is not any sort of a sensible response, and again it is misleading. But at least in the short term, while these people are out of the work force, they ought to be entitled to have access to a much greater level of assistance than they are getting at present.

There are a number of statistics-particularly the youth homeless allowance figure, which has risen by 62 per cent over the past year-which underline the social significance of these current figures. I think my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Calvert in their speeches will pay particular attention to the levels of youth unemployment and the consequences for youth.

I regard it as nothing more than a cynical response for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) almost to claim credit for the increase in the youth homeless allowance figure by somehow suggesting that that reflects a higher take-up rate rather than the obvious implication that there are more people in need. I hope that we will get a much franker explanation for those figures and a better understanding of their consequences, because, unless the Government is prepared to face up to the meaning of the figures, there is not very much that it is likely to be able to do about the problem. Again we can see almost a 50 per cent increase over the last decade.

There are also statistics that are very enlightening about the proportion of married couple families in the work force with at least one dependent child. The number of families in which both spouses are employed as a percentage of the total number of families has risen from 28.6 per cent in 1980 to 42 per cent in 1990.

We can certainly say that Government members have a lot to answer for. After eight years they have no-one to blame but themselves. They clearly have no solution to the economic problems, let alone the political will to do anything about them. On the one hand, we have people like Senator Richardson acknowledging, as he has done for years, that the three-mine uranium policy is a disaster. But of course he is having it both ways. He is not prepared to get too far out in front, pretending that it is not a high item on the agenda, that he will not die in a ditch and that if it gets rolled, so what.

All those attitudes are a classic microcosm of the way in which this Government operates. It is not interested in the merits of the argument. This Government's approach is, `Who gives a damn about whether opening up additional uranium mines might lead to significant economic growth or might boost our exports'. Subject to all those safeguard issues that others might want to debate, we do not hear one word of economic analysis; it is all about what the factions will wear. That really is the response that we get on a whole range of areas that are encapsulated in the term `micro-economic reform'.

Unless we do something about those sorts of problems and unless we can reduce the cost structures of business, there is not very much prospect of the unemployed and those who are increasingly getting in the welfare queues being able to look forward to any meaningful prospect of economic recovery. The tragedy is that those who are in their 50s, quite often with a poor command of the language and perhaps in a not-so-good state of health, are the ones who will be the permanent victims. When we come out of this recession they will still be on the scrap heap. Indeed, it is almost counterproductive to be spending money on training and education programs in a vain effort somehow to try to recycle these people. So they become simply flotsam and jetsam in the swill. I hope that Senator Richardson, in his response, will tell us what he proposes to do for those people in particular, because all that we will have is longer and longer statistics and more and more people being effectively disregarded and offered no hope into the bargain. Unless one tackles the problem at its source, is prepared to look at economic growth and actually tries to do something about it rather than shutting off the short term political problems, one has nothing to offer those victims of the economic recession.

I say that on two counts the Government has a great obligation to the Australian people. It has an obligation to try to tackle the economic problems and it also has an obligation to assist in dealing with the social consequences of that economic mismanagement. To date, it has failed to do both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government will not argue that in a recession, with unemployment as great as it is now, there will not be pain felt by a considerable number of people. The purpose of a proper social security system and a proper training system for those who are unemployed is to make sure that the people who do feel that pain are caught by some safety net. The Government will be about maintaining and improving that safety net and not ripping it to shreds-which is the alternative that Senator Alston can offer.

SPEECH.PARA: When the economy was booming there was a need to dampen excess demand; no-one can deny that. The weapons available to governments, having already cut billions of dollars off government expenditure, are limited. Obviously interest rates constitute the main weapon that one can use in that situation. But, given the signs that were becoming evident of a slowdown in the economy, the Government moved to reduce interest rates, which have gone down by a total of 6 percentage points over the course of the last year, with a further half point reduction last week. Further to that, the wage-tax deal with the trade union movement in the wake of the September consumer price index figures, which has helped make certain that lower inflation is here to stay, has provided relief to employers in a deteriorating labour market and has created a timely increase in the fiscal stimulus flowing from the 1 January tax cuts.

The Government is confident that these measures, combined with the cyclical developments in the economy, will see a pick-up in activity later this calendar year. To back that up from independent sources, today an interesting piece of news has come from the Westpac-Melbourne Institute leading index. It states that for the second month in a row that index has risen. From that, Westpac has drawn the conclusion that:

Though it is still too early to say positively that the leading index is foreshadowing an upturn in the Australian economy in the latter half of 1991, the signs are promising that this message may not be far ahead.

I think that the Government can say with increasing confidence that that recovery is on the way. In the intervening period the Government must ensure that those who are affected by the recession and who are unemployed have their skills improved so that, once that upturn does occur, they can take immediate advantage of it. Not only that, but as those skills improve the skills of the Australian work force at large improve. That is of critical importance to Australia's future. I shall have more to say about the active employment strategy (AES) a little later.

The labour market itself will lag behind other indicators of a recovery as has always been the case. I see no reason to believe that that will not continue to be the case. While we cannot expect any immediate sign in the labour market of that recovery, in accordance with the leading index from Westpac, I do not doubt that that recovery is under way.
Today's matter of public importance has as its first words:
The worsening plight of the ever increasing number of victims.

Senator Alston would have us believe that he is very concerned about that worsening plight. He said that what was required-to quote from his speech-was `a sympathetic . . . financial response'. Judging by the records of Senator Alston and the Opposition over recent times, that is not what could be expected from the Opposition were it to gain the government benches.

The other Sunday, Senator Alston put out a press release saying that he would visit some Department of Social Security offices-a sign that it must have been a slow news Sunday. He told us all that he would be visiting the Parramatta, Marrickville, Redfern, Darlinghurst and Chatswood offices to see at first hand what was going on. Those at Redfern are still waiting; Senator Alston did not make it. He did send along a staffer but he himself was too busy. Earlier Senator Alston had turned up at Parramatta an hour late and his visit lasted only half an hour. At Marrickville things were a little better; he stayed for an hour. Apart from the regional manager, the area manager and a social worker he did not bother to speak to one staff member. By the time he got to Chatswood after lunch, a few other things were obviously on the senator's mind. He stayed for only 35 minutes, most of which time he spent on the phone.

I can understand why Senator Alston might have been unsettled or preoccupied on that day. He was having the classic bad day. It had begun when he was given a rather torrid time by Pru Goward on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Daybreak program. Some policy documents that Senator Alston had been working on had fallen off the back of the proverbial truck. Those documents did include some absolutely spectacular proposals. One might say that they were spectacular for their level of stupidity rather than anything else.

Let us look at some of these ways that the Opposition will fix the worsening plight of the ever-increasing number of unemployed. The Opposition will sack 370 social workers and hand over their functions to the private sector. That is the first way in which the Opposition will actually help the worsening plight of the unemployed. It will dump special assistance programs, such as the jobs, education and training program for sole parents. This too will help the unemployed. The Opposition will hand over the Department's counselling service for the disabled to particular welfare agencies, to the corporate world, to whoever might take them-whoever the Opposition can find. The Opposition will give pensioners free bus concessions-that is good; most have them already-provided they will help in all of the voluntary agencies which will apparently be able to handle this great increase in the numbers who will be offering.

Notwithstanding all that, Senator Alston is considering how he will fix the worsening plight of these people. I wonder what his comments were in response to a question on the policy documents from Pru Goward. He said:
Well, Pru, I'm not sure what proposal we're discussing . . .
The documents have been handed around all over the building, but Senator Alston does not know what documents he is discussing.
I don't know what document you are referring to and that's why I'm talking in general terms because, to date, we haven't finalised the policy in this area.

The Opposition's attempts to finalise policies in social security and health have been going on now for many years with, I might say, a spectacular record of failure on the part of those who have preceded Senator Alston, the shadow Minister for social security, and those who accompany him now. Given that Senator Alston is not in the shadow Cabinet, maybe he does not know what is going on there; maybe it is doing the job for him or doing a job on him, I am not sure. But the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has made it pretty clear how much he cares about the long term unemployed. His intentions are on record. In October 1989, Dr Hewson had this to say:
Clearly, most of the long-term unemployed will be expected to accept jobs that they would otherwise find unacceptable or live by their own means.

That is how the worsening plight of people in this recession will be helped by the Opposition. But, of course, Dr Hewson is an absolute St Augustine compared with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Reith. Mr Reith is a real special. He has the cure; it is all fixed. He says that all that is required is a $1.5 billion cut in social security.

It does not matter how one attempts to camouflage that. I give Senator Alston credit in that at least he has dropped the rather pathetic defence that there was some other additional special benefit that these people might get after Mr Reith pushed them off dole queues after nine months by saying that they could get nothing. Mr Reith has decided that if we just stop counting and helping the unemployed we will help their worsening plight. That is what people, if they are not doing well in this society, can expect from an opposition like the one we now have. It stands here today and expresses concern for the worsening plight of the unemployed while, at the same time, it is prepared absolutely as soon as it gets into government to cut them all off at the knees and make sure that anyone who has a benefit for over nine months or longer is unable to keep it.

As bad times develop cyclically, one wonders how many people today would end up receiving nothing; how many would have to live by their own means, by the Hewson-Reith-Alston trade-off. The sad fact is that hundreds of thousands of Australian families, who are by no means living on a bed or roses today, would finish up with absolutely nothing under the kind of hard line, right wing nonsense that these people preach.

That is the kind of economic scenario which Senator Alston and his colleagues have in mind for the worsening plight of the unemployed. Of course, economics is not Senator Alston's forte; I am trying to work out what is. In the same program with Pru Goward on that fateful Monday a couple of weeks ago, Senator Alston did not have a clue how much privatisation version No. 2 will cost. We do not really hear about privatisation version No. 1 any more. In that version, Mr Hewson suggested that the payment of welfare benefits could actually--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Hewson.

—Dr Hewson. I stand corrected. I thank Senator Faulkner. Dr Hewson suggested that the payment of welfare benefits could actually be privatised. He would have people racing into the marbled foyers of the offices of some of the better accountants in Australia asking for assistance. Of course, Dr Hewson and Senator Alston now claim that they never really suggested that. The laugh is that they are on record so many times doing that. In an interview in the Sunday Sun on 11 October last year, Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the most effective level for distributing welfare benefits are . . . those at the coalface.

So privatisation mark 2 is: selling off everything else except the actual payment of the benefits. I think we all are prepared to acknowledge that Maggie Thatcher is the high priestess of the government sell-off. She looked at social welfare privatisation in the same way that the Opposition is looking at it but, fortunately, around her were some more reasonable and rational beings who talked her out of doing anything more than looking at a couple of minor computer and administrative functions and selling them off. Even conservatives in Britain understood that one just cannot go further than that.

In fact, the Liberals in Australia are about the only ones who believe that that is the way to create a fair and just society into the next century and the way to ease the worsening plight of those affected by this recession. This is the free market version of welfare economics. Senator Alston clearly thinks that the forces of demand and supply can do the job that his Party wants to bale out of. He told Pru Goward:

The principle that I'm confident we'll adopt is that wherever it is possible to identify a service that is currently carried out in the public sector that we believe could be carried out just as efficiently in the private sector, then we would move in that direction.

Given that we are talking about the worsening plight of people in a recession, let us ask ourselves what people at the coalface think about this welfare rationalism. It has to be said that Merle Mitchell from the Australian Council of Social Service did not seem to be too keen. On the same day she said to Pru Goward:

I think it would be impossible Pru. To start off with, social security needs its social workers to deal with the crises that come through the door . . . they need to be there on the spot . . . they must stay . . . they're desperately needed.

Merle Mitchell pointed out how ludicrous it was to expect pensioners to help out on a part time or volunteer basis. She pointed out that counselling and training programs to help people back into the work force require staff with a high level of training, skill and knowledge. She stated:
We certainly couldn't do it with volunteers . . . it must be done with people who have training and experience.

All this exposes the kind of lunacy and humbug that the Opposition comes up with when it says it cares about the victims of economic mismanagement and their worsening plight. All that has been demonstrated today and in the repeated statements by Senator Alston, Dr Hewson and Mr Reith is that they have absolutely no care, no concern, for those who are going to rely on government welfare.

Honourable senators opposite probably have not noticed that our social security system has been changing in recent years to try to do an even better job. We have attempted to better target some of our programs to minimise fraud. Most importantly-I said that I would refer to the active employment strategy-we have tried to do something about giving people a hope for the future by improving their skills and training. I want to quote Senator Alston again, although I am not trying to take Hansard's job. He said that the AES was dead in the water before 1 July and, in any event, all it was doing was `trying to entertain them, to keep them amused'.

I would have thought that trying to improve the skills of the Australian work force and trying to give those who are unemployed now more skills so they can take the first available opportunity to get a job when the recession is over was not just the duty of a government wanting to look after the worsening plight of those affected by a recession. It is something that all of us need to happen for the future of Australia.

The kinds of productivity gains that we need to get in Australia over the next few years or decades will not come without a much better skilled work force. While we have had remarkable success during the eight years in government in improving retention rates in schools and improving the skills of school leavers, for those who are already in the work force there will not be any other way than an active employment strategy.

I must say that I was most concerned to hear Senator Alston speak in the way that he did today about that strategy. It will not matter which party is in government. If that strategy is not kept on and is not continually improved and updated, as it was in the industry statement of only a few weeks ago, I wonder what kind of future Australia can have. It behoves every one of us-it does not matter which political party we are in-to make sure that the skills of the work force are honed and improved. That means that for those who are unemployed, who are seeking entry to the work force, there is an even bigger job to be done.

When one looks at the actual payments themselves-not just the level of benefits, but the package that goes with them-one sees that there have been some remarkable improvements during the last eight years. Let us take rent assistance being extended to unemployment beneficiaries who are in private accommodation. The rates of rent assistance have been increased enormously in real terms over recent years-by 139 per cent for families with three or more children; 109 per cent for families with one to two children; and 79 per cent for people without them.

These are very big real increases, way in excess of inflation in the past three years. They are the kinds of things that demonstrate a commitment to wanting to ease the worsening plight of these people. I would not pretend for a second that what we have done in that respect and with a whole range of other programs has finished the job, but I am absolutely certain that the job is well and truly under way. I noticed another reference to youth homelessness from Senator Alston, who said that I had been claiming credit for the increase in the numbers yet it was really a reflection of the fact that more and more children were leaving home. I have taken the time to go out and meet homeless kids on their ground during the past few weeks with the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other welfare agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of them to meet.

—That is right. I have tried to talk to them to find out what they think is wrong with the system, why they are in their present situation and what can be done for them. As one sits down and talks to kids who, even at the age of 15, have been on the streets for three or four years, one has to understand that these kids came onto the streets during times of economic boom. They did not go on the street yesterday, although kids are going on the street all the time. There is a massive social problem here. The States are walking away from it. The State ward system has virtually broken down in every State in Australia. There is no supervision, no help for these kids in that system.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be the Commonwealth's job to work with the States to help the lot of those kids. The very first step has to be to make sure that as many of them as we can get onto the youth homelessness allowance. That is what we have to do. We have to increase the numbers who are on the allowance because, with 4,000-odd on the allowance now, we are barely scratching the surface. I do not think that in the next few moments we can establish how many kids there are, but there are many, far too many. Unless we do something for them, unless we fix up their worsening plight, we are walking away from one of our worst social problems. That is all far too serious to be dealt with in a trite manner by talking about the worsening plight of the unemployed while seeking to cut hundreds of thousands of Australian families off all benefits just because they have been unemployed for nine months. That is what the Opposition offers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are discussing in this chamber, on the initiative of the Opposition, the consequences for ordinary Australians of this Government's economic policies and, in turn, the effect of its social policies. Once again I say that, while there certainly is no doubt that ordinary Australians are really suffering during this recession, we have to look at the Opposition's policies. Once again I stress, particularly after listening to Senator Alston's selective quotations from the Brotherhood of St Laurence material, which was available yesterday and from which I will quote extensively later, that the Opposition does not have anything better to offer by way of social policies. In fact, the majority of Australian families who are now being hit hard would be hit just as hard under the Opposition's policies, and indeed are being hit hard now because the Opposition supported those very policies as they went through this place. Opposition members have been accomplices of this Government because of their failure to oppose many of the social security measures which have caused further suffering to those Australians who are already bearing the brunt of this recession.

SPEECH.PARA: In my relatively short time in this chamber, I have seen the Opposition support the Government on a range of measures that have all undoubtedly contributed to the worsening plight of the ever-increasing number of victims of this recession. Australians suffering as a consequence of this recession should ask, `What has the Opposition been doing?', as through this place we saw the increasing waiting times for young unemployed people trying to access any sort of benefit. What did the Opposition do when the assets test on the family allowance supplement for farmers was put before this chamber and, indeed, could have been removed? What has the Opposition done specifically on policies for young homeless people? Where is the benefit to low income families and rural Australian families in policies that call for the total deregulation and privatisation of our transport, health, financial and communication systems? Where is the benefit to them in being cut off unemployment benefits, as Senator Richardson has highlighted, after nine months? Where is the benefit in an across-the-board flat rate consumption tax that taxes the necessities of life at the same rate as luxury goods? Certainly, I see no benefit at all to low income Australians in the massive cuts in public expenditure that the Opposition has proposed. However, I do not want to spend any more time on that matter because I do not want to let the Government off the hook for what is a major social problem. Yet, as Senator Richardson highlighted, there have been a number of promising and positive steps taken by the Government. Unfortunately, while some small benefits have increased for those in need, poverty has also increased, and dramatically. What good steps the Government has taken have been far outweighed by the hurdles and difficulties put in place so that people have greater and greater problems accessing any form of support. The Government should be deeply ashamed of the effects of its economic policies on those people who, generation after generation, have always given the Australian Labor Party their support on the understanding that it would protect the interests of ordinary Australian workers. But I must add that those who are disillusioned with the Government's policies should not expect the Opposition parties to rally to their cause.

I turn now to the unemployment figures that we are specifically discussing today. These are certainly damning figures which graphically illustrate the suffering of ordinary Australians under the Labor Government. Let us start to acknowledge that we are talking about people, real people, not just numbers on pieces of paper. We are talking about people who desperately want to find work but are not able to do so. Too often the term `unemployed' is bandied about and we forget that we are talking about Australians, workers who are out of the paid work force. Some 770,100 people are now unemployed-that is 9.2 per cent-the highest figure since April 1984. Australia has just had its worst one-month job losses since the Australian Bureau of Statistics started collecting these figures in 1978. This country lost 82,400 jobs in March, and that is the worst figure for 13 years.

These figures should shatter once and for all the notion that unemployed people do not really want to work, that they are having a good time going to the beach and watching television. They desperately want to work. Hundreds and hundreds of people across this country are applying for average skill jobs and low skill jobs. Yet unfortunately we still have an Opposition that talks about getting rid of unemployment benefits after nine months. A total of 596,890 people are on unemployment benefits, so we certainly have exceeded the Government's estimate in the Budget of 475,000. These figures need little elaboration; they speak for themselves of the great hardship being experienced by a substantial section of the community, particularly the half a million families who are now directly affected by unemployment. This gives added weight to the Australian Council of Social Service predictions that by the middle of 1991 we would have a million Australians, including a quarter of a million children, dependent on unemployment benefits.

I wish to look now at two particularly alarming statistics that were released today. First, 43,600 people, the vast majority of whom-over 30,000-are women, have given up looking for work altogether. In other words, they are now falling off the statistics. They are not on unemployment benefits; they have simply given up. They have been unsuccessful time and time again. They have seen no advertisements for jobs that they could possibly apply for.

As I have pointed out in this chamber before, the official unemployment figures fail to acknowledge the growing number of hidden unemployed-people who cannot access the paid work force. Here we have 43,000 people who by and large now will be overlooked by this Government in terms of any support services. A further example of the hidden unemployment is the fact that Australia has a growing number of underemployed. I wish to quote from an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of yesterday entitled `Part time workers seeking lift in hours', written by Shane Rodgers. In his article he said:

The Australian Bureau of Statistics said yesterday that there were 383,200 part-time workers in February who wanted to work more hours. Of those 144,700 were actively looking for full-time work. The number who preferred to work more hours was up 30,000 in January and was nearly 100,000 higher than 12 months ago.

Again, what despair and suffering are behind these figures? What will be the ultimate economic and social cost to this country of the failure to keep these people active in the labour force, in jobs that they find rewarding?

Secondly, I wish to look at the teenage unemployment figures. These jumped 3.1 per cent in March to a staggering 25.8 per cent of our young people. That compares with 16.1 per cent a year ago. The jump is largely due to the fact that these young people have had to wait several months before they can access any support at all, but that is the figure. One quarter of our teenagers who want to work cannot get a job. Since the cutbacks I mentioned earlier in income support for young people-supported again, I stress, by the Opposition-we can safely assume that the vast majority of these young people who cannot find work are living in poverty. What an indictment of this Government! So much for caring for young people as one of our most precious assets.

As if that is not enough, the Government continues to make it harder and harder for young people who want to stay in education to access Austudy. In South Australia dozens and dozens, in fact hundreds of young people and older people are giving up altogether the idea of continuing with their education as they have longer and longer to wait before they can access any Austudy support.

I should like here to look specifically at what is happening in rural Australia. There are proportionally more low income families with children in rural Australia than in our cities. This was identified in several surveys, including one done in Victoria last year. To verify this we can look at recent statistics on the availability of the family allowance supplement (FAS), and in particular at those that show how many children in this country are able to benefit from the family allowance supplement payments. In South Australia, if we look at rural electorates, of which there are four, on average there are 4700 children in receipt of FAS. However, in city electorates in Adelaide, it is only half that figure, at around 2300.

The same story applies in Queensland: 5800-odd on average receiving FAS in rural Queensland compared with 2700-plus in urban areas. It goes on State to State-Victoria: rural, 4000-plus; urban, 1800 approximately. Over to Western Australia: rural, 4500-plus; urban, around 2400. So we see that poverty is a major and growing problem in rural Australia. These figures do not include most of the farm families because they cannot access the family allowance supplement because of the assets test that is placed upon it; they are simply not able to tap in.

With farmers not earning, and so not spending, rural small businesses are getting into deeper and deeper financial difficulties. Neither farmers nor in fact the small business people can access virtually any of the Department of Social Security benefits, and I want to spend a brief time on this now.

Let us look at the rural adjustment scheme. This is very difficult, if not impossible, to access unless the farmer is prepared to leave the land. To add to the problem of lack of access, generally banks have to say that the property is unviable before help is given. It is almost impossible, I stress again, for farm families to access any Department of Social Security support. I here refer to the 1991 edition of The Rural Book put out by the office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin)-and I commend the Government on its production. It highlights the benefits that could be available to farmers but, unfortunately, they simply cannot access them, largely due to the assets test.

The special benefit is assets tested. Even though the farm maybe unsaleable and income negative, farm families get no help through this benefit. Unemployment benefit is assets tested, and farmers generally fail the work test as well because they are deemed to be underemployed and not unemployed. FAS, as I mentioned earlier, is unavailable.

Hardship provisions are virtually impossible to access-in fact I have found no farmer in South Australia who wishes to stay on his farm who has managed to obtain access through the hardship provisions. If the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), who has unfortunately left the chamber now, does know of any way that farming families can access Department of Social Security support at this time, I would be very happy for him to let this chamber know.

Let us look at just one area in South Australia-Kangaroo Island. Here, farmers are beginning to walk off their properties. Indeed, the majority of the farmers on the island are in financial difficulties. If they end up on unemployment benefits in Adelaide, the Government will have far more expenses-far more costs-than if they were able to stay on their farms. Not only will they need support benefits but they will also need accommodation support. So why not encourage the farmers by offering minimum income support to stay on the land?

The rural adjustment scheme must be extended to families staying on the land. As well, farm families must be able to tap into the social security support system available to other Australians. Work related assets should not be included in the assets test for income support or for education benefits. Only the income test should apply.

I refer now to an article in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser. This supports what I have found as I have travelled through rural South Australia in the last few weeks. It is titled `Rural women hidden victims' by Zac Donovan. This research was put together by Miss Diana Laidlaw, the Opposition women's interests spokeswoman, and I commend her for this paper. She says:
Women are the forgotten victims of the crisis gripping South Australia's farming communities . . .
The research has shown widespread social and personal problems facing rural families and women.
Specifically, I will detail just a few of these problems, which are outlined in the article:
RURAL doctors are noting an increase in stress-related ailments . . .
DOMESTIC violence, caused by financial problems, is being hidden . . .
VICTIMS of domestic violence, caused by financial stress, are being forced back into violent relationships because women's shelters cannot cope . . .
And I also might add that many of these women are not entitled to any support benefit because they also fail the assets test-
FAMILIES are fragmenting as children leave home to find work because the family farm cannot support them.
VOLUNTARY community service work is suffering . . .
CHILDREN are suffering the effects of stress.

There have been reports of children bursting into tears at school. I wish to conclude by stressing that if we do not address these sorts of issues alongside the current obsession with pure money matters, we will not only be doing a disservice to the country generally but also perpetuating the injustices in future generations. I do not believe that is a legacy we should pass on to our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The size and the nature of the crisis in unemployment were matters, interestingly enough, not dealt with effectively by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), largely because he refuses to admit them. Last year he assured me, in response to several questions at Question Time, that the bulk of the problem was over, that in fact youth unemployment, about which I was challenging his figures, was improving.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, that is simply not so, and the latest figures dramatise that. The question, of course, of how to fix it is the key one. There is no point in this Minister spending the great bulk of his response in this debate dealing with what he claims are bits of policy documents-potential policy documents or policy options that may be discussed by the Opposition. It is no good his dealing with those as if that were somehow something to do with the problem that he has to fix.

The reality is that it does not matter how one fiddles with the social security system, how much one mucks around with welfare. If there are no jobs, one is going to have massive and worsening unemployment, and one gets no jobs when one mucks the economy around, as this Government has done, so that there is no economic capacity for jobs to exist. I suggest to the Minister that he would be far better employed trying to encourage his Government to follow our economic recipe for success-in fact he should have been doing that over the past eight years-rather than seeking to divert attention away from the problem that his Government has created.

I can remember his Government telling us some years ago that it was quite possible to conquer the twin problems of inflation and unemployment at the same time. The Fraser Government was castigated for having failed to do so. The Hawke Government would show how this magic thing could be done. It got away with it for a few years by putting this country incredibly in hock to the extent now that we are a massive debtor nation.

Our foreign debt is now five times what it was when the Hawke Government came in and bought its way out of an unemployment problem. But one cannot buy a way out of an unemployment problem if one is simply borrowing the money to do so. Now the borrowing has had to stop because we are going broke. Now we are seeing the real level of unemployment-the unemployment this Government can no longer hide. I should correct myself because it is still hiding a fair bit of it.

There are lots of fiddles with the statistics. If one is `employed' without pay for one hour a week, one is no longer listed by this Government as being unemployed. That is a terrific way to solve the unemployment problem-just cut out all those people who cannot get an employed job. For example, someone in a rural area might work on the family farm for no reward, yet is not unemployed, or someone might be working in the parents' corner shop. This is apart from the enormous fiddle involved in the statistics by the extension of Austudy to secondary schools which, as the Minister for Social Security said, in many instances may prove enormously beneficial in the long run to some people who would be given opportunities to get better education and training. But for many it is simply teenager-sitting at public expense in order to fiddle the employment statistics and to make them look far less than they really are. So the figures now hide a large volume of unemployment.

Let us see how bad these figures are. This is the fastest fall in the number of people in jobs and the fastest rise in unemployment effectively since the Depression. The rise of 230,700 over the past 12 months in people looking for jobs is a 57 per cent increase. That is an increase by more than half in the number of people looking for jobs in just 12 months. I might say that three-quarters of that increase is made up of males.

We have heard a comment from the Australian Democrats that the situation for females is equally bad, that they have simply been dropping out of the statistics-another bit of evidence of hidden unemployment. On top of this increase in the number of unemployed, the people looking for jobs, what has happened to the people actually in jobs? Over the last 12 months we have had a fall of 190,200 in the number of people in jobs. Of the number of jobs available to Australians almost 200,000 jobs have been wiped out by this Government in the last 12 months.

The tragedy is that of those almost 200,000 jobs lost, 110,000 were people under 20. More than half the job losses that this nation has suffered in the last 12 months have come from the most vulnerable section of the Australian work force. They are the people aged between 15 and 19; the people who have just left school; who have just finished their training; who have very little job experience; and who are setting out on this, hopefully, adventure of life only to find immediately that it is a tragedy. They are in the firing line of this Government's recession we had to have. They are the people who are suffering most.

It is interesting that, in recent statistics of voting trends at elections, the great bulk of young people have tended to vote Labor rather than for the coalition. I invite those young people whose jobs have been wiped out by this Government seriously to consider where their best interests really lie. Is it to continue to support the people who have destroyed their prospects of jobs and who have destroyed 110,000 of the jobs they actually had or is it to look to a political party which has an economic policy which will rescue this country-with great difficulty, I might say, but nonetheless rescue it-from the disasters brought about by the deliberate economy policy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? He proudly said that this was the recession we had to have and he keeps on saying that these are good numbers when we go further and further into debt.

There are no jobs for young Australians leaving school. We ask why and what can be done. As to why, the answer is that this Government has created on its own an economic disaster at a time when the rest of the world until very recently had been going through a continuous boom. On the question of what can be done to fix it, there is one simple answer and that is to change this Government, get rid of it. Then, unfortunately, the effort of correction is going to be long and difficult. But there is no doubt that while this Government persists with its dreadful and disastrous economic policies, we are going to have more and more of these disastrous figures.

There are now about six million people in full time work in Australia and that is the lowest for years. This full time employment situation is the real one. Many people are simply forced into part time employment because they cannot get a full time job. Even the part time employment numbers in the latest figures are down by around 30 per cent in the last 12 months; that is, something like 40,000 part time jobs have been wiped out.

The unemployment rate that this has generated of 9.5 per cent for people seeking full time work, and 9.2 per cent when one includes part time, is the highest level since 1984. This is despite the fact that probably something like 50,000 people who have been fiddled out of the unemployment statistics by this Government's devices. So, clearly, the real level of unemployment right now is far worse than it was at the worst point of the 1983 recession. I might remind the Senate that the worst unemployment figures from that recession were, of course, while Mr Hawke was Prime Minister and not while Mr Fraser was.

But let us concentrate on the people who concern me most as shadow Minister for youth affairs, and that is the young people of Australia. What we have had here in the last 12 months is the biggest job loss that has ever taken place in Australia, including 110,700 young people who have lost their jobs. So the number of jobs available and filled by people who are under 20 is now only 320,300.

I might remind the Senate that when Mr Fraser left office eight years ago to the very month-that is to the March figures-there were 438,000 young people at work in Australia. Under Mr Hawke there are now 320,300. The dramatic difference between the number of young people who could get a job under Mr Fraser compared to the disastrously low level under Mr Hawke dramatises what this Government has done for young people in Australia. It has lost something like 27 per cent of the jobs that were then available to them.

Where have these young people who have lost their jobs gone? In the latest year there were 110,000 of them. According to these phoney statistics, youth employment has increased by only about 30,000 in the last 12 months. Yet 110,000 young Australians have lost their jobs. What has happened to the other 80,000 young people? One hundred and ten thousand young Australians have lost their jobs and yet unemployment is up by only 30,000. Where are the remaining 80,000? What has the Government done with them? Has it done a big fiddle? The facts are that the unemployment statistics do not reflect the number of young Australians who have been forced out of their jobs and, in many instances, into schools or into working for their families for no reward whatsoever.

When we look at the unemployment rate of the young, according to the revealed statistics-at least the ones which we know are fiddled-we see that youth unemployment in Australia is up to a level of 25.8 per cent; one in every four young Australians is out of a job. Thank you, Mr Keating! This is a 10-point jump from the 15-odd per cent of March 1990-that is, a year ago. That is the biggest yearly jump on record. All we heard from Senator Richardson was a smart alec response to what he believed was a possible policy of the Opposition in respect of social security. These figures have meant a big increase in the number of people on unemployment benefits. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small table which I showed to the Minister for Social Security earlier.

In Victoria, the number has more than doubled in the last 12 months; in Western Australia, there has been a 70 per cent increase; and in Queensland, a 47 per cent increase. Honourable senators will notice that New South Wales has about the best figure-only about a 32 per cent increase. The bad figures all come from the States with Labor governments and no-one is surprised by that. The youth unemployment figures are also absolutely appalling in all of the Labor States. It is 30 per cent in Tasmania, as Senator Harradine has pointed out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate we are having today on a matter of public importance emphasises to me the danger of trying to have an intelligent discussion about something as complex as national employment and unemployment figures only a matter of hours after those figures have been issued without allowing time for people who obviously have very genuine concerns about these issues to really see what the overall picture is or, more importantly, to identify the discrete elements of that particular picture. This was never so starkly pointed out as it was in the comments that have been made by the last two speakers about youth unemployment figures. It seems not to be appreciated that the overall unemployment figure-we are looking at it in seasonally adjusted terms-with regard to the number of people aged 15 to 19 years who are looking for full time work was 25.8 per cent in March of this year; up from 22.7 per cent in February. I am not denying for a moment that each case of unemployment may indicate a considerable amount of distress for the individuals and the families concerned, but one needs to remind oneself that that figure simply refers to the percentage of people in that age group who are in full time employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Of that 25.8 per cent, only 8 per cent-or less than one-third-of 15- to 19-year-olds are actually looking for employment. The rest, who are not available for employment, are those who are in education or training. I would suggest that of the 110,000, according to the previous speaker, who lost their jobs-once again, we are discussing this matter without having a chance to really look at the position-many are involved in a labour market program of some sort or, as we know, have gone back into the education system to complete their matriculation, creating in the process some difficulties for some state school systems which are not quite prepared for the rush of young people. Let us get this into perspective: it is not one in four young people who are seeking full time employment; it is more like one in 12 young people. I think this adds a little light to that particular argument.
The matter of public importance that we are dealing with today reads:
The worsening plight of the ever increasing number of victims of the Hawke Government's economic mismanagement.

As is not uncommon in this chamber, that is a startling misrepresentation of the facts. There is no point in arguing that there is not an increasing number of unemployed people and, as I have said, in many cases it can be a tragedy. There is, however, a failure to acknowledge in this matter of public importance that, despite the increasing rate of unemployment-and I would much rather talk about rates than numbers-a significantly decreasing percentage of Australians face the poor prospect, in the longer term, of being unemployed; thanks to the education, labour market and social security policies of the Hawke Government. That is the truth of the matter.

This applies to each discrete sector of the work force. It applies to women, especially those who have been out of the work force for any length of time and who are seeking to expand their skills and their employability. It applies to people with disabilities-there is a new disability program which is ready to start later this year-it applies to Aboriginals, where there is a slow but steady increase in higher education and work force participation. It applies particularly to youth, where the level of assistance that is available, the range of programs and projected programs, is better than it has ever been before. These are among the great achievements of this Government: the provision, as Senator Richardson said earlier, of a safety net which will cushion the effects of a recession such as the one from which we are suffering at the moment.

There are a number of elements to this safety net. The main ones would be income support, education and labour market programs. Income support for low income families and social security beneficiaries is enhanced a great deal on the position that existed when we came into government in 1983. In December 1990 our family allowance supplement (FAS) was being paid to 183,000 families, covering 454,000 children. By January 1991, it included 400,000 pensioners with their 740,000 children.

A very significant sector of the work force-I remind honourable senators that that is well over 1.2 million children out of a population of 17 1/2 million-is being assisted very substantially through this program. At the moment the payment, tax free, to eligible families for each child under the age of 13 is $26.50 per week and for each 13- to 15-year-old child it is $38.65. The average payment to families is in the vicinity of $65 per week tax free. That is the equivalent of a very substantial wage rise, as has been pointed out on a number of occasions by the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The take-up of this program is satisfactory, although there could be some more understanding of the eligibility requirements. It has been found that the targeting of this particular program has been extremely satisfactory. The people who are receiving this assistance on account of their low incomes say that FAS plays a vital role in helping working families to make ends meet. It is used to pay for children's basic necessities such as clothing, food and school expenses, and the majority of parents receiving FAS think that their children are as well off as most children in Australia today.

It has had a significant effect on the level of net family income, which is not surprising at $65 tax free a week. Most families who are receiving a FAS payment rely on one income. They are heavily reppresentative of the families in Australia where there is only one income, and the families are shown to be ones which would much rather rely on that one income than on social security.

Senator Richardson has talked about the enormous difference that rent assistance has made. Since the child support scheme was introduced it has made an enormous difference to the standard of living of very many sole parents. The average level of court orders has increased substantially during the first stage by approximately 30 per cent a week, or $10. There are 36.5 per cent of custodial parents currently on social security payments receiving maintenance-compared with 25.6 per cent before the scheme, a very substantial increase in the number of people receiving the maintenance to which they are entitled.

The average amount being received by the sole parent pensioners with maintenance income from 1 October 1989 was approximately $70 as against $41.90 before 1 June 1988-a 40 per cent increase in that relatively short time. It is interesting to note that the incidence of non-custodial parents considered to be untraceable is very low-about one per cent-a very pleasant surprise for those of us who thought it would be much higher.

We have introduced labour market schemes that have been very well targeted and very successful for the particular groups at which they are directed. Job growth over the eight years of our Government has been very substantial. There has been a big loss of jobs in the last few months, but we must not forget that 1.6 million new jobs were created during those eight years, over 90 per cent of them being in the private sector.

There has been a much higher level of work force participation, providing for all those people who were in the work force-even if some have lost their jobs more recently-job experience and economic security during that time, and a much higher level of employability when the economy picks up.

Newstart was put in place in February 1989 and there was a 28 per cent drop in the number of long term unemployed between February 1989 and November 1990. Even at this stage the percentage of long term unemployed is far lower than it was in the early 1980s. We certainly hope that the labour market programs that are being put in place and that are being expanded will help to reduce the numbers of those who are long term unemployed at this stage.

The jobs, education and training program is another very well targeted program. Between March 1989 and May 1990 nearly 11,000 sole parents have participated in labour market programs. Until February 1991, 29,500 sole parents had actually attended interviews. Of course, child-care is a very important element of this program. The vast majority of those who sought child-care in order that they could go back to education and/or training or to employment has been accommodated.

As a result of these and other programs, real household disposable incomes per capita have grown by 12.4 per cent between March 1983 and September 1990. Although that is an average over the whole population, it should not be overlooked that this has added substantially to the capacity of low income families to withstand a period such as the one that is creating difficulties for many at the moment. The family package overall has helped increase the real income levels of the bottom 10 per cent of two parent families by 12 per cent and of sole parent families by 15 per cent.

I wonder what it is that we might anticipate if there were a change of government. It is hard to tell. As Senator Richardson has described, all that we know about the plans of the Opposition that we have heard so far is somewhat fantastic and almost difficult to believe. When we look for hard evidence I suppose the best examples that we can find are those in the State of New South Wales, which has had a Liberal-National Party government for several years.

I am indebted to Jenny Earle, Marion Brown and Linnel Secomb for their article entitled `Hard times for women under Greiner's NSW Inc.' in the Legal Service Bulletin in December 1990. They point out the following:
. . . the conservative ideology and so-called economic rationalism of New South Wales Inc. is not conducive to an expansion of opportunities for women.

We are talking today about `victims', and I think we have acknowledged the fact that unless women are able to develop their economic dependence, families on the whole will be much less well off. The State Government of New South Wales stood by while the Government Insurance Office abolished paid maternity leave for new employees and also abolished flexitime. The Government infrastructure in New South Wales for ensuring proper consideration of women's interests was dismantled, sidelined or otherwise silenced in the early days of the Greiner regime, presumably in the interests of efficient management.
Effectiveness and rationality seem to be the messages that are coming through, and certainly Senator Alston has not done anything to disabuse us of that impression. The article continues as follows:
Other women's policy units were either eliminated or drastically reduced

It says that family support services were cut to the bone, many district offices of the Department of Family and Community Services were closed down, the Child Protection Council was greatly diminished and the capacity to respond to those community needs minimised. Finally, the article states:
It would be rather nice for women shareholders in New South Wales Inc. to feel that the next Board of Directors recognised their 52% shareholding!

I might add that it might be rather nice for the people of Australia to get the impression that there is some real concern for the needs of families by the coalition if, in fact, it is holding itself out as a credible successor to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish I could say it is a pleasure to participate in this debate on a matter of public importance today, but it is certainly no pleasure for me to debate the worsening plight of the ever increasing number of victims of the Hawke Government's economic management. Like my colleague Senator Michael Baume I would particularly like to concentrate on the young people of Australia. I was recently appointed to a young Australians task force set up by Dr Hewson and chaired very capably by Senator Michael Baume. Through that committee I have had the opportunity to visit and talk to young people and see what is happening out there.

SPEECH.PARA: After all is said and done, it is the young people of our community to whom we are looking for the future. They are the ones who are going to make this country the `clever country', to quote the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Unfortunately, at this point in time, as has been pointed out by my colleague Senator Baume, from the youth unemployment figures today they must be looking with a great deal of scepticism to their futures. At that age the prospect of unemployment is totally degrading. Unfortunately, we are looking at the prospect of some young people spending their lives on the dole and hanging around waiting for the old age pension. What a future they must have.

A lot has been said today about youth unemployment and what is going to be done with the people who are unemployed. People have spoken about all these training schemes-putting young people into training and whatever for when we come out of the recession-but no-one has really said why we went into the recession.

We went into the recession because the policies of the Hawke-Keating Government-the policies of high interest rates, high taxation, high inflation and high exchange rates-have ripped the heart out of small business in Australia. Small businesses in Australia employ up to 80 per cent of our employable people. They are the ones who are feeling the effect of this recession, the recession we had to have.

It is interesting to note that no-one from the Government or the Australian Democrats spoke about small business at all, except for Senator Lees, who mentioned rural Australia, and I give her credit for that. When we look at what has happened because of the policies of the Hawke Government, we see that in Victoria from February 1990 to February 1991 there has been an increase in bankruptcies of 69 per cent. There has been an increase in bankruptcies in your own State of Queensland, Madam Acting Deputy President, of 50 per cent in the past 12 months. In Western Australia, Senator Cook's State, there has been an increase of 89 per cent, and in my own State there has been an increase of 10.4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened in the great State of Western Australia?

—In the great State of Western Australia bankruptcies increased by 89 per cent from February 1990 to February 1991. The Australian Small Business Association has predicted that another one in eight businesses will go broke in the next 12 months. What has this Government done to help this situation? It announced in the Budget that small businesses would have to pay up to 85 per cent of their income tax by 28 July. That was a big help! That effectively brought forward the payment by nine months. I know that small businesses with profits under $400,000 are exempt in the first year, but that certainly was not any help.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot about interest rates and how they are coming down, but the rate that small business is paying is still around 16 to 18 per cent, plus all the additional charges that banks put on. The figure can then increase to around 20 per cent. The Government in its wisdom really helped small businesses by imposing a one per cent training levy-another great help!
