It might be fine in good times, but it certainly has been no help to them in this recession we had to have.

There has been a lot of comment from Senator Richardson and others today concerning what this side of politics would do about this situation. I think small business knows that one of the things the Opposition would be doing is giving some incentive back to small business by abolishing the capital gains tax. It is interesting to note that, when Arthur Anderson and Co. conducted a survey in September last year of over 2,500 small businesses, most companies reported a drop in profit and a confidence crisis in small business was evident.

If we are going to get young people-in fact, anybody-back into work, it is the small business sector of our community that we have to look at. If those opposite do not believe the figures I have quoted, they have only to go to places like Perth and Melbourne, or even my own State, and look at the number of shops that are closing up. When I mentioned bankruptcies, those figures did not take into account those people who have closed their doors because they could see what was going to happen to them.

Senator Lees from the Democrats mentioned the rural crisis. We know that in good times the rural areas are big employers of young people, but at the present time, partly due to the high interest, high inflation policies of this Government, they are not only employing people, but their wives are looking for work and they are taking their children out of school, all due to this recession we had to have. I repeat: the effect of the recession on young people has been catastrophic. I quote from an article in the Age on 28 March written by Margaret Easterbrook:
Jobs, education and money are the personal issues of most concern to young people . . .

While people under the age of 25 are often generally worried about their finances, the rest of the community underestimate their concerns and consider unemployment, followed by drugs, as the main youth issues.

This poll was conducted by the Australian National Opinion Polls and it shows that, while many young people are interested in travel, employment is their primary interest and expectation in the near future. There is no question where the priorities of young people lie. These priorities are being denied them because of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke-Keating Government.
It is not just the youth who are feeling the effects of the recession that we had to have. An article in the Australian on 15 February by its science and technology writer, Julian Cribb, stated:
Jobs are becoming harder to find for university graduates, a national survey by the Graduate Careers Council revealed yesterday.
Of 84,000 graduates surveyed on leaving university last year, less than 60 per cent had found full-time employment . . .
So our academics are also facing difficulties under this recession we had to have. An article in the Australian of 9 January stated:
Young people should consider staying at school rather than seeking work in the face of the recession, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said yesterday.

There is a very apt cartoon in this article. It shows a young child saying, `Hawke says we should stay at school till after the recession!' The other young child is saying, `And then go straight on to the pension!' Mr Hawke advised school leavers to make full use of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The article continued:
While unemployment would rise, training programs were ready to deal with the problem, he said.

What is the point in training people if no small business is around to employ them? I will return to that subject a little later if I have time. What has been the effect of keeping people at school? I quote again from the Age, where the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, is reported as having said that:
High unemployment has caused overcrowding at universities across Australia . . .

The situation has reached the stage where students at New South Wales universities are being locked out of lecture theatres and are forced to take their courses in cafeterias. This situation is not going to improve, particularly while the policies of this Government are still in operation.

I have spoken about the prospects for the young unemployed and university graduates. What about the apprentices? As Senator Richardson said, small businesses would benefit through apprenticeship training schemes. The apprenticeship scheme is probably one of the most effective ways of training young people, yet in Victoria, we see from the Age, apprenticeship vacancies are down by 43 per cent. The Federal Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, Mr Wayne Blair, said that the figures show that employers lack vision. What those employers lack is money and confidence. That is why they are not taking on apprentices.

This Government has to start encouraging small businesses to get going again. They cannot do that while we have this high inflation, high tax, high unemployment situation. The figures that became available today have been commented on, but to reiterate: the unemployment beneficiaries in this country have risen in the past 12 months, from March 1990 to March 1991, by 204,000-from 392,000 to 596,000. In the same period, job vacancy figures have fallen by 24 per cent.

If we needed more evidence of the ever increasing victims of the Hawke Government's economic mismanagement, we need go no further than my own State of Tasmania. Senator Button, in answer to a question from Senator Harradine today, said that Tasmanian youth unemployment had always been high. I can guarantee that it has never been as high as 37 per cent on a State basis. In my own city of Hobart there is 40 per cent youth unemployment. I am not quoting the March figures; those are the February figures. So I cannot be accused of trying to fiddle the figures, as Senator Giles said in her speech.

Senator Button said that the figures had always been high and asked what the Government could do about it. The previous Premier of Tasmania and his Liberal Government tried to do something about it. They tried to establish a pulp mill, and yet they got rolled. They were rolled by the Greens with the help of the Commonwealth Government. Now we have Mr Field in a minority Labor Government trying to do the same thing and it looks as if he will also get rolled by Greens. One only has to hear what Senator Walsh said about the effect that the Greens are having on the economy of Australia. I wonder how they feel about the unemployment figures.

The figures that I quote from Tasmania are quite horrific. In the statistical region of Hobart the number of full time unemployed youth rose by a massive 85 per cent, or 1,100 people in the last 12 months. The youth unemployment rate for the same period has risen from 20.6 per cent last year to 40 per cent this year; in other words, it has doubled. There were 1,600 jobs lost, which translates to a 30.8 per cent fall in jobs that are available. The same figures show that in Hobart adults fared little better than young people. Total adult unemployment in Hobart is 42.6 per cent, which reflected a rise of 2,300 adults, and 1,700 full time jobs were lost during the same period. In the north of the State the figures are a little bit better, but the percentage rises have been just as dramatic. On a State-wide basis, youth unemployment has risen by 37.8 per cent.
The young people of Australia are suffering and suffering very badly. As we have said, in the main, it is all as a result of the irresponsibility of this Government and its economic policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join this debate on a matter of public importance introduced into this place by Senator Alston. The topic for discussion is:

SPEECH.PARA: The worsening plight of the ever increasing number of victims of the Hawke Government's economic mismanagement.

What we have heard from Opposition senators today is a very confused argument. They are not quite sure whether they are talking about what should be done under welfare to assist people or about economic considerations. Most of the time they have been trying to tell us that what this Government has done under welfare is a disgrace. That is quite curious. How can Opposition senators criticise us for not doing anything when they stand on policies that will do even less?

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) pointed out that the Opposition has a policy whereby after nine months it would not assist people on unemployment benefits any more. They would either have to take jobs they did not want or they would get no benefits and have to manage for themselves. That was a quote from Dr Hewson and I am only paraphrasing it because I do not have it here. The best defence Senator Alston could mount against that was that it was not really reasonable to criticise the Opposition for this, that or the other piece of policy that it might or might not have. Honourable senators cannot come into this place, criticise the Government and not cop the same back if their policies do not shape up, judged by their own arguments or matters of public importance. Why should the Opposition criticise the Government, saying that it is not doing enough to help people under welfare when it has policies that will do much less?

At one stage Senator Alston reached dizzy heights of illogic by telling us that the number of women in the work force had gone from something like 28 per cent to more than 40 per cent. I am not at all sure what women in the work force has to do with a debate about unemployment, unless of course Senator Alston, like Senator Harradine, wants to suggest that there is a causal connection between women and young people-that women are taking the place of young people. Certainly Senator Harradine has mentioned that kind of argument quite often-that if only women got out of the work force and stayed at home where they have the preferred prospect of looking after their families, then there would not be anything like the same problems in work force participation for young people.

I imagine that Senator Harradine has never spoken to any woman in the work force and asked her whether she chose to get that job, whether she is pleased to get the income it returns to her or whether she finds herself more satisfied because she is able to go out and work. I certainly do not think that any of his Opposition colleagues have ever asked men whether many of them would prefer not to have to go to work each day. It demonstrates an insufficient understanding of what people do when they choose to go to work. As I said earlier, to actually suggest that the increased participation of women in the work force is some measurement of unemployment is an example of some dizzy heights of illogic reached by Senator Alston in his contribution, unless of course he means, as Senator Harradine does, that women in the work force are some kind of replacement for young people. By and large, if people understood female participation in the work force, they would know that women are doing jobs that do not replace other workers. Almost invariably they are taking jobs in the work force that are specifically for women and very rarely are they replacing either young men or older men.

As was spelt out, the Opposition wants to privatise many areas of welfare. I have a big concern about this because in telling us that some things will be privatised-for example, the assistance given to people who are in need of furniture; the household assistance that people in need receive; or the social work contribution from the work force-Opposition senators do not tell us who will pay for them. Does Senator Alston presume that unemployed people or very poor people will be able to afford to go to social workers under a private arrangement? Certainly no explanation was given as to how deserving people who have certain needs would actually benefit by having this sort of service being provided through the private sector. Somewhere along the line someone will have to pay. If it is a private provision of services, presumably it will be a user pays system; at least I think that would be consistent from Opposition senators. But nowhere do they explain how people who are poor could possibly then be able to afford those services currently provided through the public services of this Government's policies.

At the same time the Opposition criticises the Government for not doing enough in the welfare area and says that we should do this, that and the other. But never does it say that it appreciates one of the most important values of good economic management-fiscal restraint. We see Opposition senators come in here and, by way of criticising us, simply allow us to conclude that they would increase outlays. If they do not mean that, they really must explain it. If they do mean that, then their policies would undo the enormous gains contributed to that section of the economy by the Government.

The Opposition does not appreciate that in the area of social security under this Government there has actually been a reduction in the outlays of that portfolio and, at the same time, an increase of each payment because these are more targeted and more stringent in their application.

Senator Lees from the Australian Democrats wanted to make the point that the Liberal Party of Australia or the Opposition was just as culpable as the Government because the Opposition has supported the Government in a number of tough measures in the welfare area. I will not run through those again, but anyone who is interested might read Senator Lees's contribution.

Senator Lees cannot have it both ways. If she wants economic restraints, a good economic policy, and fiscal policy that is actually providing for that healthy country that we are looking for, she cannot continue to expend outlays under welfare. Does Senator Lees want to increase those payments to people who are eligible for welfare and at the same time increase expenditure or does she see what I have cited is the record of this Government-to reduce outlays and at the same time increase all payments-as a huge gain?

Senator Lees also made a very important point that some people seem to be beaten down by the eligibility criteria whether they be the requirements of where they have to go, how many forms they have to fill in, or whatever. I think that point needs to be very thoroughly examined. Certainly, there are people who from time to time find that fronting those systems or services in this country is very forbidding and very frightening and all of us would agree there are people who are eligible for those payments who do not actually get them because they do not make it across the barrier.

It has been a matter of grave concern to this Government and all the Ministers in the social security portfolio from Senator Grimes to Mr Howe to Senator Richardson have addressed how precisely to deal with that point. If people have eligibilities, they must not be prevented from getting them because of a hesitation, a nervousness or some barriers to their application. If Senator Lees knows of any examples and brings them to the attention of the Minister, he will very much want to address them. It has been his policy to make those eligibility criteria a critical part of the Government's policies. The Opposition has dismissed this out of hand this afternoon.

Before this recession and before the undoubted needs of people who are currently unemployed-in a time of growing jobs and falling numbers of people depending on welfare-this Government was concerned to see that anybody on welfare did not anticipate a lifetime of being locked into welfare. This has been addressed by the provision of training programs, the assistance of payments, the recognition of poverty traps, the counselling services and the new subsets of welfare to special groups of people on pensions and benefits to assist them across that barrier from being on welfare to going back into the work force. Those programs are in place and will be assisting people with those needs now. I have not yet heard of any demand for those services being too high for the Department to supply. I am quite sure that that is a matter that the Minister has a close eye on and I am quite sure that, if there were that need, the Government would provide officers to assist those people.

The Opposition has made another point. Senator Calvert seems to suggest that it is a dreadful thing to have overcrowded universities. Maybe there is not enough infrastructure in our universities. In saying that, Senator Calvert does not acknowledge the dramatic growth in university places under this Government. If that falls short-and I suspect it will continue to fall short for quite some time-let us talk about the shortfall and not suggest that it is some type of indictable offence to have people preferring to go to university than to go directly onto unemployment benefits.

I would have thought it quite encouraging that so many people in this country would want to seek out those training opportunities and to get through university. Indeed, I think the most important point that needs to be put into this debate is that, despite the tragedy and the difficulty confronting people at the moment, because of the opportunities for training not only introduced now and being taken up now but also in place for a number of years, which are continuing to grow, particularly with the further announcements in the recent industry statement that more and more people are taking up that opportunity for training for skills development, as this recession recedes the Australian work force and people in Australia will be much better placed to take advantage of the opportunities that present when that recovery occurs. That point has not been spelt out by the Opposition. It seems not to be recognised by it. It is one of the reasons that makes this time in history so very different, even from that in 1982.

The book written by Mick Young during the Fraser years, I think, pointed out the terrible tragedy of losing so many trained and qualified people, particularly in the apprenticeship trades and crafts area, because there is at least a five-year lead time to get that skills base to where it can be used in a growing productive sector. That gap will not happen now. Because the Government has recognised the dreadful loss of skills disappearing in those years, it has particularly targeted programs to say to people, `If you have to be unemployed for a time, make constructive use of that time to get that training, to get your skills up so that as soon as the employment opportunities present themselves you, and on behalf of the community, this country, will be very well placed to move those skills into the work force where they are needed'. That point cannot be emphasised too often and too loudly.

As Minister Richardson said, this Government does not run away from the very sad consequences of the figure of higher than 9 per cent unemployment. Who would want it? Certainly not the Government. We recognise the pain and anguish that it is causing to so many people, particularly the personal deprivation of loss of job and loss of income. At the same time the Opposition does not acknowledge the commitment by this Government to those people, both in times when there were jobs and now, of not forgetting them or wasting them on the unemployment heap but of providing the counselling, the focusing, the training, the assistance, and even the educational programs for literacy and numeracy, recognising how many people in the Australian work force do not even have those basic skills. All those opportunities will be of benefit to those people in the short term and in the longer term and will, of course, be of benefit to this country. That increased educational base of Australia's work force will make this country that much stronger in the future and it will make it so much better able to face the recovery when it arrives.

For many years, we have been talking about the sad loss of skills in this country. That is one thing that will happen while this Government is in office and while it has its programs in place. From listening to the debate today, I only hope that, should the Opposition ever get into government, it would not insult Australian people by taking away those tremendous programs put in place by this Government to assist people at whatever time in life they find themselves able to benefit from training programs either during their working life, as they come into their working life or during a period of unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to Senator Crowley talk, one would think that Australia was not faced with an enormous tragedy. Blandly she spoke to the Senate. At no stage did she really tell the Senate what the Government will to do; what new policies the Government will enact so as to reverse this tragic trend in unemployment that we are seeing today. The Government owes it not only to the Parliament but also to the people of Australia and to the unemployed to tell us and them what new policies the Government will come up with and enact so as to relieve this tragedy. Instead, in the last few minutes, we have heard political point scoring and a false characterisation of a number of things that have been said by other honourable senators and by me. I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: First, let me remind the Senate of the enormity of the position which Australia and this Government faces: near record unemployment; a decrease in male and total seasonally adjusted employment, the largest monthly falls since the monthly surveys began in 1978; and youth unemployment at record levels. As my colleague Senator Calvert said, in the Hobart area 40 per cent of people are unemployed. What is the Government going to do about it?

Senator Crowley has attempted to falsely characterise what I have been saying about the participation rate and to falsely suggest that I have not been speaking to women in the paid work force. I happen to be the President of the Tasmanian branch of the largest union in Australia, a union which has a very large number of women members. What I have been saying is the policy of that union, determined at levels where women have been in the majority. Clearly, those women are concerned that they and/or their daughters at some stage will be in a one-income family situation. They know that this Government is discriminating against the one-income family. They know that the policies of this Government have forced families to have two and three incomes in order to make ends meet. A large number of those women are forced into the paid work force through economic necessity.

In the last 10 years, the number of families with at least one child under 4 years of age, both their parents being in the paid work force, has increased by 65 per cent. Why? A large number of them have entered the paid work force because of increased housing costs, inflation, higher taxes and reduced disposable income.

I have asked the Government to look at the construction of the paid work force to see who in that paid work force desires to work to pursue socially constructed alternatives. They are not my words; they are the words of the Prime Minister. It was the Prime Minister who said that we cannot rely on economic measures alone and that we have to look at this other aspect to relieve the pressure. This was said in 1984, yet nothing has been done. No person should be compelled to leave the paid work force; neither should any family be forced by economic pressures, by government policies largely, to have both parents in the paid work force to the detriment of the family.

Let us have a look at family allowances. They have lost their value enormously. A family with three children is now $68 a week worse off than it was in 1976. Why not restore the true value of family allowances and extend child-care payments to all mothers, including those at home. Those changes are required to end the economic discrimination suffered by one-income families, and this could relieve the unemployment situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The time for the debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Hospital Costs and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance entitled Hospital Costs and Health Insurance. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE (HOSPITAL COSTS AND HEALTH INSURANCE)
May I first congratulate the Committee for its hard work in preparing a well balanced Report covering such a wide range of issues.

The Committee was appointed in June 1989 to inquire into and report upon the implications of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which related to the introduction of the Government's Vocationally Registered General Practitioners arrangements. In addition to that task, the Committee was requested to inquire into and report on the Health Insurance Industry Structure. The Report we are addressing today relates to the latter Term of Reference.
I note that the Committee, which had all party representation, submitted a unanimous Report which endorsed Medicare.

There has been some recent debate on paying for health care instigated by members of the Opposition other than those on the Committee, which is once again proposing that Medicare be abolished. Will those members of the Opposition never learn. Three times the Government has gone to the people with Medicare as an integral part of its election platform and three times the people of Australia have endorsed the Program. The Opposition, which puts so much emphasis on results of surveys, should read the press releases put out by the Health Insurance Commission following its surveys of the acceptability of Medicare by the community-more than 71% of the population support Medicare. When is the Opposition going to accept that it is here to stay.

I make this point having regard to the introduction by the Committee that said ``This debate (in relation to Medicare and funding of public hospitals and the pressures on available resources) has, in the past two decades, all too often degenerated into a brawl between rival interest groups seeking to defend or promote their own views of, and positions within, the health system.'' (Para 1.4)

The Committee continued with ``It is important that attention be focused on the real issues which affect health outcomes in this country and that the health debate be conducted in a well informed and non-partisan way.'' (Para 1.5)

It is within that context that the Government established the National Health Strategy-more commonly known as the Macklin Inquiry-to look at the real issues that affect the health of the population and the way in which services are financed and provided.

To that end, the Minister for Community Services and Health has referred the Committee's Report to the Macklin Inquiry and requested that the Inquiry take into account the Committee's recommendations in the course of its investigations.
The Senate Select Committee broadly examined four aspects of the health care system:
- The Medical Context;
- Is Medicare Achieving Its Objectives?;
- Private Hospitals; and
- The Private Health Insurance Industry.
I do not intend addressing in detail the Report or the recommendations contained therein. However, there are some significant issues which need to be acknowledged.

Reforms to the hospital system feature prominently in the Committee's Report. The Government has acknowledged on several occasions the need to closely examine existing mechanisms for hospital funding and where identifiable, shift the emphasis of that funding to address areas of need; for example, the stresses placed on the system because of the ageing of the population.

The Government notes the Committee's reference to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&RC) Working Party on Ethics and Resource Allocation and its desire to see a debate initiated on the ethics of resource allocation in hospitals. The Government would be happy to see such a debate and will refer this issue to NH&RC.

On the more general issue of resource allocation, the Committee recommended that the NH&RC be asked to develop goals for public hospitals and establish priorities for resource allocation. While welcoming input into the debate on health care outcomes, goals and objectives by an independent body such as the NH&RC, the Government doubts that this is an appropriate body to do that task. The ultimate decisions about hospitals on, for example, location of hospital services, type and sophistication of services and number of beds, is a State Government responsibility. The Commonwealth has no direct role in the provision of hospital and related services, but provides funds to States to address areas of need. The determination of priorities is a matter for Ministers and it is in the Australian Health Ministers' Conference process that many of these issues are determined.

Two other recommendations made by the Committee related to changes to funding for hospital services. These related to the way in which Nursing Home Type Patients are charged and the possible introduction of casemix funding for hospital provision and services. Both of these issues are being looked at by the National Health Strategy. In addition, Cabinet has recently considered the role of casemix information and funding systems in improving efficiency and equity in the hospital system. As a result, discussions will be held shortly with State and Territory Health Authorities aimed at developing a co-operative approach to the uses of casemix information.

I note that the Committee rejected proposals for changes to be made to the Medicare Program. Some of the proposals were similar to those adopted by the Fraser Government which led to the abolition of Standard Medibank, namely, to allow individuals with private health insurance to opt out of Medicare, encouraged by increasing the Medicare levy and tax deductability of contributions. The Committee opposed these proposals because they would impact adversely on the principles of simplicity and equity of access, which are vital elements of the Government's Medicare program.

The Committee made some interesting observations about possible reforms being made to the private health insurance arrangements. Many of the recommendations would have far reaching implications for the health insurance industry, the private hospital sector, and the community-in particular the suggestion that private health insurance might move to experience rating. Given the adverse impact on cash flows of private hospitals and the affordability of health insurance for the elderly and the chronically ill, the Government will need to be convinced that a move away from community rating is justified. There is, of course, within that principle the need to look at how reinsurance is operating. Nevertheless, these are matters which the Macklin Inquiry will no doubt be looking into closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to this Government response to the report of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance entitled Hospital Costs and Health Insurance, and I believe a number of my colleagues may want to do that too. The response by the Government to the report has been incorporated in Hansard. I would like to highlight some of the points made by the Government in response to that Committee report, which the Committee called, `What Price Care'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges that it was a well balanced report, covering a wide range of issues. The Committee, as the response tells us, was appointed in June 1989 to inquire into and report upon the implications of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, relating to vocational registration of general practitioners. In fact, that part of the reference was dealt with in 1989 and a report from the Committee was tabled in about August 1989.

Subsequent to that, the Committee tackled the task of the second term of reference, going much more to health insurance and hospitals. I have commented before on the terms of reference. They were written in haste and promoted for political reasons; so they were less than tight and focused terms of reference. But the Committee was able to conclude that what we were really being asked to look at was Medicare, private hospitals, public hospitals and the efficiency of those three sections.

The response from the Government notes-and I think it is important to put it on the record-that it was an all-party committee. At the time of writing its report and concluding its deliberations, the Committee consisted of myself as Chairperson, Senator Peter Baume, Senator John Herron, who joined the Committee later with my colleagues Senator Michael Beahan and Senator Susan West, and Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats.

The Committee was widely representative. Indeed, it was thickly represented by the medical profession until Senator West-who is a very competent double or triple certificate sister, if I can use such old fashioned language to describe nursing-joined to assist us, at which time the Committee became representative of the health professions. I do not in any way denigrate her capacity or the information and expertise she brought to the Committee. It is important to note the construction of the Committee and also that that all-party representation submitted a unanimous report in part of its work endorsing Medicare.

Chapter 1 of the `What Price Care' report opens with a quote of the then Senator Puplick in a debate in this place talking to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. He described the Bill as:
. . . the next step to patch up this ramshackle, shambling and discredited health system of Medicare . . . in the face of all evidence that what [Medicare] in fact requires is radical surgery.

Our report did not find that, and the Government response to our report notes that, we did not focus on shooting our guns in the wrong direction but on trying to redirect the health debate so that it could be a constructive debate. The Government response picks up some of the comments from the Committee report. To quote again from the report, in part, it said:
This debate-
that is, the debate about Medicare and funding of public hospitals and waiting lists-
. . . has, in the past two decades, all too often degenerated into a brawl between rival interest groups seeking to defend or promote their own views of, and positions within, the health system.
The Committee continued:
It is important that attention be focused on the real issues which affect health outcomes in this country and that the health debate be conducted in a well informed and non-partisan way.

The Government response goes on to say that it is within that kind of context that the Government has established the national health strategy-more commonly known as the Macklin inquiry-to look at the way the real issues affect the health of the population and the way in which those services are financed and provided. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), in his response, has recommended that our report and its recommendations go to the Macklin inquiry, to be picked up by that inquiry and used as part of its deliberations, and indeed requests that the Macklin inquiry take into account the Committee's recommendations in the course of its investigations.

The Government response says that the Senate Committee addressed the following: the medical context; is Medicare achieving its objectives?; private hospitals; and the private health insurance industry. It concluded that that would be very useful information for the Macklin inquiry in its deliberations. The Government response notes that reforms to the hospital system featured prominently in the Committee's report and states:

The Government has acknowledged on several occasions the need to closely examine existing mechanisms for hospital funding and where identifiable, shift the emphasis of that funding to address areas of need; for example, the stresses placed on the hospital system because of the ageing of the population.

The Government noted the Committee's reference to the National Health and Medical Research Council working party on ethics and resource allocation and its suggestion to see a public debate initiated by that NHMRC working party to look at resource allocation in hospitals. The response says that the Government will be happy to see such a debate and will refer this issue to the NHMRC. As the Chair of the Committee I am delighted that the Government is prepared to refer this issue to the NHMRC and encourage the NHMRC to look at ways it can establish that public debate.

The Committee realised that the pressures of increasing costs of health care in this country are not going to lessen; they are only going to continue. Not only is there increasing pressure as a result of people living longer-that is, the ageing of the Australian population-but also there is a significant push for increased expenditure for the ever-increasing high technology in medical care and delivery of surgical procedures and so on. Some of those high technology areas, which are very expensive, are in the investigative or diagnostic area.

The Committee recognised that increasing costs will only continue to apply pressure on governments when they already have another requirement, another pressure-that is, to keep the lid on the total outlay of health costs in this country. When there is a push for increased expenditure and a lid on how much can be expended, in the end we are going to have to look at agreeing that what is occurring now has to be discussed formally-that is, rationing the delivery of services. We have asked that the NHMRC go to the Australian public and say, `These are the sorts of challenges that we have to look at'.

While I can illustrate the point with all sorts of examples, from the wildly emotional to the much less than emotional, we must appreciate that if people have a fatal disease -I was going to say `are dying from a fatal disease', but I am sure Senator Watson would be amused at that contribution to the Rex Mossop prize; therefore I will not use that tautology-should they still be entitled to the surgical procedures that may be under pressure of supply? To what extent would a person with a fatal disease be eligible for much more than palliative care? That needs to be seriously addressed. It is a very hard question and we believe that it ought not be one that falls on the caring doctor or the practitioner nurse at the time. Also, it ought to be something that is beyond the hospital administration's decisions. It ought to be something on which the community has come to some agreement.

If it costs, as it does, $75,000 to keep an underweight baby, a tiny-weight baby, alive through the humidicrib and intensive care procedures, how do we put that cost against, for example, the general requirement of inoculation against measles? To what extent do we balance the cost of a liver transplant? Originally the cost was about $300,000. I understand that the cost has been reduced a little. One way of looking at it is to say that that one liver transplant to assist a very ill person is equivalent, we are advised, to the provision of 30 nurses for a year. Does the community have a view on such things? I believe it is time the community looked at these facts and had them presented to it in those terms.

If we leave the health debate to be run by Derryn Hinch, I do not believe we will have a constructive outcome. It is no easy way to ask any individual patient or any individual patient's family to not want the best care for that person but, at the same time, we ought to be able to make decisions about what is a reasonable allocation of health resources. How do we decide between prevention and cure and, among those curative provisions, how do we make decisions? When my grandmother was alive she never even thought of having a hip replacement; it was not an accessible procedure. I suppose for many of the people who were alive not too many years ago-maybe 20 or 25 years-hip replacements were not a possibility. The technical know-how and their provision was not possible. When the operation was first introduced patients were a very expensive drain on hospital resources because of the number of days they were required to be in hospital. Nowadays the length of stay in hospital for such a procedure is remarkably short and patients are back on their feet in a very short time. That reduces the outlay of costs for such a provision.

Would anybody in the Senate say, `Certain groups of people are not going to have hip replacements', even though quite clearly they have severe arthritis, are in considerable pain, have disability with walking, and are getting back problems from the disability? Are we going to say that people are not to have a hip replacement? Somebody may have to make that decision. We believe that, to assist government or hospital administrators to make that decision, we should be putting the conflicting facts and values to the community and getting them extensively discussed.

We need to ask people what their view is on the costs of health care. Do we see a push for the prevention side of health care that may assist people to keep out of hospital? At the same time, do we appreciate that the inoculation of children in this country has contributed to the demand on hospital services because so many more people survive? I am not suggesting that we go back to letting a large percentage of children die. I am suggesting that what we have to do is face up to the consequences of that kind of delivery of health care. That is what the report found-that there are many areas where some kind of rationing that is currently happening needs to be formally discussed and considered by the community.

One area that we heard about, although not in great detail, was the provision of a lithotryptor-that is, a machine that can reduce or do away with kidney or gallstones without any invasive surgery. Where should such an expensive piece of equipment be put and who should be eligible to use it? The Government, in dealing with this a few years ago, determined that such an expensive piece of equipment ought to be provided in a way that facilitated the optimal use by the maximum number of people. It may indeed be provided in the private sector, but it ought to be for the use of the public sector; or it may be provided through the public sector, but private patients should have access to it.

Senator Herron might be able to say more about the state of play in Queensland in that and other high-tech areas. If he were able to contribute to the discussion along those lines, I for one would appreciate his updating it. He certainly made a very useful contribution to our deliberations about these matters and how government should deal with them. I hope that I have not anticipated Senator Herron's speech.

These things are currently happening. Indeed, the debate in this place in the past about waiting lists has sometimes been quite unseemly. The size of waiting lists has been used to thrash the Government. It would seem from some contributions that the only proper way to deliver health care in this country is to have a waiting list of nil. Any amount of evidence given to the Committee points to the fact that no hospital would have a waiting list of nil, meaning either no patients or no days to wait; that the majority of people who would visit their doctor and be judged as deserving of certain elective treatment are the people who are on waiting lists. A four- to six-week waiting list is seen as the optimal. By the time people put arrangements in place for their own businesses, their own family arrangements or whatever, no-one could just go straight into hospital. By definition, that is what waiting lists and elective surgery are about, and they are quite different from accident and emergency or urgency provisions through the health care service.

Waiting lists are a current, already-in-place method of rationing. One of the things that was of concern to the Committee was whether the extension of waiting lists in the public sector was disadvantaging public patients-that is, people who were insured under Medicare only. The very conclusive evidence before the Committee is that one cannot say. The data about waiting lists is very insufficient. The criteria from State to State was not comparable. First of all, the number of people on the waiting list was in doubt in terms of the accuracy of those figures and the criteria people had as to those who got onto the waiting list. The clear evidence was that there was duplication of waiting lists and, indeed, grave doubt about the reliability of the figures.

When I point out that the Committee received no absolute evidence about waiting lists, this does not mean that the Committee denied their existence. We know that waiting lists exist. What is in doubt and in considerable dispute is their size. The Committee concluded that a better way to look at this whole question was to take waiting times. The number of people on a waiting list could be very large, but if all those people were dealt with within six weeks nobody would have too much of an objection. But, in terms of numbers, one could say there was a very extensive waiting list. We recommend that a more useful way of looking at waiting lists for people who collect this data would be to look at waiting times.

We were advised that the public hospital system does a remarkable job in taking huge numbers of patients who come to it through accident and emergency-that is, as urgent matters for treatment-and that 100 per cent of people arriving in a hospital in the public hospital system, certainly in the two major States of Victoria and New South Wales, are dealt with within 24 hours. That is a remarkable achievement and an extraordinary acknowledgment of the ability to be effective in our public hospitals. I do not want to be understood as justifying having lengthy or growing waiting lists, but their size compared to the number of patients who go through the public hospital system is a small percentage. I could not reliably put a figure on the number in New South Wales, but it would be about one per cent-and that is perhaps an overstatement. The problem, as I said a moment ago, is not the actual number of people on that list but how long any one person on it waits. If one counts the numbers in the monthly statistics, one sees that many of those people are new numbers, but many have been there for the last three or four months.

We also found evidence, either from canvassing literature or asking people, that the waiting list problem is not new. It has been around for at least 20 years in more or less the same areas of specialty. That is a matter of concern. We suggested ways in which governments might like to consider addressing that matter-in particular, more movement between the public and private hospital provision.

Much could be said about this report. I think the Government's response to it suggests that we did provide very constructive information for the Macklin inquiry. I shall read very closely the papers that emerge from that inquiry. Already we are up to paper No. 4. I shall also look forward to seeing its recommendations to Government and how the comments in our report are taken into account by the Macklin inquiry. I believe that a few quotes from our report are already included in the most recently released paper.

We also in our report turned to private health insurance and suggested that there was room for considerable improvement in the private health insurance area. We discovered from senior surgeons that they could not advise their patients of how much it would cost because they could not read their way through the insurance forms either. I do not know how many honourable senators have recently looked at applications for private insurance, but one may have a gold star option or more modest bed assessments, and one can have extras or supplementaries. I find it somewhat challenging to work out the difference between an extra and a supplementary, but they have two very different meanings in terms of private health insurance.

Getting through what the private health insurance people are advertising is one of the challenges. Evidence was given to us, as I say, by senior surgeons that they could not help their patients because there was such a maze to read through. We would like to see the health insurance industry picking up on that comment and our recommendations to that effect. It should try to simplify the system so as to make it easier for people to understand and therefore to exercise their option to take out private health insurance.

We would like to see some serious deliberation and consideration about the whole private health insurance area. The wall around it from the rest of insurance means that it is a very comfortable area in some ways. Maybe it is time for the private health insurance area to take a long hard look at itself, and indeed for Government to look at it. For example, is it time to look at whole of life health cover that is included perhaps with superannuation, workers' compensation and so on? Could we be looking at a new way of providing health insurance that might make it an option that is more likely to be taken up, and perhaps even more likely to be less expensive?

We seriously looked at what has been used in the past, and that is the opting out of Medicare if one takes up private insurance. The Committee recommended strongly against this because of its dramatic capacity to cut into the efficacy and optimal outcome for Medicare. In particular, the Committee is concerned that the benefits of Medicare that have been now so well established are not diffused or lost. We do not want to go back to a sense of Medicare patients only being a stigmatised lot who cannot afford private health insurance or who are somehow less than virtuous in their health care provisions. Medicare has assisted through its universality and its cover of all in doing away with any of that kind of stigmatisation. We would certainly not want to see it return. We saw even on those grounds no good justification for the opting out provision.

Once one starts looking at the consequences of opting out-that is, the encouragement to take up private health insurance-one has to address the very serious question of what this will do to health costs. In general, it is an encouragement for them to increase because of the reduced restriction on what doctors will charge. It is within the category of privately insured people that we see a percentage of doctors who charge well above the schedule fee. They cannot do that for Medicare patients. So it is in the private health insurance area that this happens. We had anecdotal evidence about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they can charge above the schedule fee, and the Medicare patient pays the rest.

—Senator Walters might like to question that. I shall leave it to her to explain that to the Senate. Certainly we were concerned that if there was not that type of brake or check on those costs, that problem would arise. People took out private health insurance thinking that it would cover them, then they received a bill from the hospital and from their doctor that meant they were very much out of pocket. They thought they had bought private insurance to cover themselves but indeed, the very fact that they had private insurance put them more at risk in terms of an out-of-pocket expense. That was one of the reasons we were told, again only in anecdotal evidence, that people were not preferring to take out private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, representatives of the private health industry were unable to give us hard data on how many people might have left private health insurance for that reason. They were certainly concerned that there may be now almost a generation of people who had grown up without private health insurance, who had found their health needs were being met under Medicare provisions and who may never be persuaded ever to take it out again. Certainly, while the Committee appreciated the points raised by the private health insurance industry, we also recognised that we did not have the time or the direction under the terms of reference to fully and adequately canvass the area of private health insurance. So our recommendations went to highlighting areas that we thought could be usefully developed further. Indeed, in his response the Minister is suggesting that the Macklin inquiry take up those points and develop them further in its deliberations.

The real question that emerges from this report is that in summary there are numbers of issues that are of concern. For example, one is that we have an excellent public and private health system but we have different ways in which those systems are funded. The public hospital system faces a real challenge to try to manage within its budgets. We had evidence of the ways in which the public hospital system increases its funding or reduces its outlays by shifting its costs to the Commonwealth. One small example was that patients who previously would have been sent home with four weeks' supply of pharmaceuticals are being sent home with two or one week's supply. The rest they then buy through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme system and that is then an outlay from the Commonwealth. The highlighting of the pressures for cost increases against the capping of budgets means that less than optimal practices are happening, and that these are exactly the sorts of things that the Macklin inquiry ought to address.

We were also interested to hear a number of complaints by the representatives of the private hospital system that there was insufficient bed usage in their hospitals. However, the evidence given to the Committee, and very well documented, shows that the story is actually otherwise-that there is very good use of private hospitals, even though there is a reduced number of people with private health insurance, and that is largely because the move to day surgery and shorter stays in hospital has meant a very much increased throughput of patients in the private hospital system.

We also have to deal with what are described as efficiencies in the health care area, and these are ongoing challenges for those people who look at health economics. Essentially, an empty bed in a hospital is cheaper than an occupied bed, but that is not the sort of efficiency any of us who build hospitals or fund them would really be looking for.
Senator Coulter interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite so. Senator Coulter reminds me that we were very entertained by being reminded of the Yes Minister program that addressed exactly this problem. A very efficiently run public hospital-according to the television program-was able to economise splendidly by making sure that a bed was never occupied. We do not believe that is a way to encourage practice in this country and I do not believe it is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: We also appreciated that more use of public and private bed arrangements between the two institutions would be a very constructive thing to do. That is exactly what is happening in the Illawarra district of New South Wales. The patients, especially those with eye problems, are being treated at private hospitals. That is actually contributing very much to reducing the waiting time for people with eye problems in that area.

This has been a very useful inquiry. The Government recognises that we have contributed to the body of information that can be part of the health debate. We hope that, in some ways, by suggesting that we start focusing on facts rather than promulgating preferred fictions, we might assist in helping the community appreciate the challenges ahead of it in the health area.

We need this debate about rationing resources. The community cannot do that until it has those facts and figures presented to it. I hope the National Health and Medical Research Council is very successful in conducting that debate, just as much as I look forward to the final recommendations of the Macklin inquiry and the way in which it can make use of our contribution to that inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally reject the third paragraph of this Government response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: That this is a unanimous report which endorsed Medicare.

The Medicare system is in crisis; the Government has shown that by the establishment of the Macklin inquiry. The Select Committee addressed the problems associated with hospital costs and health insurance. If one asks people what Medicare is, one gets varied responses. Indeed, in the Select Committee's report it is defined thus:

Medicare is primarily a system for the distribution of funding to implement the Government's commitment to providing access to public hospitals and reimbursement for all Australians of a proportion of their medical costs.
On the other hand the Macklin inquiry defines Medicare in its latest paper thus:

Medicare is a national public insurance program. So the Government cannot even agree with itself in two different reports as to the definition of Medicare. Therefore, it is absurd to say that the report gives a unanimous endorsement of it.

In 1990 the Medicare levy, which is 1.25 per cent of income brought in $2,545m, while the Federal Government expenditure was $7,497m. If the Medicare levy were to bring in this amount of money, it would need to be increased to an extra 5 or 6 per cent of income. One must bear in mind that Medicare does not include the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS), nursing homes and hostels and the Department of Veterans Affairs and its repatriation hospitals.

The Macklin paper No. 4 has a quote that the public believes that Medicare pays for public hospitals and 85 per cent of doctors' bills and that one in five is unsure or incorrectly believes that private hospital care is covered under Medicare. So the public itself is confused about Medicare, let alone the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe). Page 2 of this report refers to the static proportion of gross domestic product consumed by health services, and I quote:

This makes explicit what has always been an issue in health care provision-the rationing of resources and the ethical problems associated with this. Because they are policy and ethical questions the community should be involved in addressing them. It follows that they must be resolved in the public arena.

Since this report was written, the New South Wales Government has produced a booklet, Health Care at Any Cost, to stimulate debate in this area. There are major problems in health care in this country at the moment, otherwise this Committee would not have addressed them, nor would the Macklin inquiry be addressing them.

There is the use and cost of technology, which is dramatically increasing at the moment. The use of pathology and radiology has increased 42 per cent per patient in the last five years. The medical service use per person has gone up 23 per cent in the last five years. Health insurance rates have increased by 72 per cent in the last three years, and have risen by 100 per cent in the last five years. The use and cost of pharmaceuticals has dramatically increased. The Government has made some attempt, by introducing co-payment, to rein in this cost but in 1990 it cost $1,500m and in 1982, $658m. There has been a dramatic increase in the population and the number of aged persons. We must bear in mind that two-thirds of health expenditure occurs on people over the age of 60 years. The population, which is now 17 million, has 2.6m over the age 60 years-15.5 per cent of the population. A little over five years ago it was 15.6 million and 2.3 million over 60 years of age. So not only is the population increasing but it is also rapidly ageing. Waiting lists have been referred to. The Australian Private Hospitals Association Ltd believes that at any one time there are 75,000 people waiting for admission to public hospitals.

Something that is not addressed in the report is the dramatic increase in the number of doctors in the community. It is estimated that there are over 38,000 doctors now in practice whereas 10 years ago in 1980 there were 25,700. The report by Sir William Keys on behalf of the National Office for Overseas Skills Recognition has been previously referred to. This year, 800 overseas doctors will be sitting for examinations so that they can be registered in this country to add to the burgeoning number of doctors who are coming into the community. The medical schools themselves already graduate 1,200 Australian students. The possibility arises of this dramatic increase being furthered by the National Office for Overseas Skills Recognition and, indeed, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. There has to be some resolution of this problem.

There are many other problems including the mal-distribution of health personnel where only 23 per cent of doctors are outside the cities; the gap between medical fees and Medicare refund which has been increasing; the increasing demand for nursing home beds; and the dramatic increase in pensioner health card holders, benefit card holders, sickness benefit card holders, and their dependants, which now totals 3.8 million of the population of 17 million.

There are also problems with the demand for screening in relation to mammography, acquired immune deficiency syndrome and other diseases. Costs in the public hospital sector are increasing 12 per cent per year. There has been cost shifting between the State and Federal governments particularly in relation to pharmaceuticals, which has already been referred to by Senator Crowley. Also of concern is the shifting of outpatients out of the hospitals into the private sector and the billing of privately insured public hospital patients. The Minister says that the Committee gives a unanimous report which endorsed Medicare. It is an unbelievable conclusion. The level of private insurance is now down to 43.1 per cent, whereas it was nearly 70 per cent only eight years ago, and capital investment in the public hospital system is now down to 3 per cent of recurrent costs.

This is supposedly a report which endorses Medicare. Page 6 of the report refers to the introduction of case mix base charges. Since the report was written I attended the inaugural national conference of the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals on Monday this week, 8 April. A paper was presented by Johannes U. Stoelwinder, who is chief executive officer of the Monash Medical Centre in Melbourne. He referred to an earlier paper entitled Dear Minister, Please Save Me From Case-Mix Funding, which was an open letter addressed to the Minister for Community Services and Health and which was published in the Australian Health Review last year. Stoelwinder states in this paper:

The model for case-mix funding is Medicare in the USA where it was implemented to contain the growth of costs. Australia does not have a problem with growth of cost. Our total spending on health care has hovered in the 7.6 to 7.8 per cent of GDP for over ten years. Hospital costs have been at 3 per cent of GDP over that time.

The economic argument about efficiency is essentially a theoretical one. Australian hospitals have, in fact, improved their efficiency as demonstrated by growing throughput with less beds by shortened length of stay. The economic argument goes that competition creates efficiency, our current funding of hospitals does not create competition between public hospitals and between public and private hospitals. Therefore, by moving to case-mix funding we will have competition and, ergo, efficiency.

While one can never argue that efficiency could not be improved (significantly, in my view), the lack-of-efficiency argument needs to be put to justify such radical funding reform. However, it would not be the first time that significant reform in the administration of the health system was based on a lack of credible need.
In other words, if it is not broken, why fix it? Page 41 of the Committee's report reads:
In fact there is no evidence that Medicare has encouraged overuse of either medical or in hospital services.

Since the report was published, the Department of Community Services and Health has published figures from the Medicare claims data file that show a rapidly increasing average use of medical services per person by State. In my own State it has increased by 23 per cent in the last five years and there has been an increase of 42 per cent per patient in the use of pathology and radiology.
Page 78 of the report in fact promotes private insurance and it reads:
The public sector has a vested interest in maintaining an active private sector, both to provide choice for some services to the community and to attract resources . . .
I believe this should be emphasised. Here we have the Minister saying that it is a unanimous report which endorsed Medicare. On page 101, the report reads:

The Committee therefore recommends that the Macklin inquiry establish a working party to examine the likely impact of reforming private medical and hospital insurance. The findings of the working party should be presented with the final report of the Macklin inquiry.
However, since that was written, again I have serious reservations about the impartiality and objectivity of the Macklin inquiry.

It has been brought to my attention that not only does the Committee have no practising doctor on it, but also its chairman is not an economist, neither does she have any medical or nursing expertise. She has been a researcher and journal editor at the Labor Resource Centre in Melbourne. This centre was opened by Mr Gough Whitlam in 1976 as a `research organisation supporting the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement'. The present Federal Minister for Health has been Chairman of the Centre's board of directors.
Ms Macklin presented a paper discussing the work of the Labor Resource Centre at the Marx centenary conference in 1985. In this paper she stated:
Over the time I have been thinking about strategies for the 80's challenging capitalism and building socialism.
Further she stated:
The essence of this is that it is a strategy for a war of position where we can gradually make incisive interventions into the sovereignty of capital.
Hardly a recommendation for conducting an impartial inquiry into the health insurance, health system and health strategy of this country. I no longer regard Ms Macklin as impartial and objective.

The Minister has stated that the Committee rejected proposals for changes to be made to the Medicare program. That is not correct. The Committee supported the principles of universality and simplicity but stated quite clearly on page 52:

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth seek to extend use of private hospitals by the public sector where it is a cost-effective way of providing treatment, particularly in specialist areas which are characterised by significant delays in providing elective treatment.
Further on page 78, the report reads:
The public sector has a vested interest in maintaining an active private hospital sector, both to provide choice for some services to the community and to attract resources into the health sector.

If the Minister needs any further evidence of the impending collapse of Medicare, I refer him to yesterday's Courier-Mail under the heading `Equipment loss may close clinic'. This article refers to the Royal Brisbane Hospital, the major and largest hospital in Queensland, where financial restrictions have left it with only two functional bronchoscopes, with operating theatres that are being closed and with lists being cancelled. My understanding is that the hospital has already exceeded its budget to the end of June and is now running in deficit. It is obvious that Medicare in its present form cannot sustain Australia's health system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on I am not too sure what because, for the first time while I have been in the Senate, we have a Government response to a report before we are actually technically debating the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance entitled Hospital Costs and Health Insurance and they are both on the same Notice Paper. But I notice that the previous speaker, Senator Herron, addressed both and Senator Crowley seemed to confine her remarks fairly much to the actual report rather than the Government's response to the report. Having said that and remarked on the peculiarity of the situation, I just wish to make some remarks on both the report and the Government's response to the report.
—We actually have the Government response before us but the Chair is quite amenable to your doing that.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. In his remarks, the previous speaker picked up on paragraph 3 of the Government's response, in which the Government is noting that the Committee had all-party representation and had submitted a unanimous report which endorsed Medicare. It seems to me that that is drawing somewhat of a longbow because, quite clearly, while endorsing the fact that a national health care scheme along Medicare lines needed to be retained-and it is something that I think everybody on that Committee did endorse strongly-the report, nonetheless, made recommendations for modifications, both in the public and the private area. So I think what is endorsed is the need for the underpinning of a health insurance scheme by a scheme which is very similar to Medicare, perhaps with some modifications. I would like to address some of those modifications in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things to which our report drew attention, and something which I have mentioned in this chamber on a number of previous occasions, is that there is a desperate need in the Australian community-indeed throughout the developed world-to encourage public debate on the emergence of new technologies, particularly expensive technologies, and the role which they should play in the treatment of patients. Both previous speakers have instanced examples of some of these very expensive technologies, their costs and what can be achieved with them.

It is quite unsatisfactory that the application, or non-application, of these technologies should be left in the hands of doctors or medical personnel in hospitals: for example, decisions about patients getting kidney transplants or heart replacements or lithotrity, which is mentioned, or some of the more expensive imaging technologies should be made under a cap of economic constraint and they should be made by medical personnel under that cap. It is quite clear to me, and it has been for a long time, that we need a wide-ranging public debate as to just what sorts of services should be provided. If there is to be a limitation on those services, that decision should be made by the wider community.

Unfortunately, in responding to that matter the Government draws attention to that fact and then says that the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) ethics and resource committee allocation will be looking at that. It mentions its desire to see a debate initiated on the ethics of resource allocation in hospitals. It says that the Government would be happy to see such a debate and will refer this issue to the NHMRC. It has made a partially positive response to that recommendation because, quite clearly, what is needed here is an ongoing debate. We are not at the end of the process of introducing new expensive technology; this process will continue. As these technologies emerge, we need to continue that public debate as to the application of those technologies, and the debate needs to range far more widely than just in the medical area.

It is not a case, as Senator Crowley mentioned, of whether we immunise 1,000 children against diphtheria compared with a very premature baby-I think that was her example-with little chance of survival whose care is associated with enormous costs. We need to consider the costs of medical care in the community against a whole range of other community needs. Is it more appropriate to provide more adequate pensions for elderly people so that they can live with a greater level of dignity or to provide better kindergartens for children rather than some of these increasingly expensive medical treatments? I do not choose to answer those questions for the very real reason that these are questions which really need to be opened up for public debate.

While it is true, as both previous speakers have said, that we have, quite remarkably, kept medical costs in this country to somewhat less than 8 per cent of gross domestic product for more than a decade, nonetheless, that cap is being administered by medical personnel under increasingly difficult circumstances. Doctors are being asked to make ethical decisions which should really be made in some wider context.

I am concerned that the Government has responded to this particular recommendation in a way which is far too narrow. We do need a debate, but we need an ongoing debate. It needs to be a very wide debate, not just within the medical area, and one which makes comparisons more widely with other social services provided by government. Of course, that debate might show-and here again insufficient figures are available on this-that some of the preventative medicine measures which have been implemented in recent years, such as health and education measures aimed at reducing smoking or health and education measures aimed at improving diet and exercise which have probably led to the significant reduction in coronary heart disease, may be a great deal more effective in dealing with these conditions than allowing people to develop diseases as a consequence of faulty lifestyles and then trying to pick up the pieces afterwards.

We do not know that at the moment. The results of such inquiry and debate may well come out with the opposite conclusion. Again, the results will emerge only if we spend more money in the area of health research. Even in the area of health education we do not really know what means of health education are more effective than other means: for example, whether certain types of advertising campaigns to encourage people to stop smoking are more effective than others or whether it is better to aim them at young people at this age or that age. A great deal more research needs to be done in that area.

I notice that the Government has rejected the NHMRC as a review body in relation to goals for public hospitals and public funding for health. If I recall correctly, the Committee made that recommendation because it cast around for a suitable body that was already in existence rather than face the task of creating yet another body.

I return to the point I made at the beginning: that the Committee quite clearly recognised the Government's acceptance, and the desirability, of having both a public and private health insurance program in this country. I will speak to that point for a moment. There is a strong tendency, in both government and opposition, to say that the market system will provide best for Australian society in a general sense; there is a tendency to leave everything to the market.

There was a clear cross-party recognition by this Committee that in the health area-and my own view would extend it to many other areas-the market system simply cannot provide adequately. The market system will make allocations which are inequitable. Left to itself, the market system would provide the second Rolls Royce for the rich before it provided the mere basics of medical care for the poor. It is in that context that a continuation of a publicly-funded-tax-funded-Medicare system is absolutely essential. In this context, it is distressing to note that where the Committee has recommended that it may be appropriate for the private health insurance system to go away, either entirely or partially, from community rating towards a risk-rating system-in other words, towards a more purely market-driven system-the Government rejects this totally.

In that response from the Government I see a very dangerous philosophy emerging, and that is that the Government also sees private health insurance as a necessary underpinning of an inadequate-and I stress, inadequate-Medicare scheme. If the Medicare scheme was adequate to provide the underpinnings, then it would not be necessary to impose the very complex community rating system which is imposed on private health insurance. If the Government really wants to get out of this confusion, it seems to me that it would provide a more adequately funded Medicare scheme and, at the same time, perhaps, allow the market system to operate more freely within the private health insurance area. The fact that it is not prepared to do that I read as a rather sinister sign of the continuation of inadequate funding of the public health care system.

Our report draws attention to the ageing of the Australian population. Previous senators' remarks also included reference to that increase in the age of the Australian population, the heavy dependence of some part of the aged population on health care and the high cost of that. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that while there is an increase in the age of the Australian population, two other factors bear very strongly on the costs of providing social welfare services in the health and other areas.

They are that the Australian population has fewer young people in it, and the overall total costs of providing education, therefore, may well be falling. The way that we might pick up the increased costs of supporting the elderly may be through a shift of resources. Secondly, as a consequence of the decrease in the number of young people in the Australian population, and even taking into account the ageing of the population, the number of working people in the community relative to the number of people who are supported-in other words, the dependency ratio in Australia, to use a demographic term-is better now than at any time since the Second World War and will continue to be like that for the next 30 years.

I think we need to be careful when we wave the flag of ageing population and say, `Whoa, whoa, whoa. We need to spend a lot more money in this area'. We need to recall that there are other demographic shifts in the Australian population which, if properly addressed, might well allow us to shift those resources to the areas where they are needed.
