In that connection our Committee recommended that if the current reinsurance scheme, which is part of the community rating scheme, is to be retained, then all over 65s should not be classified as a high risk group for reinsurance purposes. We are all aware that there are many people in the community over the age of 65 who are perfectly healthy and who remain healthy for many years, and within that group it is a much smaller group which is heavily dependent, particularly in the last stages of life, on the health care scheme.

The final point that I would like to pick up is the decrease in the number of people who have taken out private health insurance in recent years. Attention was drawn to that and it was made a feature of the evidence before the Committee. The Committee received some evidence, quite strongly put, that what was necessary was for the Government, essentially, to underwrite the private health insurance system so as to encourage more people to take out private health insurance. The evidence which we received on this point was controversial and conflicting and, in general, the Committee came to the view that if more money was to be put in, rather than underwrite private health insurance it would be better to more adequately fund the Medicare system.

If private insurance is steered towards a risk rating system it is quite clear that there will be some people who will be encouraged to go into private health insurance who now no longer take out private health insurance. The young and the healthy may well enter private insurance schemes because, for them, the costs would be much lower than at present where their health insurance premiums underwrite some of the risk being picked up by the elderly or people with chronic diseases.

On the other hand, there will be other people who would leave private health insurance because, under a risk rating scheme, the premiums would rise. As I recall the evidence before the Committee, it was that probably the numbers in private health insurance would fall still further to somewhere around 20 per cent. I seem to recall that that was the evidence before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends how you do it.

—Yes. That may be the system towards which we are moving. Perhaps we should move towards a system based on the philosophy, which is strongly espoused by the Government and the Opposition, that we continue to have a private health insurance system, but a private health insurance system which is based on risk rating, in other words, a free market type system. If we are to go down that road-and I return to the point that I made earlier-then the existing underpinning of that scheme through a publicly funded, tax based, Medicare type system must be far more adequately supported than it is at the present time. It is quite clear, as we move into these more expensive modes of treatment-and if we are going to apply those to the Australian community-that it is quite unconscionable that the rich will have access to those facilities and the poor will simply not have them available at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was absolutely staggered and amazed at the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. For the Government to claim that the Committee, which had an all party representation, submitted a unanimous report which endorsed Medicare was just not factual. It is a pity that the Government has resorted to that sort of falsehood to try to get some political advantage. How can a committee unanimously endorse Medicare when it puts forward six or seven recommendations-I have not counted them all-asking for change? That is not endorsing Medicare. It seems to me that there are so many flaws in what the Government has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also said in its reply-again, far from the truth-that the Health Insurance Commission, following its survey of the acceptability of Medicare by the community, found that more than 71 per cent of the population supports Medicare. He asked, very sarcastically, `When is the Opposition going to accept that it is here to stay?'.

If we have a look at the Health Insurance Commission survey, we come up with some very different figures. It says, quite rightly, that 71 per cent of people were in favour of Medicare, but-as with the findings of the Committee-51 per cent of those surveyed said that they wanted a change to Medicare, 45 per cent said that they wanted it kept as it is and 4 per cent were unsure. The change people wanted varied considerably from some minor change to an emphasis on making membership of Medicare voluntary. I am reading from the Health Insurance Commission report. What absolute rubbish and indeed misrepresentation the Government has put forward in its answer to the report.

The terms of reference the Committee were to look at were the effectiveness of the current health insurance industry structure, in particular, the ability of hospital Medicare to meet its two main objectives, namely, accessibility and equity and the type of restructuring which may be necessary to assist in this regard. I wonder why the terms of reference only mentioned those two objectives? The Department does not agree with that. Indeed, it says that Medicare's objectives have been concisely summarised as universality, simplicity, equity, accessibility and cost containment. I am reading from the report. That is what the Government's Department believed the objectives were. Cost containment is very important to the Department.

The definition of Medicare says that it is really just a place where money is handed out, first to the States and secondly to the private patients. In looking at the issues of universality and simpli- city, I agree that Medicare has been successful in those regards. Everyone is covered by Medicare and although not fair it is simple. But let us come to equity. It is pretty important that we look at equity and accessibility, and cost containment, because to my mind those are the most important objectives as seen by the people of Australia. Even the Committee admits that equity was compromised. And boy, how it is compromised!

I would like to read into Hansard a letter that was given to the Committee in evidence. It is a letter sent by the Medical Director of Williamstown Hospital to the Executive Director, the Director of Nursing and the Admissions Clerk. It says:

The financial position of the Hospital has deteriorated throughout the month of January and the over-run is now in the order of $385,000.00. This amount has to be recovered before the end of the financial year. In particular VMO-
that is, visiting medical officer-
payments are presently $92,000.00 over budget with pathology and radiology payments also over budget. These over-runs reflect a public/private mix of 66.2% public patients year to date-
that is, 66.2 per cent public patients to date this year-
an over-run of 6.2%. It is therefore necessary to adjust the number of public patients admitted for the balance of the financial year to the level budgeted for.

In consequence all future elective bookings of public patients will be on the basis that any number in excess of one public patient per elective list will require approval from the Medical Director. This restriction will not be introduced for patients for whom request for admission has been received as of today the 23rd February, 1988 but will be active for all requests for admission received after today. The restriction will remain in place until future notice.

That means that because this public hospital had an overrun and because, according to its budget, it had too many public patients, too many Medicare patients, being treated-66.2 per cent-it said that there would be no more public patients on elective surgery lists, except one on each list, until private patients were brought into the hospital to fill those elective lists. That is an extraordinary situation. My impression was that the public hospitals were there to serve Medicare patients primarily. But this public hospital in Victoria was told, and I would like to emphasise it:
In . . . future elective bookings of public patients will be on the basis that any number in excess of one public patient per elective list will require approval from the Medical Director.
What an extraordinary situation. Yet the Minister says that Medicare is effective and that Medicare has been `endorsed' by the Committee. The Committee was given that sort of evidence.

We now know that 41 per cent of people over 60 years of age are privately insured. That is 41 per cent of the majority of pensioners. About 700,000 pensioners are spending a large proportion of their pension on health insurance because Medicare cannot service their requirements. But 20.6 per cent of those privately insured have weekly incomes of $160 per week. What do people have to go without to pay private health insurance when they are getting only $160 per week? As to single parents with dependent children, 21.5 per cent of those privately insured have private health insurance. These people are struggling to make their priority health insurance because Medicare is not satisfying their requirements. As the Health Insurance Commission survey says, 51 per cent of people want changes made to Medicare. I have taken those percentages out of the latest Macklin background paper No. 4. So we have a situation where true equity and access-one of the prime objectives-does not exist in Medicare at all.

The Victorian public hospitals admit to an average waiting list of 20,400. Senator Crowley said that the waiting list figures were inaccurate and that there had to be waiting lists; she went on with all sorts of excuses. But when we see a letter written by the medical director to the admissions clerk of one of the public hospitals in Victoria, we certainly understand why those waiting lists are so high. Public patients are to be debarred from the hospitals because the hospitals have had an overrun in expenditure.

Chapter 2 of the report asks, `Is Medicare achieving its objectives?', but it does not answer the question. I was very surprised, knowing former Senator, now Professor Peter Baume as I do, that he did not insist on some aims and objectives. The requirement for the National Health and Medical Research Council to take up that recommendation to go into the aims and objectives was made because none were able to be put forward by the Department. Of course the Government is right in its response. The National Health and Medical Research Council cannot do it for the Federal Government because it is a State issue. That is one area where I believe the Government was correct in saying that it could not really give that task to the National Health and Medical Research Council to undertake.

In dealing again with waiting lists, I point out that the Australian Private Hospitals Association compiles a considerable number of statistics in this area. It says that about 75,000 Australians at any one time are waiting to be admitted to public hospitals. If Victoria has about 20,400, that figure of 75,000 is not a figure that anyone could dispute. I know that in my State at the moment in orthopaedics the waiting time for a hip replacement is about 85 weeks.

We then come to the other objective after equity and access, which is cost containment. Yes, cost containment has taken place because services have been rationed. From the report we see that over the five years between 1982-83 and 1987-88, 800,000 bed days have been cut from the public hospital system. That is some rationing and that is some way of putting a cap on the costs! But is it an equitable way? I certainly do not believe that it can be said that it would be particularly equitable.

I would like to go through the recommendations. The one that interests me and the one that I would agree with most is the recommendation that the National Health and Medical Research Council be asked to establish priorities for resource allocation decisions by the Government. Containing the costs of new technology in the health field is something we have spoken about for a number of years. Who makes a decision on who gets what medical service? Who is entitled to some of the most expensive medical costs when it comes to people with varying health problems?

I suppose that the National Health and Medical Research Council is as good a body as any to give the decision to. It cannot be given to the doctor treating the patient; every doctor wants to do the best for his or her particular patient. It cannot be given to the nurses; every nurse wants to do the best for her particular patient. Nor can it be given to the matron of the hospital. All are too heavily involved with both the patient and the patient's relatives to be able to say who gets the best health care in this country. What the Government is saying is that we must have a cap on the costs. If people are not prepared to pay more taxes for our health care, the Government has to ration health care. Senator Crowley spoke about that issue today.

The Committee has come up with the recommendation that this very difficult task be given to the National Health and Medical Research Council. I wish it the best of luck because I really think that that is perhaps the most difficult job that anybody could be asked to do. The mother of a four-pound baby would quite rightly want all the best health care and new technology, et cetera, for the care of that baby in order to give it a healthy life. I think that it would be very difficult for someone to tell that mother, `No, I am not going to allow that to occur. Your baby isn't worth saving.'. If the National Health and Medical Research Council can come up with something along those lines, I wish it luck. As I say, the other recommendation seeking the Council's assistance to define goals for public hospitals is a State matter and I do not see how it could be expected to come up with that recommendation.

As regards standards and aims I point out that at the moment 143 private hospitals have accreditation, which is 42 per cent. Only 23 per cent of public hospitals are accredited. Of course the standards for accreditation are the same for both public and private hospitals. So it is really up to the public hospitals to get their act together and have accreditation-to make sure that they come up to scratch with their standards. If they do not, the State or Federal Government has to supply the answer because patients will be requiring the standards to improve.

The Committee's next recommendation says that, where a case mix system for costing hospital services is introduced, private patients in public hospitals should be charged the full case mix base cost of their treatment to reduce the disparity between fees in public and private hospitals for private patients. I do not understand the justification for that. If as a privately insured patient I go into a public hospital, I have already paid my levy. Therefore, my costs should be taken into consideration in that public hospital.

The fact that I am privately insured but am using that part of my payment of the medicare levy means that I should get public hospital treatment free. A privately insured patient pays the levy, pays a private contribution to the fund, pays 25 per cent of the doctor's fee if he or she is in a private hospital and is paying over and over again. There is no justice in asking a private patient who goes to a public hospital for his or her fund to pay that amount in the public hospital. That person's levy payments should be taken into consideration and he or she should get the same treatment as someone else who is getting that treatment in a public hospital. I found it interesting that the Committee would recommend deregulation in community rating to allow experience rating.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the recess I was referring to the fact that the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance was recommending that deregulation of the insurance industry should look at getting rid of community rating and, instead, should look at experience rating, for example, by age, gender or group. I presume that means non-smokers or similar groups. It seems incredible to me that the Committee would go as far as to say that the industry should be deregulated to a very large extent by allowing it to opt out of the community rating and go into experience rating or at least that it should even be looked at. There are so many things against experience rating and, indeed, the Committee says further that the problems with experience rating could be overcome by having priorities made for the aged and chronically ill, for instance that they could be permitted to enter public hospitals first. The Committee acknowledges that there are a lot of problems with experience rating.

SPEECH.PARA: Later the Committee recommends that the Government should get into the private health insurance industry in a big way and to regulate it in another sphere. It recommended that the costs of standard fees for accommodation, approved surgical implant prostheses and same day treatment in public hospitals, including gap cover for 100 per cent of the medical benefits schedule should be mandatory for private funds. I find those two recommendations hard to understand. One recommendation says that the industry should be deregulated to a large degree and another says that it be regulated in another area. If surgical implant prostheses were included, the cover for private medical insurance would have to go up.

I refer to another main recommendation of the Committee which stated that National Health Strategy, known as the Macklin inquiry, establish a working party to examine the likely impact of reforming private hospitals and medical insurance. I do not know the Committee was set up. I thought that that Committee was to look at this matter but it seems to have ducked for cover. The Government has also indicated that it believes the Committee has already ducked for cover because it has handed the report on to the Macklin inquiry. The Federal Government has said nothing in its response to the report that would indicate that it was taking up any of the recommendations. It has handed the whole caboose over to the Macklin inquiry and the Committee is saying that it is not prepared to go into this matter in detail and that the Macklin inquiry should take it on by establishing a working party.

I have only a few moments left tonight and I would like to discuss just one other area in the report which I find incredible. The report says that the Committee could not find any evidence that Medicare had encouraged overuse of either medical or hospital services. I find that quite unbelievable because I know that several years ago the Joint Committee of Public Accounts dealt with this matter. Mr Deputy President, you will remember the Edelsten case in which there was tremendous controversy. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts found that Medicare had formed the basis of the overservicing, when it had inquired into that particular clinic, and that, had it not been for Medicare and the bulk billing that had been brought in under Medicare, Dr Edelsten would not have been able to rort the system in the way in which he had.

We know that Medicare had instigated all these entrepreneurial groups-not even doctors, but groups-of businessmen who set up these clinics and the overservicing that has gone on is not just in my imagination, because the Government has claimed it as well. Tonight Senator Herron said that to a large extent overservicing is attributable to these organisations. I believe that there is ample evidence and, as I said, the evidence brought forward by that particular Committee of the Parliament was sufficient. I cannot imagine how the Committee would have ignored that evidence and why that evidence had not been brought to its attention. Perhaps the Committee will have another look at it and put a small amendment to the report pointing out that that evidence is available, not only outside but also within the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in speaking to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, entitled Health Costs and Health Insurance, as one of the members who joined the Committee after 1 July 1990. At that stage the deliberations were fairly well down the track. However, we did undertake one set of hearings over two days in Sydney which I consider to be of great importance, great significance, and something I would like to recommend to other Committees, that is, we had an open forum. Prior to my going onto the Committee there had been a number of people coming before the Committee putting differing points of view. The private hospital associations, public hospital associations, private insurers and insurance companies were all disagreeing.

SPEECH.PARA: This open forum enabled us to put about seven different groups together. We were the catalyst for discussion which opened the eyes of those who were appearing before us as to the complexities of the problem in relation to health insurance and health legislation. It is a very complex issue. It is one that we wrestled with for some time. I think that this open forum was of great value and of great benefit and has given rise to a number of recommendations.

I am pleased with the Government's report in response to our report and I thank it for congratulating us on our hard work because a lot of hard work was done on that matter. Former Senator Peter Baume representing the Liberal Party was on that Committee and his contribution needs to be recognised, as does that of Senator Crowley, the Chairman.

Senator Walters has raised the issue of why we did refer a number of matters to the National Health Strategy, known as the Macklin inquiry. I think anyone would feel it was appropriate that we were looking at a small section of the health industry but when there is an inquiry on health matters, it is appropriate that we not come down with a number of conclusive and concrete recommendations but should make sure that our report was available for the inquiry. That is what happened.

I note also that our report has been used as one of the reference texts to National Health Strategy Background Paper No. 4, entitled A Healthy Risk? Use of Private Insurance. That report highlights what I thought was one of our key findings-that is, the complexity of private insurance arrangements. I agree fully with everybody who has written on this: private insurance arrangements are extremely complex, in the writing format and in the explanatory notes. I think there is a high degree of misconception and misunderstanding on the part of a number of people in the general community as to what their rights are when they have private insurance, at what level they have private insurance and how that impacts upon Medicare. The document states:

Strategies to improve public understanding of these issues need to be developed so that people can make informed choices about the relative merits of Medicare and private health insurance. That is a very important point because that is a very complicated and unclear area.

There has been some discussion about the relative merits of Medicare. For many years, I have been supporting, first, Medibank and then Medicare. With a health professional background, I have worked and cared for many people who felt discriminated against because they could not afford to buy private health insurance. In pre-Medibank days, someone visited people admitted to hospitals and conducted a means test. If the patient did not have a low enough income, they were classified as having to make a contribution. I have vivid recollections of people with chronic and acute illnesses, some of which were life threatening, signing themselves out of hospital because they could not afford what the health costs were going to be.

In the days of the Fraser Government, pre-1983, I worked in the community. I know of a number of families who did not get adequate care and medical attention for their children because they could not afford it and because they did not have health insurance. We need to remember that two million people, who should have had health insurance and were not covered under the previous arrangements, were forced to pay for every item of health cover or health treatment that they ever undertook. I know of people who could not afford health cover; I know of people who were eligible to be classified as disadvantaged but who did not want to be so classified. They did not want to be discriminated against; they did not want to be stigmatised by being labelled `disadvantaged'. If anybody wants to have a debate on Medicare, I am more than willing and more than ready to participate.

I commend the Government's response to this report. I also urge people to read Background Paper No. 4. I suggest that more people should work in the area of public health where they will learn what it is really like to have to balance a budget while one is sick.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDELINES FOR THE PREPARATION OF DEPARTMENTAL ANNUAL REPORTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

During 1989 both the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration completed inquiries into aspects of departmental annual reporting. Both Committees found extensive non-compliance with the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports. The Senate Committee and some witnesses appearing before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts advocated a review of the guidelines by the Joint Committee and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The document before us today is the result of that review.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry, which was numbered 304, found that for departmental accounting to be compatible with the emerging performance emphasis in management the approach to annual reporting must change fundamentally. If departments are to be judged by results, those results must be reported; and if annual reports are to facilitate and encourage assessment which emphasise results, annual reports must report those results. To do otherwise is to report, at most, half a satisfactory story.

The emphasis on results does not remove the requirement for reporting on resource usage and the methods employed. Parliament has an interest in what departments achieve, the cost of that achievement and whether the means used are acceptable. I am particularly pleased that the document before the Senate has consequently recommended clauses 26 and 27. Clause 26 states:
The annual report is to contain a separate section for each program, which discusses the major activities undertaken by the department.
Clause 27 states:

The annual report is to identify the operational approaches adopted and issues confronted in the implementation or maintenance of each program over the past year. Descriptions are to be provided of program activities and outputs, including those related to or arising from evaluations and program planning and review exercises.

Further, I remind the Senate of the change of name of the explanatory notes to `Program Performance Statements', which more accurately reflects the role of those statements. Program performance statements address the separate and more strategic issue of whether the activities have been effective in meeting program objectives. Unlike annual reports, the program performance statements present both a retrospective and prospective view of program performance and resourcing. In addition to reporting on outcomes for the past year, program performance statements present the strategies to be pursued and the outcomes sought for the coming year and identify the resources required to achieve them.
I am also pleased to see that the guidelines have incorporated recommendations Nos. 9 and 23 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I quote firstly recommendation No. 9:

Departments which perceive a need to produce an annual account of their operations for public relations purposes consider the cost effectiveness of producing a smaller document for that purpose if the annual report is considered too large.
For some time it has been a criticism that too much money has been spent on lavish reports. Recommendation No. 23 states:

Departments take necessary measures to ensure that they are able to reasonably estimate the costs and benefits of significant changes in business regulations for which the relevant Minister has responsibility.
Those recommendations are there for departmental heads and parliamentarians to note. I commend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes new legislation to provide bounty assistance to Australian manufacturers of citric acid by fermentation.

The Bill gives effect to the Government's decision announced in the Industry Statement to provide bounty support for the continued development and commercialisation of leading edge Australian fermentation technology in this area.

The bounty arrangements contained in this legislation provide in clause 9 for a bounty to be paid at a rate of $700 per tonne in the first year reducing to $150 per tonne in the final year. The bounty applies to citric acid produced from 12 March 1991 to 31 December 1995.

While the support relates only to the production of citric acid by fermentation, it has much wider strategic implications for the development of an Australian fermentation-based biotechnology industry.

A particular opportunity for Australia, given its competitive advantages in agricultural production, is the production of organic chemicals based on the fermentation of carbohydrates such as wheat and sugar. These chemicals are widely used in the food, cosmetic and health industries and include: proteins, enzymes, antibiotics, vitamins, amino acids, gums and organic acids.

The world market for chemicals produced by fermentation is estimated to be in excess of $10 billion per annum and, in the longer term, the technology offers the opportunity to replace many petrochemicals with ecologically sustainable products as well as to develop export opportunities in the food, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries.
At the moment, however, the realisation of this potential is severely threatened by price distortions in both the domestic and overseas markets.

Domestically, the structural adjustment arrangements currently in place for the sugar industry substantially increase the price of sugar over that available to producers in competitor countries. In this regard, opposition by the Coalition in the Senate precluded the adoption of the Government's original tariff proposals for the sugar industry which would have had less impact on domestic sugar users. Whilst a speeding up of tariff reductions on sugar was announced by the Government in the economic statement, domestic prices are likely to remain substantially above world prices for some time. This issue will continue to be addressed in the context of the forthcoming Industry Commission inquiry into the sugar industry due to report in March next year.

Internationally, governments are intervening to assist the production of citric acid and other fermentation based chemicals through subsidizing the price of fermentation substrates and by providing tariff protection to their local industries.
EEC producers, for example, are able to purchase sugar or other carbohydrate substrates at world competitive prices through a system of rebates on raw material costs.

In contrast to the duty free access of citric acid to the Australian market, tariffs of 30% apply in Indonesia, 24% in Japan and 6.0% in the USA. Imports into Australia are mainly from Ireland, China, US and Indonesian producers which benefit not only from subsidized raw material costs but also a protected domestic market. In other words, a combination of domestic and international policies have distorted the operating environment.

Since 1984, Sirius Biotechnology Limited has been developing technology in this field, originally invented by CSIRO. Some $14 million of shareholders funds has already been committed to the development of the technology and the commissioning of scale up production facilities. The first product developed by Sirius has been citric acid.

Sirius has also developed strong strategic linkages with industry and the research community. Research into a number of other applications of the technology is currently underway in collaboration with the CSIRO and the University of Melbourne.

In recognition of the strategic importance of the technology, its development has been strongly supported by the Government through the industrial research and development board programs. Sirius has received $375,000 in grants relating to citric acid production, and research projects with the CSIRO and University of Melbourne are receiving a total of $932,000 in Commonwealth funding.

The significance of the Sirius operation derives not only from the commercial opportunities for the technology. The skills and production facilities at Sirius represent a key base on which future fermentation based biotechnology potential can be built in Australia and are not available elsewhere.

In view of the importance of the Sirius technology and production facilities as the foundation of a carbohydrate-based fermentation industry in Australia, the Government has decided to introduce this bounty assistance scheme. The bounty is to be payable on the production in Australia of citric acid by the high technology production process involving the fermentation of carbohydrates in air lift fermenters. This is contained in clause 4 and clause 6 of the Bill.

The bounty is not a protection measure but is a support mechanism aimed at offsetting the distortions which prevent the intrinsic competitiveness of the Sirius technology being realised, enabling the company to achieve commercial viability in citric acid production.
This will provide a vehicle for the continued development and commercialization of the technology in new areas and the maintenance of a unique production facility in Australia.
In reaching a decision to provide support for this high technology production process, the Government considers it appropriate to make the bounty assistance contingent on a number of conditions.
This will be achieved by requiring bounty recipients to be registered under the Act, with registration subject to:
First, that the bounty recipient continue to research, develop and apply the technology to the commercialisation of citric acid in Australia;

Second, that the bounty recipient contribute to research in new product development arising from or associated with the fermentation technology the subject of the bounty, with a view to the commercialisation of those new products in Australia;
Third, that the bounty recipient explore international market opportunities for the technology and the product; and

Finally, that the bounty recipient take all reasonable steps to ensure maximum advantage is taken from the expertise and know-how associated with the development and production of citric acid and other new products in Australia by suitable licensing, franchise or other arrangements.

The Government considers support in the form of a production bounty, incorporating the conditions I have mentioned, is the most appropriate form of assistance. The level of support will be linked to success in commercialising the technology in Australia and it directly addresses the pricing distortions.

Sirius will need to make substantial investments in plant expansion in order to benefit fully from the support and its major shareholder, Bunge Industrial Limited, has indicated it will be commencing a program of research aimed at reducing the cost of wheat based fermentation substrates.

The Government is firmly committed to realising opportunities to apply Australia's scientific and research skills to the development of new industries in Australia. Few areas offer better opportunities than technologies which add value to Australia's intrinsic strengths in agricultural production, particularly in the food, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics sectors. The bounty, which is the subject of this legislation, is aimed at ensuring that the opportunity to capitalise on Australian developed technology for citric acid production as well as to build a substantial chemical fermentation industry in Australia, is not lost overseas. In addition, the bounty will position Australia to develop a strong international competitive base upon which to achieve significant net export growth across a number of sectors.
Financial Impact Statement

The amount of money available for the payment of bounty, or advances on account of bounty, under this scheme is limited by that amount which is appropriated by the Parliament for that purpose. This limitation is contained in subclause 11(2) and clause (30) of the Bill.
It is anticipated that the total cost of this bounty will be $7.27 million (in current prices) on a financial year breakdown as follows:
$1.05 million for 1991-92
$1.65 million for 1992-93
$2.17 million for 1993-94
$1.85 million for 1994-95
$0.55 million for 1995-96.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the accompanying Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the annual report of the Privacy Commissioner was addressed some weeks ago in the chamber, and I spoke on it then, more examples of corruption have been revealed by the investigations of the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) being undertaken at the moment. Evidence has come to light since I last spoke that the ANZ Bank has regularly obtained information from private investigators relating to the Department of Social Security (DSS), Medicare, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. The Westpac Banking Corporation has obtained government information from private investigators in a similar way to ANZ. The National Australia Bank Ltd has also obtained confidential government information from DSS, Telecom, Medicare, Australia Post and the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Through the ICAC investigations, it has also been demonstrated that one official from the Department of Social Security disclosed information about clients of DSS over a period of 15 years. When he left the Department, he passed on that role to another senior person in the Department. So the next person in line took on the role of providing that information. The second officer who provided the information, after the first officer's retirement, had responsibilities which included security of the DSS computer system.

It concerns me that this sort of evidence is coming out of ICAC. The Privacy Commissioner has, over two years-I have noted this before when speaking on the report-called on the Government to bring into force amendments to the Privacy Act to allow him to investigate the circumstances surrounding these events and also to investigate un- authorised disclosures. He wants the Privacy Act amended to allow him to impose liability for damages on those who procure the improper disclosure of such information and also to tighten up the criminal law so that it is amended to enable the prosecution of those who are party to these transactions and to place some liability on the principals.

Nothing has been done. Senator Tate has said that a code of conduct is being drawn up, but how, when and in what circumstances information about credit commitments should be disclosed has yet to be decided. Senator Tate claims that the aim of the legislation and the code of conduct is to require the consumer credit reporting industry to observe principles of privacy. But there is no mention that the code will make any mention of the direct or indirect use of personal government information that has been corruptly disclosed by public servants.

There are usually two parties in these things-a debt collecting agency, or an information service that provides information to organisations such as banks, and the public servant at the other end providing the information. There is no point in having legislation or codes which place restrictions on the debt collecting agency if there is no concomitant legislation to ensure that the information is not freely available, especially when we have recently had discussions about the claims transmission system that pharmacists will be using. Under that system, there will be more information available in the public arena-names and addresses of people-which can be used inappropriately. I think that as a society and as a parliament we need to address those issues. I am again calling on the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to address them. I have already discussed this with the Chairman.

One of the things that has come out of ICAC is the extent of corruption. Each week we are seeing more and more evidence of the extent of the corruption, which is of great concern. It ought to be of concern to all senators in this chamber that information about individuals, given for the purpose of social security or because one is receiving medical treatment, is then used and abused in other forums. I think we need to address this. I think that I need to constantly bring to the attention of this chamber the evidence that is coming out of ICAC.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Anti-Dumping Authority on its annual report and the work it does in investigating and identifying areas of dumping goods onto Australian markets. The report notes that under current Australian law the Government may take action against only one kind of dumping-that is, dumping which causes or threatens material injury to the Australian industry producing like goods to those being dumped, or which materially hinders the establishment of such an industry. A broadly similar rule applies in the case of subsidisation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the year of investigation, the Anti-Dumping Authority looked into a wide range of cases ranging from black lead pencils to outboard motors, woven bags, woven worsted fabrics, audio tape webs, cement clinker and bulk brandy. I do not know much about many of these goods, but I do know a little about the wide range of horticultural goods which are currently being dumped onto the Australian domestic market.

My colleague Senator Boswell has raised this issue on many occasions. He has spoken of the plight of many farmers who not only have to fight the rural crisis but also see their products competing on the supermarket shelves with goods dumped from overseas.

Last year I was able to speak to a motion raised by Senator Boswell on anti-dumping legislation. I was glad to be able to take part in that debate. Similarly, I was very pleased to be able to attend a luncheon last week when the anti-dumping committee was in Kingaroy looking at the problems being caused by dumping to the peanut industry and the navy bean industry in our town and district.

In the midst of the crisis currently hitting our rural community, Australia is importing about $2 billion worth of food products every year. Australian horticultural products are fast becoming an endangered species. The list is growing every week. First it was pineapples. Now it is bananas, canned fruit, peanuts, navy beans, peas, beetroot, beans, potatoes and other vegetables as well as apricots, dried vine fruits, rice, orange juice, apple juice, jams, mushrooms, dairy products and fresh meat. As Senator Boswell said last year:
A whole smorgasbord of imported foods is entering our market as cheap and subsidised products.

At the same time our farmers are having to plough back their products into the soil. This problem is not just one for farmers, but we can understand how farmers feel about the matter. I feel very upset about it. Certainly, too, I can understand housewives who under current economic circumstances try to buy the cheapest products when shopping. Who can blame them when we have seen our household incomes seriously eroded since this Government came to power? Many of those households now face life on the dole as unemployment rises, which the figures released today indicate. It is very sad that this figure has now rocketed to 9.2 per cent unemployment in Australia.

Of course, any sensible shopper will try to cut costs by buying cheaper brands, but with many of these dumped brands the products are not as tasty or as nutritious as Australian-grown fruit and vegetables. Most housewives would know that Australian-grown and Australian-processed products guarantee the best quality in the world. Our goods are grown under strict guidelines and processed under high standards of hygiene using the best and most advanced technology available. However, it is not only the farmers who suffer from the dumping of these products. Almost every part of the Australian community, both in the city and in the country, is affected. There is an entire support network servicing these farmers and their products, which is also affected. I am talking about the rural communities, the transport workers, the processors, the cannery workers, the packers, the storemen, the factory workers and, of course, in the end all Australian consumers.

As I said on this issue last year, it is bad enough that Australian farmers are suffering because of irresponsible policies of this Government and then having to compete in a corrupt and dishonest world trading market, but dumped products add another dimension to the problems of the rural industries. It means that farmers are having to compete on their home turf with inferior products which are deliberately dumped onto our domestic market. I commend the Authority on its excellent report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Grants Commission Report on Interstate Distribution of General Purposes Grants for Local Government is a very important document, particularly for local government. It results from a reference that was given to the Grants Commission by the former Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Stewart West, and following the decision made at the Premiers Conference on 18 May 1989. In those terms of reference the feasibility of three options was included. The major one in which local government is interested relates to whether the application of the principle of fiscal equalisation was appropriate to determine the distribution of this assistance in the future. I, like many of my colleagues, and I imagine quite a few members of the Government and perhaps the Australian Democrats, have received many letters from different local government bodies since this report was put down.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government representatives, quite rightly, ask why local government funds should be distributed in a different way from the way in which the States are funded. The States have been funded under a fiscal equalisation principle for many years, yet local government has had different and varying methods of funding for quite some time. When I was a warden of a municipality in Tasmania our funding was distributed under a system of part needs and part per capita funding. The Government decided to adopt one of the recommendations of the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and move to the funding of local government on a per capita basis, and in the past five years this has happened. That has had varying effects on different councils. In Tasmania, for instance, we have gone from around 3.4 per cent of the funding down to about 2.1 per cent, and in the last year we received a minus percentage increase. On the other hand, those States with a large populace in local government areas received more under the per capita system. Now it seems that the role will be reversed, and it is not surprising that local government authorities in New South Wales and Victoria are making their voices heard.

When one looks at some of the theoretical results, at what could happen under fiscal equalisation, one notes that New South Wales, which currently receives $243m, would possibly receive only $81.9m. Victoria would go from $182m to $90m. That is under a complementary relativities system. To make matters a little more complicated-and the Treasury and the Office of Local Government support fiscal equalisation in principal-the present Government, I understand, intends to absorb road funding into general purpose assistance grants. If we look at what could happen under that scenario, we would find that in total New South Wales, for instance, which would have received $320m, would have its funding reduced by $176m to $144m. Obviously one can understand why New South Wales is getting upset.

Set out in the report are three options. The first option relates to a system that is similar to State Government funding; option two contains some variations; and option three has even more variations. It is not the last we shall hear about this matter. I shall be interested to learn the attitude of the Australian Local Government Association. It has not yet decided on its attitude to the report, but whatever happens I hope that parochial matters or parochial interests in different States will not have the effect of ruining what I believe is a very good report which has set out for everyone to see the options that might occur in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The reports of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody make for very sober reading. They all highlight the tragic details of lives lost unnecessarily, and the documentation in this report of the life and death of Faith Barnes is particularly poignant. Not much is known about Faith Barnes, but what is known presents a depressing picture. It is not even certain where or when she was born. She was probably born in Kalgoorlie, as this is more commonly given in government records as her place of birth.

Her mother died in August 1957 when Faith was not yet three. Little is also known of her childhood or her schooling. Apart from the respiratory problems, which led to her hospitalisation at Princess Margaret Hospital, Faith Barnes suffered during her childhood from a considerable number of minor ailments of a kind which generally result from poverty and deprived living conditions. These are noted on her records from the Menzies Nursing Post and include sore eyes, infected wounds, burns, boils and scabies.

Between the time when she was 21 and her death at the age of 27, Barnes was the victim of numerous severe assaults. She was admitted to Kalgoorlie Regional Hospital for head injuries on five occasions, received outpatient treatment on two occasions and was treated at the Menzies Nursing Post on nine occasions for head injuries. During this period she also received treatment many times for other traumatic injuries to various parts of her body.

On 21 October 1982, only a week before her death, she again attended the hospital. It was noted that she was having difficulty in breathing and smelled of alcohol. She complained of pains in her chest and thought that she was at risk of having a fit. The report says that attendances such as this may have represented a cry for help from a person who retained sufficient insight to perceive the hopelessness of her own condition.

The death of Faith Barnes presents a picture now familiar to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. At about 11 am on 26 October 1982, she was found lying, apparently asleep, in the street beside the Kalgoorlie Police Station. She had, it seems, been there for at least an hour. Known to have an alcohol problem, she was thought to be drunk and taken to the lockup without any further inquiry being made as to the cause of her unconsciousness. She could not be roused and had to be carried or partly dragged to the exercise yard where she was left lying on the bare concrete.

A number of cell checks were made between that time and four in the afternoon when it was noticed that there was dried blood on the side of her head. After further attempts to rouse her were unsuccessful an ambulance was called and she was taken to the Kalgoorlie Regional Hospital. There Barnes was found to be semiconscious but unresponsive to spoken command.

Admitted in the early hours of the following morning, she was found to have a severe head injury. An emergency operation was performed to remove blood clots from inside her skull. After surgery had been completed she suffered an unexpected cardiac arrest. Resuscitation was unsuccessful and she was declared dead at 7.36 on the morning of 27 October, 1982.

Faith Barnes did have a severe alcohol problem. The report concludes that her treatment by those who took her into custody at Kalgoorlie for the last time was totally devoid of kindness or humane consideration and that her treatment at the hands of some members of her own community was even worse.

Between 1975 and her death she received medical treatment for head injuries on at least 16 occasions, being admitted to hospital on at least five of these occasions. A proportion of these injuries resulted from severe assaults. She was also treated for other traumatic injuries at various times.

It is not know how she came by the severe head injury which caused her death, but however she did come by it the neglect demonstrated by the Kalgoorlie police responsible for her custody is described by this report as `disgraceful'. She should never have been placed in custody in her semiconscious condition without a prior medical examination to ensure that her unconsciousness was alcohol related as thought and not caused by injury or illness.

The report claims that the indifference of those responsible is even more reprehensible when one considers that another Aboriginal, Roy Norman Walker, had died the previous year after being held in custody in the same lockup in similar circumstances; that is to say, while unconscious as the result of a severe head injury when thought to be drunk.

Her death is associated with a neglect not only by those responsible for her custody but also by the wider community, which regards those known as fringe dwellers as a public nuisance to be put out of sight and out of mind. I quote from the conclusion of the report:

Until the community addresses the problems of these unfortunate people, they will continue to die like Faith Barnes in circumstances which will bring them back to haunt the conscience of thinking Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Bernard Albert McGrath was in a public house when he was apprehended under authority of a warrant by two police officers, one of whom was Senior Constable Suiter who knew Bernard.

Bernard was asked to leave the tavern with police officers and did so without offering any resistance. He was then taken to the Kalgoorlie Police Station and lodged in the lockup shortly after 11.50 p.m. This case is important because it concerns an Aboriginal person in the custody of police who was, on the evidence before the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, killed-probably by other prisoners also present in the gaol. Therefore, the police failed in their duty to properly supervise persons in their custody and, a little like the Gundy case, continued to cover up, after the death was discovered, the circumstances in which Mr McGrath met his death.

Let me return to the facts of the case. Bernard was not eligible for bail, essentially for the reason that the warrant commanded that he be apprehended and brought before the Kalgoorlie Court of Petty Sessions to answer the complaint that he failed to complete 50 hours of community service as ordered previously in 1986. We should pause and consider that here we have a person who had failed to complete 50 hours of community service-obviously a penalty imposed commensurate with an offence which could not have been too serious and which was given to him to enable him to rehabilitate himself, and yet in these circumstances he met his death.

The evidence before the Commission shows that Mr McGrath was placed in the lockup together with two other prisoners who, previous to the events described in this report, claimed that he had on numerous occasions-including to some police officers-made the comment that he wished to kill himself. Upon being placed in the cell with those two prisoners, he took a towel and tried to place it around his neck and on a doorknob. Subsequently, evidence was given by one of the other prisoners that another had torn a strip from a towel, put it around Bernard's neck and around the doorknob and virtually said, `Well, there you go'. This happened while Mr McGrath was in the custody of police in a police station.

Some of the constables were subsequently charged under police regulations and convicted for their failure to act on the claim of one other-a third prisoner who reported the death but who was not believed by the police who were in another part of the police station. The total sum of these events showed an extremely casual, not to say contentious, attitude by the authorities to people in their custody.

It does recall to our minds the fact that we have just passed in this Senate the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill, which limits the time that police officers may inter- rogate the person. There has been a fair amount of controversy about the restrictions that we are able to place on police officers. I believe that events such as the death of Mr McGrath fully justify caution to the extent to which we are prepared to give latitude to law enforcement officers. These are the persons who are not used to our legal system but are placed in their custody.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to speak to this report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which concerns the inquiry into the death of Ricci John Vicenti. Ricci died at the age of 19 in the Royal Perth Hospital late on the evening of 31 March 1982. He had been shot in the head by an armed prison guard in the course of his attempted escape from the remand centre in Canning Vale. Vicenti was a remand prisoner at the time he was shot, having been remanded by a magistrate in the East Perth Court of Petty Sessions for the preparation of the pre-sentence report which was put in, having admitted four charges of breaking, entering and stealing.

In order to effect his escape, Vicenti somehow climbed on top of the roof and negotiated a number of walls and barbed wire entanglements. He was seen by a prison officer, who warned him and subsequently fired a warning shot which was well wide of the prisoner. When Vicenti tried to escape, the prison officer shot, aiming not to kill, according to his evidence, but at the lower mass of the body. These were the words of the prison officer. As it was, the shot actually lodged in the head of Vicenti who died.

There was no suggestion in the report that the prison officer concerned acted in excess of the regulation covering his behaviour. It would appear that prison officers in this situation, after having warned an escaping prisoner and having fired a warning shot, may then shoot to kill. I believe that this raises the question of whether we, as a civilised society in these circumstances, should condone such actions and whether we feel that prisoners who are in an institution and try to escape should do so at the risk of their lives. We should consider carefully whether we wish to place people's lives at risk in that sense and whether the protection of property and public law and order extends to the licence to kill when somebody in custody attempts to flee. I leave that question open for the consideration of honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the Advance to the Minister for Finance for March 1991. I particularly want to take note of the advances through the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the Antarctic Division. The first part of the Advance requires an amount of $67,720 for the purpose of providing for the transport program to resupply the stations, et cetera. Attached to that is a letter from the Assistant Secretary of the Portfolio Coordination Branch to the Secretary to the Department of Finance. I actually get a mention in that letter because I had previously raised the matter about the spillage of station fuel and, as is pointed out in this letter, I was totally incorrect. I apologise to the Senate for making a comment that a few hundred thousand litres of oil was spilt when, in fact, only about 20,000 litres of station fuel was spilt. I certainly was wrong. I think it was a slip of the tongue because I was aware that it certainly was not hundreds of thousands of litres. But, anyway, I probably got carried away in the heat of the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, there is a difference in what I had believed because the original $700,000 extra asked for was, of course, for bunker fuel. The reason is that the price of bunker fuel oil increased quite startlingly because of the Gulf war situation. I am pleased to note that there was then a credit of $81,000 because of a reduction in the price during the course of those negotiations.

The second request is for an amount of $158,696 to effect a legal settlement. It does not mention here what it is about and I have no argument about its correctness. But I will be pursuing that matter in Estimates committees to find out what it is about, because $158,696 does seem a fair amount of money in relation to a legal settlement.

The first application talks about extra contractual requirements for the Aurora Australis and the Iceberg. I might just pass on to the Senate a matter I noted during the week regarding the Aurora Australis because I think it is rather sad. A magazine article from the Australian Ships and Ports magazine of March-April 1991 is headlined `Carrington Slipways in receivership-What happened?'. Through the article it says what went wrong. It states:

Carrington Slipways was a close knit family type of organisation. It appears that some of the founding members of the team left the company and the successful ingredient which was then lost, needed to be reworked. Whether or not the new team were galvanised as well as the original team will never be known.
Further on the article points out:
Without doubt the mortal blow to Carrington Slipways was the construction of the icebreaker `Aurora Australis'.
It goes on to say:
This vessel . . . should have been constructed overseas. No doubt through the Australian Government's wishes, the `Aurora Australis' was built in this country.

I have always supported the building of the Aurora Australis in Australia and I am on record as saying that. But I was against the fact that, through matters which the Auditor-General has already pointed out, contractual agreements between P and O Polar, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd and the Government in fact cost Australia $25m more than it should have. Anyway, it is very sad to see that Carrington has gone into receivership. I still believe the decision to build the ship in Australia was right. I was very concerned to read this article.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue my remarks on the annual report of the Australian Institute of Criminology. Senator Baume has already referred to the timing of this particular report, with qualifications, and I will not go into that aspect. An institute such as this is regarded as having a function of rigorous research and members of parliament should be able to presume that an organisation which receives in excess of $3m of taxpayers' money should be beyond reproach in its research activities. The Institute does of course conduct some very interesting, detailed and rigorous research, but its credibility is undermined by the selection of one or two researchers-particularly the Deputy Director of Research, Dr Wilson-as publicists.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to the question of the credibility of this organisation, I refer particularly to the continuing attempts by Dr Wilson of the Australian Institute of Criminology to belittle the work, or at least the overall majority view, of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material so far as that view relates to X-rated videos. That Committee held extensive discussions and received extensive evidence, yet Dr Wilson continues to quote the National Committee on Violence which he and the Institute acknowledge paid scant attention to the question. Indeed, at the last Estimates Committee E hearings-I refer to pages E99 to E103 of the Hansard-I challenged Dr Wilson about an article that he had written. I referred to a statement by Dr Wilson from an article which appeared in the Melbourne Herald on 21 February 1990, in which he said:
Despite intense pressure, the committee-
that is, the Committee on Violence-
in its final report backed away from advocating increased censorship of X-rated movies.

Dr Wilson admitted that there was no intense pressure. I invite honourable senators to read that article. Honourable senators might recall that the same Dr Wilson criticised the findings of the Meese Commission on Pornography in the United States and cited, in support of his opposition, persons named Nobile and Nadler. It was not until later that we found out that Nobile and Nadler were, respectively, the Editor and Deputy Editor of Penthouse Forum magazine. In fact, Professor Donald Downs, in an article in the American Bar Foundation Research Journal, said of Nobile and Nadler:

Unfortunately, Nobile and Nadler are absolutist libertarians with axes to grind . . . not only do they reject any restraints on sexual material . . . but they treat all opposing views as presumptively illegitimate and intolerable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) deplores the appalling abuse of the Kurds in Iraq by Saddam Hussein and his military;
(b) notes that the UN Security Council Resolution on the ceasefire did not include provisions to protect minorities in Iraq;
(c) regrets that the Australian Government failed to lobby for the inclusion of such provisions; and
(d) urges the UN Security Council to take such action as is necessary to end this human tragedy.
I was struck this morning by a news report, the first few lines of which I will read. It had come in from Cukurca in Turkey and it stated:
Six small bodies of Iraqi refugee children, wrapped in muddy wet towels, lay in the mosque of this border village today.
They had perished of cold at a makeshift camp overflowing with families who fled Iraq in terror of Saddam Hussein and who are now fighting to survive freezing rain and hunger.

``Kill me,'' shouted Ihsan, a middle-aged Iraqi jostling with a soldier trying to push back crowds fighting for bread. ``Drop a chemical bomb on us. It is better than dying slowly like this.'' Two other bodies lay beside the dead children in the mosque-a man of 40 who died of exposure and a girl of 18.

This is a matter of enormous international embarrassment. It is something of which the entire international community should be ashamed. At the end of the Gulf war the Kurds and other minorities were encouraged by the allies-and we should remember that Australia was part of that alliance-to rise up and replace Saddam Hussein. But they had no capacity to do so and they have been ruthlessly dealt with by Hussein's military. They have fled to the north, to the borders of Turkey and Iran. We are told that on the Turkish border there are now some 300,000 Kurds; some on the Turkish side of the border and some still on the Iraqi side. Some have been restrained from crossing the border, an area of windswept mountainous terrain. At this time of the year it is freezing cold.

On the Iran border there are even many more. It is estimated that there are about 900,000, expected to rise to perhaps 2 million, and many have crossed as Iran has allowed more to cross, although there have been recent reports that that border has closed as well.

The ceasefire agreement that was negotiated at the end of the war contains no protection for minorities. It did, in fact, permit the retention and use of helicopters by Saddam Hussein from which he has attacked the Kurds, his own people, since. The subsequent Security Council resolution on the ceasefire to which I referred a moment ago, although in many ways the most comprehensive resolution of its kind in the history of the United Nations (UN), also gave no security for the Iraq minorities.

Australia could have lobbied for the inclusion of such protections in that resolution but it failed to do so. We raised the question with Senator Gareth Evans the other day as to why Australia did not argue for the inclusion of such basic protections in the resolution, as we lobby for many variations to Security Council resolutions even though we are not presently a member of the Council. Senator Evans's reply to that question was as follows:

Australia is well aware of all of these developments as they are occurring in the United Nations, and it is simply a matter of making a judgement as to whether or not there is anything more we can usefully do than is already happening as these things are negotiated to fruition. We made the judgement that, particularly given our status as not being a current member of the Security Council, there was little we could add to a very lively debate on these issues that was already proceeding. That is the view that we continue to hold.

That is a most disappointing statement from the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Basically, it is a statement in which he indicates that Australia washed its hands of the issue because it was too difficult, it was a complex matter and we are not currently a member of the Security Council. As he said, in his view there was little that we could constructively add, so we did not make any effort to include the basic protections that were necessary within that resolution.

There are those who will argue-and it has been said by those defending this position on behalf of other nations-that it would be inappropriate for the United Nations to act because this is basically a matter internal to Iraq. I thought that that particular question was addressed very ably by Douglas Davis, a correspondent from London, reporting in the Australian on 5 April 1991. He looked at that question and said:
But such a narrow, legalistic ledge is proving to be a perilous perch for those who seek to justify their position on the spectator stands of this tragedy.
I could not express it any better than that, because that is exactly what Australia has done-it has stood on the spectator stands of this tragedy and has taken no action at all.

The narrow, legalistic ledge that he talked about simply does not stand up to current analysis. The UN Security Council resolution which was passed shortly after the one on the ceasefire condemning the abuse of the Kurds, in fact, leaves open the capacity for the UN to maintain its sanctions against Iraq while these abuses continue. So the United Nations, through that, has indicated that there are sufficient international aspects to this conflict to allow it to so act. We already have the precedent that the United Nations will not rely on that narrow, legalistic ledge.

Clearly, the abuse that is occurring at the moment in Iraq arose out of the war and the settlement of the war which, of course, was an international matter. What is particularly distressing is that one suspects that it would have required little or no enforcement. If, at the time of the ceasefire, when Saddam Hussein's generals sat down in the tent, they had been told that one of the conditions that they would be expected to comply with was to demonstrate respect for their own people, I am sure that no further action would have been taken. Saddam Hussein was simply not in a position to negotiate, in the same way that he did not negotiate any of the other terms that were imposed upon him in that ceasefire.

It is a lesson that we have not learned. One suspects that if the international community had been equally as firm with Saddam Hussein when he was demonstrating an intention to invade Kuwait, indicating that it would have been intolerable to the world community and would have brought a massive response, that invasion would not have taken place. But the message was not given on either occasion.

Why was it not given? One suspects because of fears of the reaction of countries such as Iran, Turkey, Syria and the Soviet Union, all with Kurdish communities; fears that if the Kurds gained autonomy, or some form of independence in Iraq, perhaps that sentiment might spread to adjoining countries' Kurdish populations and that would be something that they would regard as unsatisfactory.

There were also concerns about encouraging other minorities. As the Senate is aware, at this invitation of the international community the Shi'ites also rose up in southern Iraq and were beaten down, and the international community stood aside, one suspects because the Shi'ites were supported by Iran and there was a view that Iran should not be given any further encouragement or be allowed to attain a power base within what is now Iraq.

What that means is that the old balance of power arguments still rank supreme, and the question of balance of power is seen as more important than basic humanitarian concerns. It demonstrates what little progress has really been made towards-using this engaging expression-a new world order. It indicates that there is such a long way for the international community to go before it is prepared to use its international might to stop the sorts of abuses that we are witnessing in Iraq at the moment.

Again, we have not observed the lessons of history. If we look at the Kurds, they have been abused over the centuries by the Persians, the Turks-the Ottoman Empire-the Arabs and, in more recent times, Saddam Hussein in the most atrocious way that one could imagine. Whereas they may now say that they were encouraged by the international community to rise up, in the mid-1980s they were encouraged in Iraq by Iran to rise up during the time of the Iran-Iraq war, and they did so. At the end of that war, in 1987, the revenge of Saddam Hussein upon them was absolutely appalling. One remembers the use of poison gas. In one village alone more than 4,000 Kurds died in a cloud of poisonous gas-that is the town of Halabja-according to the magazine the Economist which has not been disputed. In 1988 the Iraqi offensive to put down the Kurds was brutally effective.

What then happened is that they were forcibly moved by Saddam Hussein out of their villages. It is believed that four of every five Kurdish villages in Iraq were levelled over the years by Saddam Hussein. They were forced to the south. Of course, after the victory of the allied forces they moved back to the north and sought to regain their ancestral lands, only to be attacked by Saddam again and forced to flee, as I said, to refuge in either Iraq or Turkey and to have the vengeance of helicopter gunships turned on them and even the Scud missiles that became so prominent during the war.

The world community has now finally reacted. There are those, particularly Britain, arguing for a temporary zone in the north of Iraq that will give them relief, and that has some international support. Although the United States does not quite support it in those terms at the moment, it has nevertheless taken the step that I and many others would have liked to see it take some time ago, and that has at least delineated part of Iraq in which it will not tolerate Saddam Hussein attacking his own people. The British, I am pleased to say, see this as only a temporary measure. Their second objective after the provision of a short term safe haven is to enable the refugees to return to the safety of their homes. That must be the ultimate objective.

We are faced with an immediate humanitarian concern to which we must respond. I am pleased that the Australian Government is at least providing a minor response in the form of some money. We will no doubt be faced with a refugee question to which we and the rest of the international community must positively respond. But the real answer is to ensure that conditions pertain in Iraq that will allow the Kurdish people to return to their homelands and to be able to live their lives in security and peace.

A delegation of Kurds visited this place the day before yesterday and saw the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and I saw them with Dr Hewson on behalf of the Opposition. They made the point that their community was not looking for independence; they did not want an independent state, which they once had. They asked for reasonable autonomy so that they could practice their religion and their culture, and peace and security in their ancestral lands, which does not seem to be an unreasonable request. They asked the international community to ensure that those reasonable conditions upon which they could live were open to them.

I urge this motion upon the Senate in circumstances in which I do not think Australia can be proud of its contribution to date. I particularly urge as most important the last paragraph of the motion, which proposes that the Senate urge the Security Council, on behalf of the international community, to take such action as is necessary to bring to an end this human tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion moved by Senator Hill dealing with the tragic situation of the Kurdish people. First of all, I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that this is not the only motion of which notice has been given this week dealing with this situation. I gave notice of a motion on Tuesday in the Senate and Senator Vallentine yesterday gave notice of a motion on the same matter. I think Senator Hill moved his today, and I do not know from the record whether any other senators moved motions dealing with the situation of the Kurds. This is a matter of considerable concern to all members of parliament on all sides and to the Australian community.
