SPEECH.PARA: A number of people-members of the community in my own State-have spoken to me about what they have been observing on the television over the last couple of weeks concerning the terrible experience which ordinary Kurdish citizens are suffering as they attempt to flee the attacks of the army of Saddam Hussein.

Although I can agree with much of Senator Hill's motion, I cannot agree with parts of it, because I think he has attempted to bring a partisan note into this tragic situation by attacking the Australian Government. My motion dealt with the same issue. It read in part, `notes and supports the Government's speedy response'. I understand that the Opposition objected to that part of the motion yesterday and to the motion being dealt with as formal. I am not going to debate here at great length why I thought that was a reasonable proposition to put forward and why I think the Opposition was unreasonable to object to that so that the motion could not be treated as formal. In a moment I will give some details of the Australian Government's response to this tragic situation.

I believe that my motion could have been accepted quite reasonably by the Senate as a formal motion. There are parts of Senator Vallentine's notice of motion of yesterday which I would find totally objectionable and which I do not think are factually correct, but obviously she may argue with me about that. I think Senator Vallentine's notice of motion was based more on trying to justify her position in opposing the United Nations (UN) resolution, supported by the allies, to evict Iraq from Kuwait. I do not think Senator Vallentine does her cause much good by trying to blame the problems of the Kurdish people on the fact that the allies were successful in liberating Kuwait. She attempts also to try to talk about the new world order in a way that is quaint, to say the least.

In dealing with Senator Hill's motion, which we now have before us, I would like to make a few comments, as a member of the Government, about what the true situation is and the way the Australian Government has quite responsibly responded to the developing situation. I think it has acted with all reasonable haste in dealing with a situation which is extremely complicated and is changing every day.

Australia, like most members of the international community, has been appalled by the actions of the Iraqi armed forces in bombing, rocketing and shelling Kurdish civilians while putting down a revolt in northern Iraq over the past few weeks. The Australian Government has expressed its outrage as the full scale of the tragedy has emerged, and we have unreservedly condemned Saddam Hussein's Government for this latest example of unconscionable brutality. As a Government senator I take this opportunity again to repeat that condemnation, which all members of the Government would support.

The Iraqi Government's reaction to the Kurdish uprising was entirely in character. Over the last decade at least, Saddam Hussein's Government has demonstrated a degree of ruthlessness in suppressing domestic opposition and a disregard for human life in its international ventures unparalleled elsewhere in the world.

Australia has been active in international forums, particularly the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, in highlighting Iraq's human rights record. At the Commission this year, for instance, we co-sponsored a resolution appointing a special rapporteur to examine the human rights situation in Iraq. In 1988, the Iraqi military used chemical weapons against Kurdish civilians. I am sure that few of us can forget the photographs of women and children collapsed in doorways and on footpaths having been caught by the poisonous cloud of gas. Australia was one of the first countries to express its condemnation of that outrage and we moved quickly to provide an expert to the United Nations investigation of that tragic incident.

The UN Security Council resolution-resolution 687-establishing a cease-fire in the Gulf war was adopted on 2 April. It is probably the most complex resolution ever adopted by the Security Council, and the most intrusive in the sense of imposing international supervision of Iraq's disarmament program and of its reparation program for damage caused in Kuwait. Prior to its adoption, the resolution had been negotiated over more than two weeks, in the first instance amongst the permanent five members of the Security Council, then between the Permanent Five and other members of the Security Council.

When the resolution was first drafted and throughout much of the negotiating period, the situation in Iraq was quite unclear. Kurdish rebels had captured several cities in the north and Shia rebels were making progress in the south. In this chaotic situation no-one knew whether Saddam Hussein's Government would survive.

By the time it became clear that the Iraqi forces were winning the war against the Kurds and that a flow of refugees had commenced, resolution 687 was in the final stages of negotiation. It was recognised then that any attempt to expand its ambit to provide protection of minorities inside Iraq would place at serious risk the consensus that had been painstakingly built up amongst the Permanent Five, jeopardising the prospects of the resolution being adopted by the Council. In short, the risk was that the baby would have been thrown out with the bath water. Instead, at France's suggestion, the question of the Kurds was dealt with in a separate resolution-resolution 688-which focuses international attention specifically on the repression of Iraqi civilians by the Iraqi armed forces.

Throughout the period of the negotiations of both resolutions, the Australian mission in New York was in close touch with the principals. Both there and in the capitals we exchanged ideas on the developing text. However, the reality is that Australia is not a member of the Security Council and thus does not have a direct input into the Council's deliberations.

As Senator Evans said on 9 April, the international community is now looking closely at how it can use the two resolutions to force the Iraqi Government to cease its repression of the Kurds. The Australian Government has given in-principle support to an idea endorsed by the European Community that a safe haven be set up inside Iraq under UN auspices, where civilians fleeing the fighting could take refuge from attack and where relief operations could be organised. As I have said before in other forums, and as Senator Evans has said in this place, the proposal raises complex issues going to the capacity of the UN to intervene directly in disputes occurring within, as opposed to between, states. That is a matter that I will come back to later on in my remarks. The idea will require a good deal of thought and development if it is to be implemented effectively.

The UN Secretary-General has appointed Eric Suy, a former UN Legal Counsel, to lead a mission to Iraq to investigate the plight of the civilian population-in particular the Kurds. The mission, comprising four or five officials, is expected to arrive in Baghdad on 13 April, which is next week, and to remain in Iraq for seven to 10 days, during which time it will visit affected areas in both the north and the south of that country. In addition to discussing relief operations, Mr Suy will be taking up with Iraqi authorities the idea of a safe haven. Further Security Council consideration of the situation is expected to be held over until the Suy delegation has returned and made its report. Members are following the situation closely and are continuing to work on ideas for dealing with the crisis.

Apart from this activity, as Senator Evans said on 9 April, UN Security Council resolution 687 makes specific provisions for sanctions on items other than food and arms-related trade to be maintained, subject to review every 60 days, depending on the policies and practices of the Government of Iraq. If the Iraqi Government continues its repression of the Kurds and obstructs the international community in its efforts to provide relief to the victims of that repression, the Security Council will no doubt take up the question of whether the sanctions regime might not be used to force a change in those policies.

On the humanitarian front, the UN Secretary-General has appealed for US$400m to support the relief activities of various international multilateral agencies such as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the International Committee of the Red Cross, and so on and has appointed an executive delegate, Sadruddin Aga Khan, to coordinate the relief operation. On 10 April, Australia chaired a meeting of the UN Humanitarian Liaison Working Group in Geneva which is mapping out a coordination plan between the different relief agencies. As has been announced earlier this week, Australia is contributing $1m to this relief operation as well as providing much needed tents and blankets, which are being flown to Turkey by the Royal Australian Air Force over the weekend.

If there is any good news in the bulletins reporting an ever increasing tide of refugees making their way to the nearest border, it is that the Iraqi Government has announced an amnesty and has apparently ceased for the moment its military attacks on civilians fleeing the country. If these reports are confirmed and the Iraqi Government does cease its repression of the Kurds, the challenge for the world community beyond the immediate need to provide food, clothing, shelter and medical treatment for these tragic victims will be to ensure the conditions which will permit them to return to their homes and pick up their lives in peace and security.

There has been much discussion in the world, including in this place in various debates, about the UN resolutions authorising the allies to take action to liberate Kuwait. That has resulted in the jargon of `the New World Order'. Many people are sceptical about the New World Order and the fact that any move under it to achieve peace and better human rights in the world will fall apart with the first difficult situation that arises. Some people quite rightly question whether the situation of the Kurds is one in which the possibility of the New World Order will fall apart. I hope that that is not the case. But one should not dismiss the fact that, for various reasons, the problems of the Kurdish people and the difficulties in which they find themselves may not be able to be dealt with efficiently and effectively in a short period, thus enabling them to go back to live in their homes safely and securely with their human rights protected.

What I find interesting is that some of the people who, during much of last year and the early part of this year were very critical of the allied involvement in the war to liberate Kuwait, are now saying that we should also take action and involve ourselves directly in liberating the Kurdish people. Many of them are asking for an involvement in the internal affairs of Iraq which last year they were not willing to support in any way. Instead, when the Australian Government supported the UN resolutions which authorised such involvement, they accused it of being involved in an unwarranted interference in the affairs of that region-particularly in relation to the military aspect. I believe that it is time for the countries of the world to discuss whether it is any longer relevant to say in outright terms that the Kurdish situation is nothing more than an internal matter for the Iraqi Government to deal with; that it should be left as such; and that we should not positively or aggressively intervene in the internal affairs of Iraq to deal with the successful conclusion to the Kurdish dispute.

All countries of the world are in the New World Order. If we want it to work, we will have to take a more positive attitude in putting pressure not only on a country such as Iraq because of its appalling human rights record against its own population but also on many other countries. I do not make any bones about the fact that I believe it is moral and legitimate in international affairs for the rest of the world to make value judgments when people are being oppressed within a country in an appalling way such as is occurring in Iraq at the moment. I hope that such action can be taken through the UN. Though this will be a new area for the UN, I believe that it is something that cannot be avoided.

There are many countries in the world other than Iraq that have appalling human rights records. It would take several minutes to stand here and list the scores of countries around the world that have an appalling human rights record. Were we to ask the ordinary people in those countries whether they would favour UN intervention to remove the government and to liberate them and protect their human rights, they would welcome that intervention to give them such liberty and give them a better standard of living.

Would it not have been great for the world in the mid-1970s to have been able to intervene and to stop the genocide of Pol Pot against his own people? Would it not have been fantastic during the past 25 years had the UN been able to effectively intervene to stop the massacre of hundreds of thousands of people in various internal civil wars inside Ethiopia? Would it not have been fantastic 25 years ago had international pressure been effective in bringing to an early end the apartheid system in South Africa? Would it not have been fantastic had we been able to bring to an end much earlier the madness of the Idi Amin regime in Uganda? These are just a few examples around the world where regimes have persecuted their own people in massive violation of their human and civil rights.

I hope that during the 1990s our country in a bipartisan nature can argue in the UN that it is time to say that the international order can intervene and make itself effective against regimes that oppress their people in such an appalling way. It will not be easy but I do not think we can afford to ignore it. The world is becoming more complex. The situation and difficulties in one part of the world affect us all. Therefore, we all have an obligation to think much more seriously about making the so-called new world order effective.

I note Senator Hill's remarks about meeting with a delegation of Kurds yesterday who said that they were not asking for independence but a form of autonomy within Iraq that would give them the right to follow their own religion, their own culture, their own language, and so on. I think that is quite a reasonable request. I am meeting a delegation of Kurds tomorrow who are coming to Canberra and I will be very interested to hear whether that delegation has a similar view.

It is quite clear that in those countries where there are ethnic minorities, the only way that we can effectively deal with and give those ethnic minorities a sense of purpose and participation within the larger country is through a democratic form of government. It is overwhelmingly the case that the ethnic minorities that are oppressed are in countries that have a totalitarian form of dictatorship and where human rights are abused. Naturally, when that starts taking place those ethnic minorities will see that the only they can protect themselves from such abuse is to demand independence, whether it be the Kurds of Iraq, of Turkey or Iran; whether it be the Armenians of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; whether it be the Eritreans or the Tigreans of Ethiopia; or whether it be the Negro population of southern Sudan. The list goes on endlessly. In every one of those countries, an ethnic minority believes that the only way out of its oppression is to demand independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Croatia.
—I agree. Although in that system I do not think it is quite analogous to what has happened in the Middle East, it certainly cannot be ignored. In the end--
—I agree that they ought to be independent.

—The Balkans is another area of the world that has been bedevilled by its ethnic politics for many centuries because of one ethnic group dominating another. The Turkish minority of Bulgaria is another that claims it is being oppressed by the Bulgarian majority. The Hungarian minority in Romania claims that it is being oppressed by the Romanian majority and so it goes on. In every one of those countries there is a claim by the minority, because it has been oppressed and because it has not had democratic rights, that the only way it can see out of its current situation is to call for independence. If we gave every ethnic minority of the Balkans independence, we would end up with lots of very small countries which, in the long run, economically might not be able to provide the living standards that they would all wish for.
—Croatians.

—Senator Harradine may be right about Croatia. He may be right about Slovenia, Bosnia or Montenegro in Yugoslavia. My view about many of those countries is that, because they have lived in a totalitarian regime, they are demanding independence. That is the reason that they have demanded independence. That is the only way that they can get out of the nightmare they are in. If Yugoslavia had been a proper democratic pluralistic society during the past 40 years, maybe the Croatians or the Slovenians would have had no need to argue for an independent country. If their country had been a proper democracy where they had a fair say, where they had democratically elected their representatives to a national parliament, where there was give and take and an acceptance of minority views, that country would have a better chance of survival. I think it is because a totalitarian regime, not necessarily the worst totalitarian regime in the world but certainly a one party state, existed for so long that the various ethnic groups of that country clearly felt the only way forward was to call for independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The nub of the question about dealing with ethnic minorities is to have a democratic form of government established in the countries of the world so that human rights are protected, so that the consent of the minority is freely given to be governed, so that they know their rights are protected, and so that they have a chance to elect the government of their choice at regular, free, democratic elections.

I make no bones about saying that the Kurdish situation is a tragic one. The Kurds have been one of the unfortunate peoples of the twentieth century in the oppression that they have suffered. They have been caught between other more powerful groups of people in the Middle East, whether it be the old Turkish Empire, Iraq, Syria, Turkey, Iran or the Soviet Union. Hopefully, out of the mess that is now there and because of the possibilities of the new world order, at long last this may be the opportunity during this decade for the Kurdish people to at last get some freedom and autonomy, to protect their culture and to get a sense of purpose in being able to participate openly in the governments of those countries, even though they may not be able to achieve what many Kurds may want, that is, an independent country because they have been so oppressed by various dictatorial regimes. I look forward to the new world order being able to assist not only the Kurdish people but also many other minorities to get a better deal in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems obvious to me that Saddam Hussein's Iraq army feels a desperate need to prove that it can annihilate someone and the Kurds are the current victims. Not only current, of course, because Saddam Hussein has been trying to eliminate the Kurds from their ancient homeland in the north of Iraq since 1975 when he was Vice-President of Iraq and he made a deal with the Shah of Iran to assist in Iraqi persecution of the Kurds. The Kurdish people have a saying that the Kurds have no friends. The recent appalling tragic sights we have witnessed on the news broadcasts are only the latest in the long and very pitiful line of events which underline the plight of the Kurdish people. Obviously, the brutal human rights abuses committed by the Iraqi regime against the Kurds for many years are totally unacceptable by any measure of international law.

SPEECH.PARA: On 4 April I received a report from Amnesty International on what is now happening to the Kurdish people. I will just read a little of it. It states:
In the Kurdish region, large scale massacres have apparently taken place in at least eight towns, where the streets are said to be strewn with hundreds of civilian dead, including children.

Hundreds of civilians have apparently also been killed after being ordered to leave their homes. Eyewitnesses from Najal also claimed to have seen 50 dead bodies of men, presumably suspected rebels, whose hands and eyes were bound, who had been shot in the back of the head.

Iraqi forces have reportedly taken some 10,000 Kurdish males as hostages from the area of Kirkuk, Toz Kharmato and other Kurdish cities and may be holding them in Tikrit. Torture is also alleged to have been used on the rebels. A reporter claims to have been shown a torture chamber in Kirkuk containing body parts on the walls.

This is obviously a systematic attempt to eliminate the Kurds from Iraq; in fact it is not the first attempt. The Kurds in Iraq have been subjected to a massive onslaught from the Iraqi army, which has indiscriminately murdered thousands of Turkish children, women and men.

In the past, the West in particular found it convenient to support Saddam Hussein in his war against Iran while at the same time turning a blind eye to the Iraqi dictator's human rights abuses against his own people. More than four million Iraqi Kurds have suffered for more than 20 years under that dictator's regime. In the last years of the Iran-Iraq war, thousands of Kurds were massacred through the use of poison gas and chemical weapons.

At that time, more than 3,000 villages in the northern part of Iraq were destroyed and thousands of people were forcibly removed to other parts of Iraq. The world took notice briefly, but apart from some token words of condemnation and a little international aid-most of which did not reach the Kurds-little was done. Meanwhile, the international community continued to support the Iraqi regime by selling as many weapons of destruction as possible to the brutal dictator.

The trade in military arms without proper monitoring was bound to lead to a situation where insane tyrants, such as Saddam Hussein, could use their military equipment for aggressive and territorial expansion, such as the Kuwaiti invasion, as well as use tools of destruction against their own people. The irony now is that, even though the United States and its allies may have won the war against Iraq, we are well and truly in danger of losing the peace which we hoped to gain.

The latest resolution from the United Nations Security Council does not augur well in this regard. As the motion which we are discussing tonight correctly points out, the Security Council resolution fails to include any provision mentioning how the Kurds' plight would be addressed. This is a glaring omission. The Australian Democrats would like to see the maintenance of economic sanctions against Iraq until the Iraqi regime ceases not only its war against the Kurds but also all human rights abuses. In fact, we had some encouragement from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) earlier this week in an answer to a question I asked of him.

We believe that the United Nations organised sanctions against Iraq should continue until the appalling campaign of terror aimed at the Kurds stops. Sadly, the international community is once again in danger of letting the Kurdish people down. Already we are seeing the switch from a policy of calculated aggression in the Gulf to one which the Guardian Weekly termed `a policy of calculated inertia'.

Indeed, the chief proponent of this inertia is now the United States Government, which seems intent on doing as little as possible. What a paradox it now is to witness the United States arguing for a minimalist interpretation of United Nations resolutions when for so long during the Gulf War it found it convenient to take as broad a definition as possible of what the United Nations had supposedly authorised.

What does the `new world order' mean to the Kurdish people, encouraged to rise up against the Iraqi Government and now abandoned by the international community and left to die of hunger and cold in the mountains on the Iraqi-Turkish border? Massed in some of the wildest country on earth are 600,000 Kurdish Iraqi refugees. In the Hobart Mercury today Bruce Wilson wrote that they are:
In the open, perched like mountain goats on the slopes, dying in hundreds, giving birth, freezing at night, eating trees and roots.

The more we witness what is happening to the Kurds, the more difficult it is to believe that there is peace there and, even more so, that justice has been brought to that region of the world. The world is faced with a very clear choice. The international community can either accept the status quo of the situation, as most of the world prefers to do, or it can actively and positively deliver a solution that finally and comprehensively delivers a just peace to this whole region.

The Democrats point out that there is an inconsistency in logic in bombing Iraq almost continuously in a 40-day war and then ending up with a policy which argues against intervention in the internal affairs of another country. At the very least, for instance, the destruction of Iraqi helicopters, which were used against the Kurds, should have been undertaken as part of the cease-fire agreement. Ultimately, however, as the Democrats have argued, a just peace in the region will only come when the international community recognises and works towards a comprehensive Middle East settlement, including the establishment of a separate and independent state of Kurdistan.

We believe that this is where the plan of British Prime Minister John Major falls down. It fails to go far enough. We believe that the establishment of an autonomous Kurdish state is probably the only way of stopping the many decades of entrenched brutality against the Kurds. Surely, self-determination for the Kurds is their right under the International Bill of Human Rights, which states in article 1:
All peoples have the right of self-determination.

If the United Nations fails to act on this issue now, history will undoubtedly record 1991 as the second spectacular international betrayal of the Kurds. The first, of course, occurred just after the First World War. The irony is that the Kurdish people were dealt their cruelest blow in another post-war period when they were promised a separate Kurdish State in the 1920 Treaty of Sevres. But Sevres was rejected by the Turkish Nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk, as were the agreements recognising Kurdish rights, agreements which were subsequently overtaken by the Treaty of Lausanne in 1923.

Once again, the world conveniently chose to forget commitments and promises. It sacrificed the Kurdish homeland to appease Turkey. The provinces of Mosul and Kirkuk, which should have formed part of the State of Kurdistan, were instead annexed, together with their oil wealth, by Britain in 1925 and given to the newly created arab state of Iraq. For the Kurds, this was a tragedy.

Before the First World War, they were split between the Ottoman and Persian empires. After 1925, they found themselves split between five states: Turkey, Iran, Iraq, Syria and the Soviet Union. In truth, despite the atrocities committed by the Iraqis in recent weeks, not one of these five nations mentioned has a record it can be proud of when it comes to the Kurds. At best, the Kurds are discriminated against; at worst they are repressed.

The Soviet Union's record of repression of minorities is well known and quite appalling. Syria is a military dictatorship which allows no dissent. In Iran, although the Kurds do have some cultural rights, their attempts to win autonomy after the 1979 revolution were brutally crushed by Iran's revolutionary guard. In Turkey, the Kurds are not officially recognised as a distinct ethnic group, but instead are called `mountain Turks'. The repression of the Kurdish language and culture in Turkey is a matter of fact. It is a crime in Turkey to speak Kurdish. We now witness the dreadful behaviour of Turkish soldiers at the border with Iraq. They have been pushing the Kurdish refugees back into Iraq, sometimes using rifles. In many ways, therefore, it is understandable that the creation of a Kurdish state has been opposed by all these countries at various times over the last 70 years and still is opposed.

The international community has always been faint-hearted on the question of an autonomous Kurdish state. It would be tragic indeed if the world remained inactive on this question any longer. It is time to act right now and to do so in a decisive manner. The Democrats believe that Australia should actively support the legitimate rights of the Kurdish people and seize the opportunity in the United Nations to argue the case for the establishment of an autonomous Kurdish state.

The Kurds have modest aims. Today their leaders aspire to autonomy within Iraq-not a separate state of their own. Given the way in which the world has treated the Kurds over the last 70 years, to do less than that is to once again ignore our moral responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that this motion is put forward with proper outrage at what is happening in Iraq to the Kurds. Certainly the first plank of this motion must be supported by everybody. The first plank of the motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) deplores the appalling abuse of the Kurds in Iraq by Saddam Hussein and his military.

As we all look at the television and see the most harrowing scenes, which have been well described by the speakers who have gone before me, we all must be moved to the most profound pity. Unfortunately, I think we are all moved to the most profound frustration. The notice of motion continues:
(b) notes that the United Nations Security Council resolution on the ceasefire did not include provisions to protect minorities in Iraq;
That is so. It goes on:
(c) regrets that the Australian Government failed to lobby for the inclusion of such provisions;

There is in that plank of the motion an implicit, if not explicit, condemnation of what the Government has failed to do. If it was proper and in place for the Australian Government to lobby for the inclusion of such a provision, which would have assisted and even saved the Kurds, if it was within the Australian Government's ability to do that and it did not do it, then the Government should rightly be condemned. Any government that stands aside and fails to do something which would have saved any of the Kurds who made that awful trek that we saw on television, any government that failed to lobby properly, deserves to be condemned. But when one goes further and asks what were the provisions that the Australians should have lobbied for to do what we all want to do-that is, to save as many of the Kurds as possible-when we ask what the Australian Government should have specifically asked for, it does not appear in this motion. I do not point that out in any way to take away from the proper intent of Senator Hill in bringing forth this motion; I point it out to show that it is very difficult indeed off the cuff, as it were, to set up some procedure which would bring peace and proper justice to the Kurds.

Senator Bourne has faced that and said that we should set up a state of Kurdistan. She would get over the problem by setting up an autonomous state within the general jurisdiction of the Iraqi Government. It seems to me that when one pronounces on that and simply states that as what is wanted, one sees the futility of taking such a step. Will Saddam Hussein peacefully allow a Kurdistan state to be taken out of Iraq? If so, will Turkey, Iran and Syria allow the same thing to happen? That is what must happen if what is sought by the Australian Democrats occurs. Senator Hill says that perhaps more could have been done, but is unable to specify what.

This is a good motion in a couple of respects. First, it points out that we should properly take note of and, more than that, feel deeply for the plight of the Kurdish people in Iraq. It also illustrates by its very terms the great difficulty for a country like Australia to do sufficient to enable the Kurdish people to somehow be brought back into a decent place in which to live and enjoy their lives.

The Government has contributed aid, and there seems to be no condemnation or cavil on the part of the Opposition or the Australian Democrats with the action taken by the Government in that respect. It may have been a better avenue of attack by the Opposition, if that is what it wanted to do, to say that the Government has not given enough and that it should have given more aid to the Kurds than it has. But that seems not to be the thrust of what the Opposition is saying in this motion. The thrust of the motion seems to be that there should have been some unspecified provisions put into the United Nations Security Council resolution to protect minorities in Iraq.

The Australian Democrats have been more specific than that. They have said that there should be an autonomous state in Iraq. I am not sure whether they would include parts of Iran, Turkey and Syria, but that seems to be the thrust of what they say. I simply say that that, unfortunately, is a solution which, although motivated by the best of intentions, is doomed to failure, unless we want to start another war not only with Saddam Hussein but also with the countries surrounding the Kurds.

I turn to events that took place in Melbourne at the weekend, and I understand that similar events took place elsewhere in Australia during the same weekend. First, I want to talk about a demonstration by Kurds in Melbourne which started off at the General Post Office and ended in the City Square. It was conducted by the Kurdish Association of Victoria, which was ably represented by such people as Mr Muslim Kocamis. The Association put out a circular which is not long and which I intend to read. It gives a flavour of how the Kurdish people in Australia think and it gives an idea of their outrage and frustrations as to what has happened in the land where their forebears lived. The document, headed `Democracy and Human Rights in Kurdistan', reads:

The Kurds are the only nation in the world with a population of approximately 30 million who have repeatedly been denied a state. Kurdistan is occupied by Iran, Iraq, Syria and Turkey where they are forbidden to practise their culture, speak Kurdish, and to have their own schools amongst many other. Depending on which part of Kurdistan the Kurds are, they are Persians, Arabs or Turks, but to cover their racism from the international arena they then define the Kurdish people as either people from Iraq, Iran, Syria or as from Turkey.
In Kurdistan, a monstrous crime is perpetrated.

South Kurdistan under the occupation of Iraq has been subjected to the brutality of Saddam Hussein's regime once again. The most recent genocide in August 1988 was the use of chemical weapons against the Kurdish people where thousands of villages were also wiped off the map.

The Kurdish people are being slaughtered by Saddam and his army. Tens of thousands of people perish trapped between the Turkish army and Hussein's army. The Kurds have been forced to flee their villages and towns (which have been totally destroyed by the Iraqi army) to the Turkish and Iranian borders. However both Iran and Turkey have again closed their borders after the acceptance of a small number of women and children. Two million women, children, and men are waiting in freezing temperatures without adequate clothing, lack of food, shelter and proper medical attention for the sick and the wounded.
Iraq has not only bombarded the Kurdish people via the helicopters they have also used Napalm bombs. The genocide against the Kurdish people still continues.

Why don't the United States and allies intervene? It was said they went to liberate Kuwait in the name of Democracy and Humanity. But now they say they have no authority to intervene in Iraq's internal affairs. Who then economically and militarily supported the people in Nicaragua and Afghanistan? Everybody knows that international law and the U.N. charter were bent to free Kuwait. Why then this sudden excess of legalism, these wise thoughts about the undesirability of a divided Iraq? Saddam Hussein has no more right to Kurdistan than he had to Kuwait.
The Kurds are not rebels, they are called ``peshmergas'' who are freedom fighters fighting for a free Kurdistan.

We, the Kurdish Community in Australia, would like to call upon the Australian Government, the media, democratic and humanitarian organisations and individuals, Christians, Moslems, Buddhists, Jews and all the other believers and non-believers, who believe in democracy and humanity to support the Kurdish struggle.
This can be done by:
- Putting pressure on United Nations to resolve the Kurdish question, in the meantime sending a peace keeping force to stop the genocide,
- To publicly support the Kurdish people's right to self determination,
- Condemning Saddam Hussein who is the wretched of the earth.
- Donations via Care Australia Campaign Kurdish Appeal at any Commonwealth Bank branch Account No: 2919930237.
PLEASE ASSIST

Then there is an address at the bottom. The other meeting was held on the Sunday by the Turkish Community Resource Centre Human Rights Committee, the secretary of which is a Ms Sevinc Sezen. The circular issued as a result of that meeting reads, in part:
Every human being is entitled to all rights and freedoms set forth in the International Bill of Rights, without distinction of any kind such as race, colour, sex, language or political opinion.
Yet every day in country after country these rights are being violated.

The circular then talks about the location of the Centre's next meeting. That quote from this circular sums up what we should concentrate upon. Until we stop seeing people as Palestinians, Israelis, Kurds, Kuwaitis, or El Salvadoreans and start seeing them as human beings and fellow dwellers on this planet, neighbours and brothers and sisters, which is the teaching of all the great religions, we will probably hear in this chamber, year after year, the same sorts of speeches as we have heard tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to and been present during the whole of this debate. I feel that there is a degree of unanimity right around the chamber about most issues relating to this debate. Firstly, there is strong condemnation of the action taken by Saddam Hussein and his army in their persecution of the Kurdish minority. The ruthlessness of that persecution is absolutely appalling. There is no need for me to reiterate what has already been stated quite adequately and competently by each of the speakers tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some difference of opinion on whether there was some failure to lobby for the inclusion of provisions in the United Nations Security Council resolution on the cease-fire to protect minorities in Iraq. That is what the debate boils down to. There is also agreement around the chamber that the tragic situation being experienced by the Kurdish people is the result of a number of factors including the Gulf war, the action taken by the coalition forces in pursuance of United Nations (UN) decisions, and the perception by the Kurds that the coalition forces would not oppose but welcome their uprising. In those circumstances the UN Security Council should have included in its resolution some form of protection for the Kurds against the onslaughts by Saddam Hussein.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the problem?

—What is it? Well, about four weeks ago I asked a question of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) about the action of the coalition forces in bombing a retreating force of Iraqis along a 90-kilometre stretch of roadway. I asked a number of questions: whether that was legitimate and whether it was militarily nugatory. I have received a written response from the Minister, which does not take his original answer much further. But I might say this to that interjection: I wondered why that column could not have been put in a position of surrender at the northern end of that road and disarmed?

SPEECH.PARA: What military equipment is being used in the onslaught by Saddam Hussein against the Kurds? It is that sort of military equipment that is being used. Why were more prisoners of war not taken? Had they been, they would not have been able to be used by Saddam Hussein in the onslaught against the Kurds, and some arrangement surely could have been made for the protection of the Kurds. I am inclined to support the motion proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill.

I think that the amount of $1m being put forward by the Government is chickenfeed in a circumstance which is facing us here and now, particularly as we expended a large sum of money in support of the coalition effort in the Gulf. Instead of frittering away moneys on the type of trendy population control projects that are still very hazy-and we still have not received information on where the $5.1m is going-what about some of that money being used to assist in this tragic situation to feed the starving and to clothe those who face the freezing temperatures in northern Iraq?

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion does not address that issue.

—As I read the motion, it deplores the appalling abuse. Yes, it is true that it does not, but I assume from what Senator Hill said that he is in favour of action being taken by the Government along those lines. I think that Senator Schacht made it clear that he is in favour as well. But Senator Cooney is right in saying that there is nothing in the motion that says it. But I assume that it is the general view around the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to repeat what has been said today. But it just seems that whilst we have a tremendous degree of unanimity around the chamber about this most important subject, there is just that small difference between us. On balance, I would have liked to see our Government, with all the information at its disposal, lobby for the inclusion in the United Nations Security Council resolution on the actual cease-fire for a provision to protect minorities in Iraq.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt whether the Senate will debate, during the whole of 1991, an issue more tragic in its ramifications than the plight of the Kurds. The Kurdish people have suffered greatly, not only in an immediate sense but over generations. They have suffered very greatly during the period that Saddam Hussein has occupied the presidency of Iraq.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wise to look at the issue in the context of the war in the Gulf. That war, of course, was provoked by the aggression of the Iraqi regime, by its occupation of its peaceful neighbour Kuwait and by the subsequent pillage and rape that took place there. When that war commenced a number of public figures and a great many commentators drew attention again to the plight of the Kurdish people and made reference to the horrific way in which the Government of Iraq had treated them. Certainly since the armistice agreement had been signed with Iran, the Iraqi regime had treated its Kurdish citizens with the utmost brutality and ferocity. The Iraqis had used technologies available to them to bring about some truly terrifying developments and I refer, of course, to the open use of chemical weapons against Kurdish villages in the north of the country.

It is a great pity that more attention was not paid to those appalling incidents at the time when they first occurred. But nonetheless, the war in the Gulf did serve to bring the plight of the Kurdish people into focus. Perhaps for the very first time the plight of the Kurds became a truly international issue with international ramifications.

It is instructive to look at a very brief chronology of recent events by way of examining the backdrop to the revolt that has taken place not only in the northern part of Iraq but in Iraq generally. It was only on 2 March that the United Nations Security Council adopted resolution 686 requiring the Iraqi regime to accept all the previous resolutions of the United Nations and to rescind its purported annexation of Kuwait. The meeting the next day of coalition commanders and Iraqi commanders did agree upon the implementation of an informal cease-fire.

That is useful to know because it was only 24 hours later that reports began to be received in the region's media, particularly in Iran and then in the western media, of a deteriorating security situation in that part of Iraq which is inhabited largely by Shi'ite citizens. That resulted in the city of Basra falling within a very short time to rebel forces. A few days later, reports surfaced of unrest in the northern part of Iraq in the Kurdish centres.

For the following two weeks, the Iraqi military-and I commend Senator Bourne for her remarks about the Iraqi military-displayed an exemplary capacity for failure when fighting other military forces but displayed an exemplary capacity for brutality and bravado when fighting largely unarmed civilian populations. The Iraqi military concentrated on quelling the rebellion in the southern part of the country, including the recovery of the holy cities of Najaf and Karbala-holy to the religion of Islam. Then, with the south largely suppressed, the Iraqi military could turn its attention upon the Kurdish people and use the same capacities in repression that it had applied in the cities of Basra, Najaf and Karbala.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was drawing together a short chronology of recent events as a background to the revolt in Iraq. Between 10 and 28 March 1991, the Kurdish people made very significant gains, occupying many of the major centres in the region, including the major oil town of Kirkuk. By 28 March Kurdish rebels had effectively wrested control of an Iraqi air base south of the city and were preparing for a counterattack. However, within two days, fortified by its successful military intervention against its own civilian population, the Iraqi army began arraying its firepower against the Kurdish people in the northern region of the country and by use of artillery, helicopter gunships and other heavy weapons, virtually all of the Kurdish-held towns and centres fell to the advancing Iraqi military. Of course, it is a matter of terrible history that the recovery of that part of the country was accompanied by brutality on a massive scale, including widespread executions.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a dramatic failure in the language of diplomacy. That precipitated the intervention by the Iraqi military against its own people, and that has resulted in the flow of refugees to Iran, Turkey and Syria. The failure of the language of diplomacy has had direct consequences on the tragedy that we have seen over the last week or so. Of course, I am referring to the statements made by the United States President, George Bush, calling upon the people of Iraq to rise up against their own Government in the expectation that sections of the Iraqi military would depose Saddam Hussein.

That, of course, flies in the face of virtually all we know about the nature of the Baathist regime in Iraq which has assumed, during the decade of the 1980s, through purges and murders, all the trappings of a monolithic, political and military structure. That was witnessed during the long period of the war against the Islamic Republic of Iran, it was reinforced during the time of the Gulf war and it is being seen graphically demonstrated again. The dictatorship of Saddam Hussein has remained secure. Hopefully that may change.

Saddam boasted that when the allied coalition began its war of liberation in Kuwait it would mean the mother of all battles. That, of course, was nothing other than rhetorical nonsense, but one thing we can say about Saddam Hussein is that he is the father of all murderers in the region.

There is no doubt that the plight of the Kurdish people represents the first test of the new world order to which this Parliament is committed. There is no doubt that it affords an additional sense of immediacy to all the endeavours by Australia and other like-minded countries to see the United Nations (UN) intervene more effectively and more forcefully in these types of appalling situations.

It gives an additional sense of immediacy to the calls that have been made for the creation of an international peacekeeping force under UN auspices. I hope that that is one of the recommendations that will emerge from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which has been looking directly at the question of Australia's involvement in UN peacekeeping operations.

I think it is entirely fair to say that the Australian Government has been forthright in terms of its condemnation of Iraq's behaviour. It has been forthright in its defence of the interests of the Kurdish people both in terms of international forums and in terms of talking directly with delegations from Australian Kurds. A delegation met the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) very recently.

I am sure that, like a number of senators from all the parties in the Parliament, people received yesterday or today an urgent facsimile transmission from the Kurdish Victorian Association detailing the slaughter of the Kurdish people that is occurring as we speak here in the Senate tonight. The facsimile also outlines what the people of Kurdistan would like to see occur. I must say that in very large measure the demands are more than reason- able, especially given the awful slaughter that has occurred and which continues to occur.

In that light it has been a very important development that within the last 24 hours the United States of America has detailed an aerial exclusion zone in the north of Iraq which will afford the refugees some measure of protection from marauding Iraqi helicopters. It is true that hindsight is always 20 : 20 vision. It is true that no less an authority than General Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf, has said that given the time again the coalition would have insisted that all Iraqi helicopters along with fixed wing aircraft should have been grounded. It is a lesson that needs to be learned for the future not only by the countries in the coalition but also by those committed to peaceful settlements and solutions everywhere. Dealing with dictatorships of the nature and structure of Saddam Hussein's regime means that it is absolutely necessary to exercise extreme care in terms of the detail of agreements.

As for the Kurdish Australian people, they are asking simply for the safe return of people to their homes, for support for people's rights to live in peace, for UN peacekeeping forces to be present and for urgent humanitarian assistance.

I must say that I was impressed not only by the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives a matter of a day or so ago on the Australian Government's action in terms of providing humanitarian assistance, but also by the immediate response of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, in support of that initiative. That means that the effective breaking down of the bipartisanship as represented by Senator Hill's motion is all the more regrettable. I have said in this Senate before that in my view issues such as foreign affairs, defence and trade ought to be largely above partisan considerations. That is why I think that point scoring is unfortunate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only when we agree with you.

—I must say, in answer to Senator Crichton-Browne whose interjections I always enjoy, that it is a two-way process-there is no doubt about that. I draw attention to a statement made at a press conference a day or so ago by Senator Evans, in which the Australian Government welcomed the initiative of the British Prime Minister, Mr Major, for the concept of a safe haven in Iraq-something which has been endorsed by the European Community and now given effect by the announcement of the United States Government that the United States Air Force would guarantee the safe haven against the Iraqi air force. This is a new development in international affairs. It has come a little too late on this occasion, but it is a very useful step for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The plight of the Kurds affects us all. The response of this Parliament is very important. It is unfortunate that the degree of bipartisanship we have shown on these issues has broken down on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a motion by Senator Hill deploring the appalling abuse of the Kurds in Iraq by Saddam Hussein and his military. I do not think anyone would have any argument with the matters raised in the first part of the resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the resolution goes on to note that the United Nations (UN) Security Council resolution on the ceasefire did not include provision to protect the minorities in Iraq. I think most members of this Parliament would know that the Security Council certainly did not take into consideration what might happen following the end of hostilities in Iraq and Kuwait. Probably at some time in the future, if we talk about the new order, the United Nations should start to take note of what might happen, and take into consideration the end of hostilities and what action should be taken to resolve the position of the Kurdish people or minorities in relation to those conflicts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for General Business has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Hill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reid) proposed:
That consideration of General Business be extended to enable the consideration of the General Business items listed on today's Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I raise a point of clarification with you, Mr President? I did not quite pick up Senator Reid's motion, as she said it rather quickly. Does her motion leave it open for people who want to speak further or move an amendment to this matter still to speak? Perhaps she might repeat the motion.
—The motion that I have moved would be to enable the Opposition to proceed with the three items of General Business that have been listed for today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I simply wonder whether item No. 170 is the most important. The other two items do not seem to me to be of vital importance. Item No. 112 is a motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resolution of the Senate of 31 May 1990 relating to the broadcasting by television stations of Senate proceedings be modified by omitting condition 6 in paragraph (3), which prohibits the broadcasting of the adjournment debate.

I do not think that that is really an issue of burning importance that should keep us here until 3 o'clock tomorrow morning. I suggest to the mover of the resolution that she be kind enough to amend her motion. Perhaps the one that is of burning interest-the one relating to the Kurdish situation-should suffice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There is absolutely no doubt that the motion relating to the plight of the Kurdish community is of overwhelming importance and must be dealt with by the Senate tonight. We have been most diligent in putting up only one speaker-Senator Hill-because it was our view that the motion should be passed. The Australian Democrats likewise had only one speaker-Senator Bourne. I know for a fact that other Democrats would very much like to have spoken, as would I, Senator Teague and many other Opposition senators. We have been faced with the situation where the Government has had Senator Schacht speak for what I thought was 30 minutes, although he said it was 25; I would have to say that it seemed like 30. Senator Loosely has spoken for 30 minutes so far; Senator Cooney spoke for 15 minutes; and Senator Jones is just two minutes into what will obviously be a riveting speech on the same topic. That presumably means that about another 26 senators on the Australian Labor Party side are prepared to keep us here until morning. If need be, that is the way it will be.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the motion relating to the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust is concerned, we intended that our speaker, Senator Michael Baume, would speak for probably no more than five minutes merely to put the situation on the record. The Australian Democrats, as I understand it, were going to do likewise. I do not know what the Government's intentions were. Although Senator Vanstone would like to explain the third motion, she has no burning desire to do so and is happy for it merely to be put to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to respond briefly to the remarks that indicate in some way that the Government has acted improperly by debating a very important issue before the Parliament. The fact of the matter is that this is a very important issue. As Senator Cooney said, 30 or 40 senators quite properly came in to speak on the very important issue of the war. We now have the important issue of the Kurds, a human tragedy, and we are asked not to speak on it, but to allow it to go through so that a resolution that the Opposition wishes to carry criticising the Government can be put on the record and for no other purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is a very important chamber in which people are entitled to express their views about important issues. Procedurally, not one person spoke to me or to the Whips about this arrangement and that is why we did not get any agreement on it. We are quite relaxed about debating it. We are not saying that we will not debate it; I am simply saying that we will not stand here and take lightly criticism that we have done something inappropriate by debating an issue that deserves to be debated. We quite properly and appropriately will continue to debate this until everybody has said what he or she wishes to say on the matter and contributions on this and on the other two matters have been concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will be very brief. It was suggested by Senator Reid that I spoke for 30 minutes. I do not know whether I spoke for 25, 27 or 30 minutes. My time certainly did not run out. I have to say that no indication was given to me that there was an informal time limit on any speakers in the debate and, as I was the first speaker on the Government side, I thought it was only reasonable that I put the information from the Government's perspective on a very important issue dealing with the Kurdish situation. As I say, I was given no indication that there was an informal arrangement that we were all limited to 5, 10, 15 or 20 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not detain the Senate for any longer than necessary, either, but I was the duty Minister in this chamber at the time that this happened.
—You mucked it up-again.

—Oh, really? I think that past practice will demonstrate that, in procedural matters and arrangements of courtesy on both sides of the House, I am as amenable as anybody in this chamber. I think that is a matter of fact. I have just discovered, from a conversation with a Democrat, that I need to correct the record in here.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid has delivered a load of rubbish in her contribution to this motion this afternoon that needs to be corrected. It has already been corrected by Senator McMullan and, indeed, by Senator Schacht. Let me say that we all know these arrangements; they are made constantly, and properly, in here. Allusions have been made to arrangements being made to limit speeches-arrangements being made for one speaker a side. No arrangements were made with me-none. I was not spoken to. The Whip has just confirmed that Senator Reid's assertions about bad practice on our part and trying to avoid votes are also untrue so far as he is concerned. No arrangements were made with him as the Whip, nor with the duty Minister. I would like to know whom they were made with.

In terms of reasonable practice and reasonable behaviour in this chamber, and a little bit of courtesy on both sides, which does help us all through the day every now and again, I thought it would have been reasonable. I could see all the machinations going on around the chamber. It was not up to me to be as rude as others were, to go and stand over the Democrats while other people were talking with them. I did not know what was going on. I would have thought it would have been courteous.

I have now been informed by a senator that a suggestion was made that it would have been reasonable to speak to the Government briefly, and the Opposition indicated that it was not its intention to do so. It is a bit rough, I would say in fairness, when the Opposition has quite happily indicated to the Democrats that, as far as it was concerned, this was going to be an ambush. That is fine-ambushes are okay-but the Opposition then claims that somehow or other we have behaved improperly, or badly, in not limiting speeches, whereas I can say, as the person in the chamber at the time, that we were not asked to do so. I had no idea that not only was this debate to go on, but that two other motions were also to be moved in General Business, because no-one had the courtesy to tell me. I am not suggesting that people have to but, if they want the courtesy extended, that is a two-way street.

I would suggest that the normal arrangements should prevail, that is, to have a one-minute chat to whoever happens to be the duty Minister in the House and to at least have a talk to the Whip to institute those arrangements that Senator Reid referred to-limiting speakers on each side, and so on. None of our speakers knew. In fact, in terms of conversations, out of courtesy I actually walked across and told the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) that Senator Loosley wanted to speak in this debate. Silly old me, not realising there was going to be an ambush, I tried to prevail upon Senator Loosley not to speak. I will tell the Senate why-pure self-interest! I have to get up at five o'clock to go and catch a plane that leaves at 6.30. I actually wanted to go home. Terrible, is it not? Senator Loosley had actually prepared a speech-16 points, all typed out.

As Senator McMullan has already alluded to, Senator Loosley actually wanted to make a contribution to this debate, as he does to a great many debates, because he felt strongly about it. I said, `Okay Steve, this is a House of debate; if you want to talk, talk'. It is just nonsense. Senator Loosely had no idea that some arrangements had been made to limit speakers, neither did Senator Schacht nor any other speaker on this side.

The point needs to be made-I did have a fairly civilised conversation with Senator McLean, as the Whip, about this-that in future if assertions are to be made and accusations are to be made, as they just were, about bad practice on this side of the House, it might be better to make them on a little more solid ground. The solid ground that Opposition members would need next time is to at least have had the courtesy of a 30-second conversation with either the duty Minister or the Whip before they start accusing us of bad practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make it very clear that no arrangement was made with me in relation to time limits on speakers or how long they would speak. That arrangement was not made with me by the Whip of the Opposition, or certainly the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). I want to make it very clear that I spoke to both my deputies and both of them said that no arrangement was made with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Can I make it clear that I was no part of any arrangement on how this matter was to be discussed. I did not take Senator Reid to be suggesting what is being discussed. I think that she was suggesting that there was an understanding on her part that this would be disposed of tonight because it was a very important motion, which it is. In my speech-I think that everybody agreed with me-I said that it was a proper thing for Senator Hill to raise and I thought that everybody made great contributions, and may I pay tribute to Senator Harradine who also had no idea that there was some understanding amongst some people here that there may have been a limit to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I take it that Senator Reid was not suggesting that. She was suggesting that it was an important matter that should be disposed of tonight. Perhaps the words that she used were capable of a construction that she did not intend. I simply put it that way because it seems to me a great shame that a very important debate about a most tragic issue should end up in the way it seems to be ending up where we are in fundamental agreement about the terrible plight of the Kurds but somehow the whole debate has taken a tone that nobody really intended. I ask Senator Reid, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine to accept it from me that I certainly did not have any intention of acting other than in a proper way, and I am sure that those on this side who debated the motion did not. I am absolutely sure that Senator Harradine is of the same mind and perhaps we could get on with the matter. I did say to Senator McMullan, as he has very properly said, that it seemed to me that this was a crucial debate and, given the time we spent on a proper debate on the Gulf war, we could have spent a bit longer on this one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Cooney is the one person who has it right and understands the situation. The difference between the sort of debate that Senator Collins is talking about and the debate tonight is that we are talking in General Business, which is restricted to 2 1/2 hours and which tonight would have ended at 10.50 p.m. The only comment that I made to the Government Whip about it was to tell him that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) was speaking briefly. I asked him how long Senator Schacht would speak and he said about half an hour. I said, `If he does, we will be running into trouble'.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of the matter is that this debate is restricted to 2 1/2 hours. It is Opposition business time and we are entitled to that time to get our business done. If the Government wants all of its 30 senators-or however many it has-to talk on this debate, it is a matter that ought to be brought on as Government business when everybody can talk. That is the complete difference between this and the debate in January that has been referred to. It is quite different.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ridiculous to suggest that we are not supposed to respond to it.

—Nobody would suggest that the Government should not respond. Nobody did suggest that the Government should not respond. All we are suggesting is that we regard this as a matter of significance and importance that ought to be resolved. Given that we are restricted in the amount of time that is available, we want the time extended to enable the matter to come to a vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Reid's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the division, I was going through the clauses of the motion moved by Senator Hill. I dealt with clause (b) and I was coming to clause (c), which I will come back to in a moment. Clause (d) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (d) urges the UN Security Council to take such action as is necessary to end this human tragedy.

I do not think anyone would have any argument with seeking some sort of action from the United Nations Security Council. Clause (c) claims that the Government has failed to lobby for the inclusion of provisions. As Senator Hill will be well aware, the Government will not agree to that clause. I am not sure that I am in order, but I would like to move an amendment to remove clause (c) from the motion. I move:
Omit paragraph (c).

One of the other points I would like to make before I talk about the Kurds is that it is fairly important to remember that tonight a number of speakers from the Government spoke on the issue of the Kurds and the problems that they have. I think it is reasonable to say that a large number of senators in this Senate spoke in the debate on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, including Government and Opposition members.

The Kurdish problem at the moment is a result of the conflict in the Middle East. I think what we are discussing tonight is just as important an issue. I note that the Opposition has had only one speaker. Members of the Government have shown that they certainly have some interest in the fact that the Kurdish people are suffering from the problems of being isolated in the north of Iraq by Saddam Hussein.

Just let me go back for a moment and deal with the United Nations (UN) and the new order. A number of speakers tonight have mentioned the new order. It is quite obvious that some people do not believe that the new order will work. In attending the United Nations, I was impressed by the number of nations, including the Soviet Union, the United States of America and European countries, and to a lesser degree China, where changes have taken place. They had a view of cooperation with one another. I believe that it was that view of cooperation that permitted the Security Council to carry the resolution that allowed the coming together of a force to go to the Middle East to deal with Saddam Hussein and the problems in Kuwait.

If it had not been for the so-called new order and the special cooperation that had developed between the countries of the United Nations, I do not believe that the Security Council would have taken the action it did and carried the resolution that allowed a coalition force to go to the Middle East to remove Saddam Hussein from Kuwait.

One would have to say that taking that action and moving Saddam Hussein and his forces out of Kuwait created the problem of the Kurdish people. It is because of the creation of that problem that we now find ourselves debating the question in this House. I believe that anyone who watched television tonight and last night would have been shocked at the way in which the Kurdish people were suffering in the cold in the northern part of Iraq. It would appear that because of the treatment of those people and the way in which they were suffering and the number of refugees who will come out of that area the international community has to stand up and say something, to see that there is some end to the problems in Iraq.

I believe that if the international community applies pressure on the United Nations about what is happening to the Kurdish people, the UN will have to rethink what it is doing in relation to moving into countries where there is an internal problem. I do not believe that the United Nations-if it is talking about a new order-can sit back for a long period and allow the situation that is developing in Iraq with the Kurdish people to continue. The United Nations has to change its charter to allow it to move into that area and it needs to do it fairly quickly.

One of the things that happened is that the United Nations believed it was acting in relation to the new order that had developed. It passed the resolution that allowed the coalition forces to move into Kuwait, but it did not think about what might happen beyond the end of the war. We should take note of what was said in today's press by James Bone in New York. He said:

United Nations forces have been embroiled in a variety of wars and communal conflicts around the world, but the organisation has never sent military personnel to establish a safe haven in a country's territory.
Often, as in Cyprus or Lebanon, it is difficult to say that such involvement does not amount to interference in a country's internal affairs.
The UN Charter allows such intervention only when it is necessary as part of enforcement action to maintain international peace.

I believe that the United Nations should look at its charter, which spells out that it should not interfere in a country's internal territory. Some action should be taken to see that in the future the United Nations, under the new order, ensures that people are not dislocated because of war, as the Kurdish people have been because of the conflict in Kuwait.

When I was at the United Nations I viewed the tapes that were shown to the Security Council of the atrocities committed by Saddam Hussein in Kuwait. They left me with no doubt that the action that was taken by the United Nations to move into Kuwait and remove Saddam Hussein was correct.

I also believe that the one mistake made by the United Nations was that it did not stop to consider what might happen after the conflict finished. I believe that it is important that in future it should consider that. Mr Shevardnadze, then the Soviet Foreign Minister, said very clearly that steps should be taken to reinstitute the military committee of the United Nations. If that had been done, maybe the military committee would have given different advice to the United Nations when it drew up the conditions of surrender for Iraq. It might have drawn up conditions that would have taken into consideration what might happen to minority groups in the area.

I believe it is very important that members of this House, particularly members of the Government-and for that matter, I know that the Opposition has not spoken on this matter, except for the Leader of the Opposition in this place-if they are really interested in the Kuwaiti issue and what has happened in the Middle East, if they are really interested in what is happening to the Kurds, should get to their feet and say something about the matter so that some pressure is put on the international community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the important issue of the Kurds. I am surprised that more Opposition members have decided not to participate in the debate. It is an issue that we all have to be most concerned about. It is an issue that deals with the civil rights and human rights of the Kurds who live in Iraq. Australia did protest, and has a history of protesting, at the actions of Saddam Hussein in 1988 when he used chemical and gas warfare against the Kurdish civilians. We saw graphic pictures then, and Australia certainly was one of the first countries to express its condemnation at that outrage. We moved quickly to provide an expert to the United Nations investigation of the tragic incidents.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been active, as I have said, in international forums, particularly in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, in highlighting Iraq's human rights record. It is a record that goes back over a decade. At the Commission this year, for instance, we sponsored a resolution supporting a special rapporteur to examine the human rights situation in Iraq. The United Nations Security Council resolution which was established on the cease-fire in the Gulf war was resolution 687. That was adopted on 2 April. It was a very complex resolution adopted by the Security Council because, as the Senate will recall, there were members of the Security Council who had reservations about its extent. It was the most intrusive in the sense of imposing international supervision of Iraq's disarmament program and of its reparation payments for damage caused in Kuwait. Prior to its adoption, the resolution had been negotiated for more than two weeks-in the first instance among the five permanent members of the Security Council, and then between those members and the other members of the Council.

When the resolution was first drafted and throughout much of the negotiating period, the situation in Iraq was unclear. Kurdish rebels had captured several cities in the north and the Shia rebels were making progress in the south. In this situation no-one knew whether Saddam's government would survive or not. It was in that situation that the resolution was adopted.

By the time it became clear that the Iraqi forces were winning the war against the Kurds and that the flow of refugees had commenced, resolution 687 was in the final stages of negotiation. It was a bit difficult then to pull it back and renegotiate. What happened, at France's suggestion, was that the question of the Kurds was dealt with within a separate resolution, resolution 688. That focuses international attention specifically on the repression of Iraqi civilians by the Iraqi armed forces.

Throughout the period of the negotiation of both resolutions, the Australian mission in New York has been in close touch with the principals. Both there and in the capitals we have exchanged ideas on the developing text. Australia is not a member of the Security Council and does not have any direct input into the Council's deliberations. However, we have been an active participant in assisting to formulate the resolutions.

It is very important to know that Australia has had a major role in looking at this. We have promised aid. We only have to look at some of the recent very graphic television footage coming into our homes nightly to see what atrocities are being committed and what hardships the Kurds are having to exist under. Some are not existing. We do not know how many Kurds have been killed or have died in this last conflict. It is a situation that we have to redress and it is something this Australian Government is doing; that is very important. It is very important to make people aware that Australia has been an active participant in trying to resolve the problem and also in trying to provide the aid and succour that is necessary to these people who are suffering greatly under this hardship.

This is not a new occasion for the Kurds. They have suffered frequently at the hands of many groups, but I think this would be one of the worst atrocities that they have ever experienced.
