On that note, I think it is important to support the Government's efforts in attempting to solve this problem, in attempting to assist in the easing of the trauma, the suffering and the hardship that the Kurds have had inflicted upon them by the Iraqi Government and army, but not necessarily by the Iraqi people. Turkey, Iran and the neighbouring countries are going to need assistance because the problem is absolutely monumental. We are talking about possibly millions of people being displaced. That brings us to the size of displacements of population that we really only saw in World War II. It is something that we are not geared up to meet or to cope with very well at present. But this resolution and the world's actions in trying to meet this need and to overcome these problems are to be praised. I think Australia stands very high and very proud by virtue of the fact that it has been one of the countries which has contributed greatly in an effort to overcome the problems that are being faced by the Kurds and other people of persecuted races. It is an action of the Government that I highly commend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I do not intend to speak for very long at all--
—How about half an hour?

—No, I do not intend to do that. But because the opportunity has arisen in a way which I would have been prepared to arrange differently if someone had had the courtesy to speak to us about it, I do want to say something about my feelings when I saw this motion. I was appalled by the motion. I do not think that it does Senator Hill any credit. I do not think it has done the Opposition the slightest credit. Knowing Senator Hill's close interest in foreign affairs-I acknowledge his attachment to that subject and, without question, his concern about the appalling plight of these Kurdish people-I think that he probably regrets that this debate was not handled a little more professionally in an organisational way. I do not think it has reflected very well on this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: If we had to pick one debate on which we would have least liked something like this to happen, it would have been on this kind of motion. I can assure Senator Hill and all Opposition senators that this was my immediate reaction when I read the terms of this resolution. I never thought I was going to speak in the debate, but I will now. Having seen-like most other people-the appalling television pictures of the plight of these people, having been in this chamber when almost every member of the Senate spoke in the debate on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and noted the bipartisan way in which that was necessarily conducted so that a unanimous view would be expressed by this Parliament, I am convinced that that was the proper and appropriate way to deal with something of such gravity.

Senator Jones, on behalf of the Government, has moved that paragraph (c) of the motion be deleted, and I foreshadow that I will support that amendment. Indeed, it would have done Senator Hill personally and the Opposition far more credit if a discussion had been held on this extremely important motion. It is irrelevant whether it is moved in General Business or in any other way: it is a motion of the Senate, finally.

If a discussion had been held with the Government on this motion on the Kurds-and it is the first motion of this kind that we have debated in this Parliament-so that precisely the same result could have been achieved in this equally grave and appalling situation as was achieved with the invasion itself, the motion would have received the bipartisan and unanimous support of this chamber. But, of course, the motion was designed to do precisely the reverse.

Senator Reid suggested-and, after 10 years in opposition it was the most extraordinary suggestion-that in a General Business debate there was an obligation of courtesy on the Government not to participate because it has other opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody said that.
—Senator Reid said that and the Hansard record will show it. Could I, as someone who has moved a few General Business motions in my day, make the obvious point--
—Be truthful.
—As someone who has been in Parliament a lot longer than Senator Macdonald--
—That doesn't give you the right not to be truthful, does it?

—As someone who has been in Parliament for quite a long time, let me make the point that, if one wants the debate controlled in that way-and I have done this plenty of times-the motion would be phrased and cast so that it did not provoke opposition from the Government benches. However, if a motion like this is designed to score a few points, as paragraph (c) does by attacking the Government, then it is ridiculous to suggest that Government speakers will not participate in the debate to defend the Government and to criticise the attack on it, which is precisely what happened this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Could one think of a motion less likely to provoke the acrimonious and indeed partisan debate that we have heard here tonight than this motion, because of paragraph (c)? I know that I speak on behalf of all my colleagues in this chamber when I say that, if this motion had simply addressed the dreadful plight of the Kurdish people, which is appalling, and if it had been discussed with the Government in the same way that the motions on the invasion of Kuwait had been discussed, then this Senate would have expressed a unanimous resolution expressing our sympathy for the Kurds and perhaps would have suggested unanimously that something could be done about it. But no such approach was made. No attempt was made for that to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't the Government do something about it?
—Because it is an Opposition motion. What an absurd interjection.
—That wasn't what the motion was about.
—I rest my case. This debate has been totally degraded this evening.
—By you.
—With respect, it was degraded by having included in it an attack on the Government.
—So we can't attack the Government?

—Senator Macdonald continues to dig himself deeper into the hole. I point out to the honourable senator that it is appropriate to attack the Government and, if there had been a debate in this Chamber as substantive as the one on the invasion itself, initiated by either the Government or the Opposition-it would be a resolution of the Senate so in the finish it would not matter how it was initiated-perhaps a subsequent attack on the Government would have been a reasonable thing to do. I say to Senator Hill that I do not read every single motion. I came into the House and I read this, I confess, for the first time and thought, `Well, that's nice; we're going to have a debate on the Kurds and it's going to inevitably turn into a slanging match because there's a clause here that gets stuck into the Government.'

SPEECH.PARA: It would have been far nicer and it would have been a far better result, I think, for all concerned-every one of us collectively-if the resolution had simply, in the strongest terms, expressed our concern for the appalling plight of these people, and it is awful, and had perhaps proposed a course of action that we all could have agreed on, and I think a little bit of discussion would have done it. Senator Hill is, as I have said before, very knowledgeable about foreign affairs. I know that is an expert interest--

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't prepared to do that yesterday.

—I am speaking for myself and I am talking about my little contribution in here. I just happen to be the bunny who happened to walk in when this debate was going. I am speaking for myself. I have not discussed this with my colleagues. That was my reaction when I sat down here, had a look at what we had in front of us and read the motion. I thought, `Well, that's nice.' It was good enough for all of us, and properly so, to actually seek out a bipartisan position on the invasion of Kuwait. But the subsequent events that have flowed from it-and in many ways, I think far more tragic than the original invasion-did not seem to warrant that same kind of even brief discussion to try to get some resolution. Instead it was, `We'll stick in a barb for the Government.'

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just consider the hypocrisy of clause (c) itself. We all know the history of the negotiations of the resolutions-the absolutely unparalleled and unique resolutions of the United Nations that led to that extraordinary alliance that successfully ousted the Iraqi armed forces from their invasion of Kuwait. It was, without question, without argument, the most complex, the most intrusive and the most difficult resolution ever adopted by the United Nations Security Council. When the resolution was first drafted, it was absolutely unclear-and Senator Hill knows this-what the situation was in Iraq. Kurdish rebels had captured several cities in the north; Shi'ite rebels were making progress in the south; and in this chaotic situation, no-one actually knew whether or not the Saddam Hussein Government would survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has written this for you?

—No-one wrote this for me. Senator Hill knows perfectly well because of the actions subsequently taken by the French Government, of which he is well aware, that if any one of those countries had been foolish enough to attempt to negotiate this kind of resolution and demand it as being an absolute pre-condition on the alliance resolution being carried, that resolution would never have been carried; it would never have got the support that it did, and Senator Hill knows that full well. So this attack on the Government is a piece of hollow point-scoring partisan sanctimony that does Senator Hill, with his knowledge of foreign affairs, not the slightest personal credit, and certainly does not do the Opposition any credit at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in conclusion that I do not think there is any current human crisis in the world that is attracting the sympathy and support of the world community more than the plight of the Kurds in Iraq. I am extremely grateful that the Government of the United States finally did move to provide military protection of the airspace over one tiny part of that area so that the Kurds can at least get some relatively safe haven where there is some chance of the aid which is now being directed to them being to good effect. I deeply regret, as a member of this Senate, that a subject as profoundly distressing as this one has been dealt with in the appalling fashion, for whatever reason, that we have dealt with this motion here tonight. It all could have been avoided with just a little bit of discussion and a little bit of communication from one side to another to produce-at least in the first instance-a motion expressing the concern of the entire Senate as to the plight of the Kurds. It would have done not only the Opposition but the Senate as a whole far more credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate, I thank honourable senators for their contribution. I only want to address very briefly the point that Senator Collins made, which was his attack on and criticism of Australian policy and inaction, in this instance, in not taking any action to lobby for inclusion in the Security Council resolution a provision that would offer a safeguard for minorities in Iraq. I said at the outset-and I do not know that Senator Collins was present when I made my contribution-that this business is an embarrassment to the whole international community, and I very much regretted that alliance states, who fought a just war in relieving Kuwait, were not prepared to go the one step further and ensure that upon settlement there was a safeguard for those who were likely to suffer, but rather fell back upon the old position of a balance of power in the region being more important than basic humanitarian concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: I genuinely regret that the Australian Government, in the terms that Senator Gareth Evans put to the Senate the other day-and Senator Collins might re-read them-did not play a part at that level because it was basically too difficult, we were not a member of the Security Council and it was better to stand aside. That is what I regret and that is what I put in this motion because I think the Senate ought to regret it as well. Perhaps the lesson might be that next time something horrible like this occurs, the Australian Government might be a little more courageous and take the appropriate action at the appropriate time.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the collapse of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust (AETT), and the Hawke Government's refusal to accept its financial responsibilities to replace lost donations intended for Australian arts groups, has caused financial distress to many of those groups;

(b) notes, too, that the alternative direct arts donation arrangements, belatedly introduced by the Government two days before the Trust's collapse, fail to cater, at present, for the great bulk of Australian arts bodies whose sources of tax-deductible donations have now been cut off; and

(c) calls on the Hawke Government immediately to provide an appropriate mechanism by which arts bodies that qualified under the Government-approved, but now collapsed, AETT scheme, should be equally covered pending determination of their requests for inclusion in the new direct funding register.

The reason for the urgency of this matter is that at present there is no way the great bulk of Australian arts bodies can receive tax deductible funding because of the collapse of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust (AETT). The arrangement the Government intends to replace the failed AETT with, which is a register to be regulated by a combination of Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Department of the Treasury, has yet to be put in place, so at the moment there is not even a conduit to replace the AETT through which the great volume of arts bodies that depend so heavily on public tax deductible donations can receive any funding whatsoever.

I have a mountain of mail from those bodies, which exhibits a combination of distress at and outrage by the results of the Government's failure to follow Opposition policy at the last two elections-which was to remove this requirement that all tax deductible donations be made through the AETT-and, indeed, the Government's failure to accept pressure from the Australia Council for the last five years and from its own Minister for the arts for the last five years. As I understand it, the opposition has come from the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

It is as a result of direct and deliberate Government policy and actions that this money has been lost. I understood it was between $5,000 and $6,000, but I received a letter today indicating that it is probably something like $700,000. Those losses are bad enough and have a disastrous impact. Had I time, I would read from some letters of the enormous volume of correspondence that I have received on this matter from small and large organisations whose money has disappeared with the collapse of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust.

It is now two weeks since the Trust collapsed. We do not know what the criteria will be for arts organisations that used to get their money through the conduit of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust; we do not know what the criteria will be for them to get on this new list; and we do not know whether all those bodies that were eligible under the Elizabethan Theatre Trust system will be eligible in future.

I understand from informal conferences with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that there are real problems involved in creating a new conduit like the AETT and that the Government may not be inclined to do so. But we do not know. We do know that something like $700,000 has been lost to these people because of the Government's idiotic policy, which was reversed two days before the Elizabethan Theatre Trust went broke. The Government suddenly discovered the urgent need to allow direct donations to 10 bodies, the great bulk of which were governmental bodies anyway. The Government, in the knowledge that the AETT was about to go broke, changed the rules but did not bother letting Australian donors know that their money would be at risk.

In this motion we are calling for the creation of a conduit so that arts bodies can continue to get money instead of not only having the tap totally turned off but also having the plug removed by this Government for the money that was in the basin. We want this conduit to exist while organisations are working out how to get on the register and also for those organisations that may well never end up getting on the register because the complications and the requirements to do so may be beyond them in view of their small size. I just hope the Government will not make the same mess by delaying and fiddling around with this matter as it did with making an appointment to the Australia Council.

Finally, I want to stress that it is not simply the Opposition and I who have been saying this; I have put out press releases calling for the Government to make good this amount and to provide a conduit and so on. In addition, a whole range of arts organisations throughout Australia have been pressing for this. I received a press release from the Arts Industry Council today in which it says that $700,000 that had been channelled through the Trust under the Federal Government's tax deductibility scheme must be made good, and that by not moving to change the relevant Act much earlier the Federal Government, instead of providing support for the arts, has effectively taken away $700,000 in private funding. The release continues:
In these tough times when arts organisations are facing financial hardship, we cannot afford this loss.

Mr President, there is plenty more I would like to say on this matter. It is a complicated one. There is real urgency for the Government to act in this matter. This is vital funding, the absence of which will cause the cancellation of some arts activities. For example, the Barossa music festival is in serious financial trouble because of the loss of $30,000, and it cannot be replaced with tax deductible donations from the private sector because there will be no conduit available until this Government gets off the pot and does something about it. We have seen no indication of what will be done about it and no creation of a conduit. This motion calls upon the Government to act, and to act urgently.
Friday, 12 April 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is about an important matter, but it is somewhat strange in its timing. I accept that Senator Baume is genuinely concerned about the arts, and I think most people in this chamber could not be other than concerned about the circumstances that have arisen with regard to arts funding and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. But it does not necessarily follow from that original concern that one believes this motion is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a little puzzled to hear Senator Baume talking about the fact that nobody knows what the criteria are for applying to be on the register of cultural organisations and that the Government has not let anybody know about this. Yesterday the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) made it clear, and in the House today he tabled the information about the eligibility criteria for new arrangements for donations to cultural organisations. A mailout of application forms to arts organisations has already commenced so that they can apply to be on that register. That decision was announced yesterday, those criteria were released yesterday, and that material was tabled in the Parliament today. The information is on its way to arts organisations at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And how long will you take to act on it?

—It is a question of their applications. The register has been established. Some bodies, as the honourable senator has indicated already, are on it and the applications of others will be processed as they apply. We cannot deal with it more quickly than they apply but we will endeavour to act quickly when they do.

SPEECH.PARA: The relationship between tax and the arts is a difficult question and it has been the source of a lot of debate, as Senator Baume knows. There are more organisations involved than just the Elizabethan Theatre Trust. There have been a complex range of measures to do with Australian business support for the arts and to do with the whole nature of section 78 of the tax Act. They have been caught up properly in a review of the proper administration of section 78 of the tax Act, not just for the arts, but for other bodies as well. There has been a need for careful consideration of that, and that consideration will continue.

I think these emerging new arrangements for donations to cultural organisations will mean a much better arts policy and a much better tax policy than those that existed previously. I do not share the view-and I do not think, on responsible contemplation, that anybody could-that the Government should have given early warning to people that the Elizabethan Theatre Trust was in financial difficulties. It is the height of irresponsibility to make a public comment saying, `We are concerned that this body may be about to go into receivership'. Nothing is more guaranteed to ensure that it does go into receivership than that sort of statement by the Government.

It would have destroyed that organisation. No serious person has suggested that we should make that sort of arrangement. It would have been, as the Minister said in the House of Representatives today, entirely inappropriate and in my view entirely irresponsible. There has not been a final decision made on the other and important question that Senator Baume raises concerning the difficulties that some organisations may suffer as a result of the moneys intended as donations being called up in the Trust's accounts. The Minister said today in the House of Representatives-and this is the first matter to be attended to-that the Trust itself will do everything possible to ensure that those moneys are passed on and there is some possibility that some of that may take place. That is obviously the first and most appropriate way that action should be taken. Secondly, the Minister has asked the Australia Council for advice on the consequences of the situation for the arts community, and on the basis of that advice, and after the situation with regard to the final washup of the Elizabethan Theatre Trust's accounts is clear, it will then become possible for the Government to make a final decision.

However, everybody knows that it is not easy to make decisions about adding an extra $500,000 or $700,000 to the arts budget or any other budget. It is not lightly come by and there would be some legitimate debate as to whether it was the best or the highest priority use of $700,000-worth of taxpayers' money, although it is a proper cause of concern and a matter that remains under serious consideration, depending upon the advice from the Australia Council. The important thing to say in response to this motion is that everybody shares the concern that important Australian arts organisations may be jeopardised as a result of the collapse of the Elizabethan Theatre Trust. There are other potential adverse consequences of the Trust's collapse beyond its role as a conduit for taxation, and they are also proper matters for concern which I have discussed with the Australia Council and with the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories. They are matters of proper and continuing interest and concern.

My opposition to this motion is that it presumes a refusal to accept financial responsibilities in a circumstance where the proper and sensible discussions continue, and that Senator Baume, in his support for it, assumed that the Government should somehow have ensured the collapse of the Elizabethan Theatre Trust by warning everybody that it was going into receivership and that we had failed in some way to make the criteria available, when in fact it was made public yesterday and the information is being distributed, the register has been established, and the bodies that meet those criteria will be included on it on the basis of their applications.

On the basis of the agreement we entered into about this debate, having spoken for the same length of time as Senator Baume, although there are other things I might have wished to say about it, I conclude my remarks at this stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the nature of the commercial arrangement between the Commonwealth and Carrington Slipways Pty Limited and/or the Carrington subsidiary, Ramsay Fibreglass, over the Glass Reinforced Plastic (GRP) facility at Tomago in Newcastle.
(2) How many people are employed at the GRP facility and who is their employer.

(3) What impact does the receivership of Carrington Slipways Pty Limited have: (a) over the arrangements detailed in answer to question (1); and (b) over the future employment of workers at the GRP facility.
(4) What outstanding contracts are there between the Commonwealth and Carrington Slipways Pty Limited and/or Ramsay Fibreglass, and what contracts involve work being carried out at the GRP facility.

(5) Are there any other GRP facilities in Australia equivalent in capability to the facility in Tomago; if so, what are their names and where are they located; if not, where would the Commonwealth propose to place orders for further vessels of the Rushcutter class Inshore Minehunters if the trials of the prototype vessels are deemed successful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is presently no commercial arrangement between the Defence Department and Carrington Slipways Pty Limited or that Company's Fibreglass Division in relation to the now Defence-owned fibreglass construction facility at Tomago. The Licence Agreement under which the Company operated in the facility was terminated on 25 January 1991 following advice of non-compliance with Agreement terms from the Mortgagee Agent.
(2) There are no Contractor personnel employed in the facility but 2 Commonwealth staff have been retained for caretaking and management.

(3) The insolvency of Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd has resulted in termination of the licence arrangements under which the Company operated in the facility. Re-employment of Company workers will depend upon whether a user can be found for the facility.

(4) There are no outstanding contracts between the Defence Department and the Company involving work in the facility although the Company was in contract with the Customs Department for the construction of two 20-metre patrol launches at the time of insolvency. The Customs department is conducting separate negotiations with potential contractors for completion of these vessels outside the Tomago facility.

(5) The Tomago GRP facility was purpose-built for Minehunter Inshore (MHI) construction; whilst high-grade GRP shipbuilding facilities exist elsewhere in Australia it is unlikely any would meet the stringent environmental control and minimum-magnetic standards required for modern mine countermeasure vessels (MCMVs). In the event that further MHIs or other MCMV types are constructed in Australia it is possible the Tomago facility would be used by the shipbuilder concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister bring up-to-date the information contained in the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1070 (Senate Hansard, 15 August 1989, p. 95); if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the Structural Review of Higher ADF Staff Arrangements an overall reduction of 10 two star, 15 one star and 102 colonels and below has been achieved.

Also during 1989-90 there was a reduction of 300 in Defence Central civilian staff which has been achieved through natural attrition. An additional 17 Senior Executive Service positions (equivalent to military star ranks) were abolished making a total of 35 such positions abolished since 1986.

A number of major reviews which could affect the levels of ADF and civilian manpower are nearing completion. These reviews include the Force Structure Review, the Defence Regional Support Review, the deliberations of the Inter-Departmental Committee on the Wrigley Report and consideration of the future structure of the Reserves. Recommendations from those reviews will be considered soon and the Government's decision announced by mid-year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated annual cost of: (a) training; and (b) the standard award rate and average overtime for 12 months for each of the following occupations: (i) heavy plant operator, (ii) surveyor engineer, (iii) air traffic controller, (iv) jet propulsion engineer, (v) marine radio operator, and (vi) aircraft electrical engineer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following discussion with the honourable senator's office, it was agreed that the information to be provided in the answer would relate to the categories of occupations specified as employed in the Australian public sector. The answer to the honourable senator's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Training. Heavy Plant Operators are employed on production of the necessary certificate indicating that they are competent and trained to operate a particular range of equipment. Changes to the equipment inventory may require subsequent training and this is undertaken on an as required basis. No information is centrally available on training costs.

(b) Rate of Pay. The rate of pay for heavy plant operators depends upon the size and capacity type of the equipment in use. The award rate of pay for operators of a typical range of equipment is $22,070-$23,370 per annum.
The rate of pay for heavy plant operators employed in the Australian Defence Forces, as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, ranges from $22,160-$24,037 pa.
Overtime. Figures for overtime are not readily available as records are not centrally based.

(ii) Surveyor Engineer: As surveyor engineers are not employed as such in the Australian Public Service (APS), there is no available information on this classification however below is general information relating to engineers employed in the APS.
(a) Training. Entry to the Professional Officer structure in the Australian Public Service as a professional engineer would require:
1. a degree or diploma of an Australian tertiary institution or comparable overseas qualification or;
2. eligibility for membership of, or registration by, an appropriate engineering professional body or;
3. other qualifications which are deemed appropriate by the Secretary of the employing Department.

(b) Rate of Pay. The annual award rate of pay for a qualified engineer undertaking professional engineering duties (as classified as a Professional Officer under the Public Service Act) ranges from $24,100 to $55,000 pa.
The rate of pay for surveyor engineers employed in the Australian Defence Forces, as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, is from $26,052-$59,752 pa.
Overtime. Information on overtime is not available on this classification as records are not centrally based.

(a) Training. An allowance of $8,000 pa is paid to 200 students (totalling approximately $1.6 million pa) intending to become air traffic controllers and who are attending a training course run by the Civil Aviation Authority.

About fifty staff are Air-Traffic-Controllers-in Training and the estimated costs for this group (i.e. salary including penalties) is $589,000 p.a. The cost of training the remaining senior Air Traffic Controllers (Bands 1-4) is $1,065,480, i.e. 30% of the total basic annual salary. This training is not compulsory but is necessary to maintain a viable Air Traffic Control System, and for individual progress in the air traffic controller career structure.
(b) Rate of pay. The award rate of pay is from $22,664 p.a. for an air traffic controller in training to a maximum rate of $47,672.00 p.a.

The rate of pay for an air surveillance operator (the Australian Defence Force equivalent of an air traffic controller), as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, ranges from $22,160-$35,798 pa.
Overtime. The estimated average annual cost of overtime is $3,700 p.a. for each individual for 1990/91.

(iv) Jet Propulsion Engineers: Jet propulsion engineers are not employed as such in the Australian Public Service, therefore no information is available on this classification. However general information on engineers employed in the APS is provided in paragraph (ii).
Jet propulsion engineers are employed in the Australian Defence Forces and their professional rate of pay, as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, ranges from $27,969-$35,798 pa.
Information is provided on marine radio officers (as opposed to operators).

(a) Training. No basic training is carried out as officers are employed with the relevant qualifications. Other training is undertaken on an ad hoc basis as changes to equipment and procedures dictate.
(b) Rate of Pay. Marine Radio Officers are paid an aggregate salary which includes components for overtime and penalty payments. The pay rate is $38,620 to $41,173 per annum.
Marine radio operators employed in the Australian Defence Forces are paid in the range of $24,307-$35,798 pa, as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal.

(vi) Aircraft Electrical Engineer: Aircraft Electrical Engineers are not employed as such in the Australian Public Service, therefore no information is available on this classification. However general information on engineers employed in the APS is provided in paragraph (ii).
An aircraft engineer employed in the Australian Defence Forces is paid in the range of $22,829-$55,798 pa, as determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal.
NOTE: The above figures for the ADF equivalents do not include Service Allowance which currently is $4373 pa.
